reviewText: I remember watching gameplay during E3 2013 and thinking it looked like just another generic FPS with the Wolfenstein brand slapped on". Here I am a year later eating those words
date: as Wolfenstein: The New Order is most probably my game of the year for 2014.\n\nSerious Sam style over-the-top one-man-army gameplay that feels amazing
recommended: with a meaty arsenal of weapons (all of which can be dual-wielded) and a heavy reliance on health and armour pickups as opposed to health regeneration.\n\nThe alternate post-WW2 setting is also incredibly well realised
hoursPlayed:
with varied and interesting locales that stay interesting over the course of the games 8-10 hour length.  Not to mention the game's soundtrack featuring Nazi-fied versions of famous real world songs is worth a look on its own.

Combined with a surprisingly well told story featuring characters that you'll actually care about (with special mention going to Brian Bloom's performance as BJ Blazkowicz) makes this the freshest single player FPS I've played this generation. Hands down.

If you're even remotely interested in this game

reviewText:
It turns out that Wolfenstein: The New Order wasn’t quite what I expected. I figured it’d be an over-the-top, vaguely ridiculous game about shooting Nazis with improbably large weapons, which never really took itself too seriously. In actual fact, it’s a game about shooting Nazis with improbably large weapons, which occasionally takes itself entirely seriously. I’m not sure I’d ever say it’s subtle or understated, but it tries to do a bit more than the bare minimum.

Yes, there are battles against cyborg dogs and men in giant robot suits. Yes, there’s a degree of mysticism – or at least, there are ancient Jewish weapons of mass destruction. Yes, there are German covers of The Beatles songs, and yes, there are some laughably macho one-liners. There’s a lot of faintly ridiculous stuff in here.

Wolfenstein: The New Order casts you as B. J. Blazkowicz, an utterly gigantic American whose LinkedIn profile contains hundreds of endorsements for his skills at murdering Nazis. The game kicks off in a 1946 level as dull as it is brown; at this point, the Nazis are winning World War 2 due to technology hundreds of years in advance of what they should have. Things do not go according to plan, and Blazkowicz spends the next 14 years in a vegetative state, returning to his senses only when the hospital he’s in is closed down and he’s about to be unceremoniously “purged” as a sub-human. In 1960, the Nazi regime rules the world… which just means there are even more Nazis for Blazkowicz to kill than before.And that, really, is your job. Kill Nazis, find the resistance, kill Nazis, help find a way to fight back against the Nazi menace, and kill Nazis. Also, kill Nazis.

Killing Nazis can primarily be accomplished in one of two ways. You can opt for the guns-out route, charging around levels firing wildly and rabidly slaughtering everything in your path, or you can opt to take a more stealthy route, sneaking around and stabbing them in the neck. More than likely, you’ll have to employ both at different times – and not just when the game commands you to go for one playstyle or another.

The main reason for this is the presence of Nazi Commanders, who are cowardly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that continually call for reinforcements if they spot you. In any area containing these guys, you’ll at the very least want to make sure you know where they are before the alarms go off so that you can make a beeline to them and cut them down. Still, you can either charge directly for them guns blazing, or sneak your way through and stab them in the skull. Both options are entirely viable, and unlike most FPS games with enforced stealth sections, the stealth here actually works.

You’ve got a wide variety of weapons, almost all of which can be dual-wielded, and all of which have alternate firing modes. You can lurk around a corner and blast away with an automatic shotgun equipped with shrapnel shells that ricochet. You can pull out a pair of assault rifles, switch one of them to its rocket launching alt-fire mode, and go to town. You can peek out from behind cover with a marskman rifle, or use your Laserkraftwerk to turn Nazis into a messy red smear. All of these weapons have a satisfying sound and satisfying impact.

The biggest problem facing Wolfenstein: The New Order is that there isn’t a huge amount which stands out and makes it exceptional. There are some excellent segments like the trailed train scene, some fun locations, a lot of backstory in the form of newspaper clippings, plenty of hidden items to find and bonuses to unlock, a number of tragic moments underpinned by some excellent writing… but for the most part, it’s just an extremely well-assembled game that marries stealth and adrenaline-pumping over-the-top action far better than you might expect.

If there is one genuinely bad thing, though, it’s probably idTech 5. My first time through the game I actually suffered relatively few problems, although Wolfenstein: The New Order was clearly chewing through my hardware like a starving man at a buffet. The second time was a bit more problematic: tearing was abundant, lip-synching was out of time with the audio, texture pop-in was noticeable, and there was a weird multi-coloured haze flashing around fast-moving characters.

I’d argue it’s probably the best Wolfenstein game since 1992’s Wolfenstein 3D. It’s just that, good as it is, it’s not mind-blowingly spectacular. Wolfenstein: The New Order is a solid, highly-polished shooter that’ll provide around a dozen hours of entertainment, with a unique setting, some good writing, and strong mechanics. That’s all it is, but that’s no bad thing.

reviewText:
+ Partially destructible environments
+ Absolutely jaw-dropping, stunning soundtrack; does wonders to set the mood and keep you immersed in the game
+ Voice-acting was borderline flawless, and the dialogue superbly scripted
+ Authentic German and other languages pervasive throughout the game
+ Tons and tons of lore-friendly articles and collectibles throughout
+ A hidden, Wolfenstein 3D minigame that almost deserves a review of its own accord; the nostalgia was overwhelming
+ Interesting, creative, and lore-friendly weapon designs
+ Facial animations, particularly the protagonist, were done very well and did much to convey the nuances of emotional expression
+ So much attention to detail, in every respect
+ Weapon customizations, while somewhat sparse, were a delight and really enriched the gameplay
+ Developers really seemed to capture the feel of the Nazis, and really nailed the Nazi rhetoric in a way that felt authentic
+ The narrative was well-delivered, meticulously thought-out, and shattered my expectations with an intense emotional depth
+ Gunplay, melee, and stealth mechanics were all solid and well-designed (though, didn't sport much in the way of innovation)

- There are times that you will lament the absence of an objective marker; easy to get turned around in some levels
- Poor environmental textures
- Moving down ladders is a massive hazard and a minor design flaw
- Minor fetch quests in the Resistance's 'secret base' are good for enriching the plot and character developement, but could have been better implemented in that it noticeably breaks up the pacing of the game and felt tedious above all else

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is pretty metal, I guess.

So, a few weeks ago I found myself without internet. Not knowing what to do with my life outside of do heroine I was going to a pawn shop to get a gun so I can just turn it all off. There I encountered Wolfestein: The New Order buried in a box of various other Nazi paraphernalia. It was either gun or the game, I went with the game. Yes, I know, I should have gone with the gun.

Wolfenstein: The Last Guardian starts in 1946 during a joint allied air assault on Deathshead's compound after the Nazi's dropped all of that D&D ♥♥♥♥ from the previous games and settled down on cold hard science. The assault probably would have worked if it wasn't for the giant robot dog. Also, they should have attacked the ground, not the air. Good job America, there are no Nazi's up there.

Yet.

You play as JC Denton. I mean B.J. Blazkowicz. A very handsome man from the previous games who seems to be unable to go a few minutes without killing a Nazi. B.J. accompanies the allied attack force to the Deathshead compound where he proves that he is the only person competent enough to use his gun. Everything goes wrong and B.J. is left with a shard of metal in his head the size of my kidney stones and remains a prisoner in his own body for dozens of years. Much like my kidney stones.

Now in 1960, B.J. Wakes up after he smells Nazi and once again continues his one man army slaughter of Astral-Lich Hitler's entire army. On this adventure, B.J. meets new friends, discovers new and wonderful places, and learns the true meaning of forgiveness.

Haha, I'm just joshing you, he kills a lot of people.

And killing Nazi's is something B.J. is really good at. Unlike most of the wimps that plague shooters these days, our all American psychopath is more than capable of carrying more than two guns at any given time, even two of various guns to be exact. And good thing too since the guns pretty much make the game.

Each and every gun has this umph to it, a crunch if you will. Shooting them and hitting something looks like it hurts, something a good number of shooters these days seems to lack. Isn't that right, Bioshock:Infinite? You disgrace. Your enemies react to being shot, stumbling and fumbling in a way that makes you feel sorry for any poor mook you manage to hit.  Each gun has competent damage and it's hard to pick out a favorite. But it's gonna be the assault rifle because...I mean...Come on look at it, this thing is friggin awesome.

On B.J.'s mass murder adventures, you meet all kinds of new and interesting Nazi's to shoot. Such as.
-Nazi.
-Super Nazi
-large Nazi
-Angry Robot Nazi
-Angry Robot Dog Nazi
-Uncomfortably sexual Nazi Lady
-Uncomfortably sexual Nazi boy.
And who could forget.
-Muscle Nazi.

“But Dirk, you incredibly charismatic man who crackles with sexual energy.” You ask. “How could you have beaten the game if you only have 2 hours on Steam?”

While I agree that I crackle with sexual energy, I still didn't have the internet when I played this game. None of my time was actually logged, but I assure you, that I played this game from start to finish.

But should you play Wolfenstein: The recent book club?

Yes, you should. Wolfenstein is everything a shooter should be. While I do miss the amazing multiplayer from Return or Enemy Territories. The game more than makes up for it with it's satisfying gun play and return to form with it's love for said satisfying gun play. Wolfenstein knows what it is and doesn't try to be anything else. You can be stealthy if you really want, and sometimes that's fun too, but come on, look at what they give you to work with, it's screaming at you to just let lose and tear someone a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

Wolfenstein: The current Chess Match gets 17 men screaming in German out of a possible 17 and the Dickbutt golden award. It's just an Emmy I found in Bill Murry's trash that I drew a mustache on. But it's still a very prestigious award.

The Curator, sometimes I update it: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

reviewText:
I have been a fan of Wolfenstein since the original and I was hoping beyond reason that the latest incarnation of this single player first person shooter classic did the franchise justice. And it did that and then some. It went back to the basics, polished them up, and delivered one of the best games I have played in a long time.

This game is a single player FPS in its purest form. Lots of enemies, lots of weapons and lots of different viable ways to play. It has a great mix of stealth, tactical shooting and all out, in your face, duel auto-shotgun wiedling, death dealing mayhem. It manages to make killing Nazis a lot of fun, and manages to keep it fun throughout the whole game.

Not for the squeemish and not for those who object to people killing Nazis. But for any single player first person shooter gamer, this is a must have game.

See my full review here : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9zNiVH-J334

reviewText:
This game is really damn good. And that was unexpected, to me, after all, who expects anything from a Wolfenstein, especially after Wolf 2009? As a sequel-reboot, this game is all parts visceral, gritty, and smart.
The story is simple, of course- what if the Nazis had won WW2 with a little help from some ancient technology so advanced as to seem supernatural? That's the game's only hook into its mystic past. That's where the simplicity ends- the story is brilliant and brutal, told initially through the eyes of BJ, an invalid, forced to watch from his wheelchair as the Nazis take over the world, systematically killing everyone they deem untermensch. It's enough to give you great catharsis when he finally stands up from his chair. The characters are superbly animated and acted, giving real life to the world. BJ is actually cast as something of the typical action hero, optimistic and unsuited for the gritty world he finds himself in, it works.
The gameplay is pretty standard FPS faire. It's got enough enemies for BJ to mow down to harken back to earlier Wolf, you can even wield akimbo weapons owing to BJ being a meathead. Enemy variety is good and the level design is impressive, often monolithic Nazi architecture though there are several excursions to unique locations- concentration camps, U-boats, the Nazi moonbase, etc. It's even got a decent length for a singleplayer FPS these days, about 20 hours.
Don't pass this up. Play this game.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a game with a story that begins in 1946, then fast-forwards to 1960. The Nazis won the war in 1946, the Allies lost, so that Nazis have taken over the world. The introduction to the narrative is long enough that it takes a long time for B.J. Blazkowicz, the main protagonist of the Wolfenstein series, to carry firearms. Mr. Blazkowicz fought in the war for the U.S., but was wounded and spends time in a Polish mental institution in a vegetative state until 1960.

This game is a continuation of the famous Wolfenstein series that has no shame in allowing you to kill as many Nazis as possible. Cities like Berlin and London are now occupied by Nazis as technological terrors such as large mechs and robotic dogs patrol the streets. There are many propaganda posters strewn throughout Germany and London, England making it clear that the Nazis are ruling and that citizens who violate their laws will be severely punished. Mr. Blazkowicz is the man who will take on the Nazis with some help from NPCs who will advise him on where to go and what objectives to complete. Killing Nazis is in his DNA.

The narrative requires you to choose one of two paths that will be slightly different from each other based on which two comrades will die at the hands of evil General Deathshead, the leader of the Nazis. Deathshead kills one of the two comrades you choose for death so that he can use him in an evil experiment that he says will change the world for the better. You will then have to play the game based on the survivor’s timeline. This ability to choose may be cruel, but it adds replayability to the game by encouraging you to play the game twice so that you can experiences both timelines that result in slightly different versions of the narrative.

The gameplay is pretty much an old school FPS. The weapons in the game are not innovative, but they still feel very satisfying and have alternate modes. The run –of-the-mill weapons include handguns, assault rifles, shotguns, and sniper rifles. Each aforementioned weapon can be upgraded and the upgrades will be necessary to take on the bigger and more powerful Nazis. Assault rifles feel powerful when dual wielding them and can be upgraded by acquiring the rocket upgrade. There are perks in the game that you can keep track of that Mr. Blazkowicz can acquire throughout the game to improve the stealth, tactical, assault, and demolition aspects of combat. These perks add a role-playing like feel to the game. The ability to pick up ammo, weapons, health, and armor feels a like old school FPS.

There are certain locales that seem to encourage stealth. This is when the knife comes in handy, allowing you to slash unsuspecting Nazis from behind. The slashings are truly gory and horrific, but satisfying since it feels like they deserve to be slashed by your blade. Some locales can overwhelm you to death if you don’t use stealth, especially if there are officers stationed there. You can detect signals that alert you to the presence of officers. Officers are capable of calling in reinforcements to overwhelm. Stealthily taking down officers is rewarding as the game’s map will open up and reveals secret items such as enigma codes, letters, and gold items. There are other locales that seem to encourage a shootout with Nazis of different sizes and abilities. Nazis are varied enough in terms of clothing and weapons. Some Nazis are powerful rocket wielding and shotgun wielding foes that will seriously test your FPS skills such as the ability to take cover. The levels are varied enough as they include a prison that you must infiltrate, a lunar base run by Nazis, the city of London filled with swastikas to indicate Nazi dominance, and a base occupied by Mr. Blazkowicz’s friends where he receive objectives. It is interesting to see an alternate perspective of World War II with the Nazis winning the war and dominating the world. They actually landed on the moon before the U.S. could ever land one of its own citizens on the moon.

I have always been of the opinion that characters in games should speak their native language. This game nails it by having Nazis speak German when engaged in combat. It makes the game feel more immersive than if they all spoke the English language in a setting that is German. Some of Blazkowicz’s friends speak German and say a few words in German. I felt like I was truly in Germany when the Nazis spoke German during combat. The A.I. is not always perfect, but it is good enough to test your FPS abilities in the spur of the moment.

One new weapon in the game is the laser cutter known as the laserkraftwerk (LKW). When you first acquire this weapon, it is a utility that can be used to cut holes in metal gratings that block your progress. There are other metal gratings that can be cut for the purpose of finding secret items. Once it is upgraded the LKW becomes more than a utility item: it then contains an alternate mode which is a weapon that is very effective against mechanical enemies. They don’t require ammo since they run on batteries that can be recharged at the various recharge stations.

The graphics look very modern and make the 1992 version of Wolfenstein seem pale in comparison. The cutscenes look polished. The levels look picturesque and very realistic, whether they are in Berlin, Germany or London, England.

I think this 2014 entry into the Wolfenstein franchise is breath of fresh air. The narrative is always interesting, although it felt like it took a little too long to carry a weapon, let alone engage in intense combat. This game provides an interesting perspective on what it would be like if the Nazis had controlled the world after World War II. The gameplay is challenging enough that it forces you to think about how to approach dangerous combat situations. The acting performances are convincing, especially from the evil Deathshead to the courageous Caroline Becker, who is an important guide for Mr. Blazkowicz. This FPS is definitely worth playing.

My Score: 9/10

It looks as good as any modern shooter, plays like the mid 2000's shooters like Soldier of Fortune you remember so well, and tells a story so ridiculous yet so deathly serious you can't help but get caught up in it. Not to mention the characters. Hell, it's been weeks since I beat this game and I can still name all the main characters in this story without hardly even thinking about it. They're all so well realized. So well voiced. They're all important. It's a rare thing in shooters these days.  But it all comes back to Blazko:

One part Lt. Aldo Raine, two parts John McClane and three parts Bear Jew. BJ is back and a better character than he has ever been. Simply put, he IS the baddest Nazi Killin' ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you've ever met. And he's not going down without a fight. Or two. Or three. Or ten. reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bj5AIlEq9mg&list=PLr7nIc3VxybRe46UbAa9ymQCiSIaDkwNe
Wolfenstein: The New Order best exemplifies the cyclical nature of the FPS market. A decade ago, the FPS market was littered with World War 2 shooters, including the Wolfenstein franchise's best entry, Return to Castle Wolfenstein, and since then the shooter market has migrated away from Nazi culling and has placed it's cross hairs on the insurgents, terrorists and Russians that populate the modern landscape. The ebb and flow of first person shooters has brought us full circle in 2014 with the latest entry to the franchise that gave birth to what has become, arguably, the most popular genre in all of gaming. The New Order mixes the classic, gib infused, lead slinging, Nazi mutilating gameplay that defined the series with modern design elements like stealth and multiple time lines for added replayability. This kind of retro game design is ambitious to say the least, so has MachineGames pulled off a Cirque de Soleil worthy performance or has it fallen and racked it's testes, rendering this classic, macho franchise an impotent eunuch?

Perhaps no other element best exemplifies this clash between modern design and retro sensibilities than The New Order's plot. It's a battleground unto itself where some startlingly realized character relationships find themselves at odds with the sheer absurdity of it's alternate take on history. Three years after the events of the original game, the Nazi's have developed advanced technology that have allowed them to turn the tide of the war. In a massive Allied assault on a weapons laboratory run by General Deathshead, B.J. Blazkowicz suffers a near fatal encounter with the sadistic general, enduring a critical head injury that leaves him in a vegetative state. Like the second coming of Christ, Blazkowicz comes to fourteen years later to find that the  Nazis won the war by being the first to utilize nuclear weapons, and it's up to him to become the messiah of the resistance movement that rages against the Third Reich in a fight that stretches across the globe and even to the moon. It's a narrative that is gloriously kitschy and slightly reminiscent of Iron Sky, though without the clever satire. Counter balancing the B-movie sci-fi narrative are some character interaction s and relationships that are extremely well realized and engaging. Some of the antagonists in The New Order are extremely memorable in ways that so few antagonists have been in recent games. Frau Engel in particular stands out, with her Raiden-esque androgynous male companion and devious, psychotic games. The game's levels are littered with newspaper clippings and audio logs that flesh out this vision of a Nazi ruled world.

Without a single Tommy Gun or Garand in sight, the gunplay in Wolfenstein's latest entry sets itself apart from the seemingly ceaseless wave of World War 2 based first person shooters that inundated the market pre 2007. Weapons have a very heavy feel to them with high recoil and their propensity to cause Nazi skulls to erupt like melons dropped from a fourth story window. Adding to the carnage are goodies like an underslung rocket launcher for your assault rifle, shotgun rounds that bounce around corners and the ability to dual wield most weapons. The lack of recharging health and collectable armor give the impression that The New Order is an old school run and gun affair but strangely it's not... Stealth is a viable option and generally recommended. Sneaking up on a Nazi and carving him up like a Christmas ham can be just as satisfying as perforating him with an entire magazine. Unfortunately, the stealth also exposes what proves to be The New Order's greatest fault, the enemy AI seems to have suffered from the inbreeding of the master race. Enemies are not terribly perceptive and have little interest in preserving themselves or employing cunning strategies to put an end to your rebellion. Despite the fact that you will find yourself tackling waves of enemies, don't expect to be flanked or flushed out of cover. Wolfenstein does provide some challenge despite the dim witted opposition, unfortunately it's the result of foes that are massive bullet sponges. In the later portion of the game a large number of armored enemies can make progress slow going, and the possibility of running out of ammo is very real.

While most of the weapons in The New Order fall into conventional categories for FPS weaponry, there is one unique and welcome addition to the arsenal: the LaserKraftWerk. It's part tool and part Nazi exterminator, allowing B.J. to cut through metal grates exposing, collectables, items and hidden passages. Through the course of the game's 15 hour campaign, the LaserKraftWerk is upgraded allowing it's beams to be reflected, target several enemies, and fire in full auto.

Levels in The New Order are often sprawling and offer multiple paths to an objective. This creates the illusion of occupying a real place instead of a methodically scripted, linear level and also provides numerous opportunities for collectables and easter eggs to be tucked away for those keen on exploring to dig them up. Among these collectables are bits of the Enigma code which gives players a puzzle that, when solved, unlock four additional game modes. Unfortunately silly scripted sequences do interrupt the flow of these levels, it's touch of modern design that The New Order could certainly do without. Variety is commendable and over the course of the lengthy campaign, you will help B.J. fight off Xenomorph inspired robot dogs,  break into prison, hijack a U-Boat and tour Nazi occupied London. In addition, there are two separate timelines that alter some of the game's events providing a small incentive for players to play through the game again.

MachineGame's brings to life a fanciful interpretation of Hitler's neoclassic and art deco laden vision of a world constructed by the Aryan people, though it's largely rendered in an oppressive gray that the fuhrer would surely disapprove of for his ideologically driven utopia. Strands of 1950's futurist design also round out the art direction, bringing to life the most absurd and fantastic elements of the game. Some of the environments can get a bit repetitive since there is little reprieve from the cold muted color pallet and unwelcoming locals but some unique and arresting locations prevent players from becoming too disenchanted with the visuals. Characters look great in stills but their googly doll-like eyes make them look lifeless and disturbing in action but their animations make up for some of this as characters emote in a convincing manner. Thankfully, the voice acting is top notch and more importantly there are German voice overs sparring players from suffering through silly faux German accented English performances or worse, the 1950's American cinema trend of having English actors play Germans.

Out with the old Wolfenstein, and in with The New Order. MachineGames has delivered a strong game that pays homage to the legacy of Wolfenstein while providing some modernizing gameplay elements and, for the most part, they make it work. The abhorrent AI is the strongest detractor that this gloriously absurd first person shooter has but strong level design, visceral weapons and an irreverence for history and realism are a breath of fresh air. While the lack of multiplayer will be a hard blow for fans of Enemy Territory, the robust single player experience complete with unlockables makes The New Order worth the price of admission.  If you can put up with this wild alternate version of history and the bullet sponge Nazis that populate it, The New Order is worth playing. It wobbles and slips on the high wire bridging old and new, threatening to fall, but it makes it across; bravado and manhood in tact.

reviewText:
My FIRST impressions of Wolfenstein TNO weren't flattering; The intro is so dull and typical that I almost dismissed the entire game.
I'm glad I stuck it out a little longer, because it quickly turned into a superb campaign with varied gameplay and imaginative writing.

Quick pros/cons:

Pros:
+Lengthy campaign with replay value (I don't exactly rush but my first play through on hard was 15-18 hours)
+Satisfying gun play
+Great story

Cons:
-I don't care for the ID tech 5 engine, with its immersion-breaking texture pop-in, and its hatred of AMD hardware
-Aside from one major choice in the beginning, it is highly linear. This doesn't bother me too much, but B.J. is a bloodthirsty German hater, so you'd best be prepared to creep up behind a man harmlessly takin' a leak, drown him in his own ♥♥♥♥-water, shove a knife into the back of his head, and finally to add insult to injury, flush the toilet and flip him the bird.
-Even though I feel like the game wants you to like him, I found the protagonist B.J. somewhat annoying. He's an idiot, but maybe I'm being too hard on him considering the shrapnel in his brain. Its a wonder he can even still butcher Nazis at all.

Very recommended. Probably worth full price, though I got it 50% off and that's a steal.

reviewText:
I am so anxious to review this game. Ladies and gentlemen, I think I have found a new favorite.
Being a testosterone filled man with deep-seated cravings for violence hard-coded into my DNA from my primal, dinosaur hunting ancestors I of course lose my mind when I come across something that's hardcore, violent, action-packed and overall manly. Wolfenstein: The New Order of course, does not let me down.
Starting off with the basics: Wolfenstein is a revisit of the classic shooter series of the same name, taking on the role of Captain B.J. Blazkowicz you start the game in a desperate final push against the German war machine in 1946 (this is an alternate timeline of our history, so don't be upset if the game isn't historically accurate). Wolfenstein has amazing gunplay, a good story that is much more gripping than I expected, excellent level design and all-around great variety.
The gameplay is mostly focused on the shooting, as you can expect from a classic FPS revisit. The firearms have a steady and satisfying punch to them and enemies react appropriately when shot, making for some very nice gameplay. You also have the option to dual-wield most of the weapons in the game, firing two at once by holding down both mouse buttons increasing your overall damage per second but draining your ammo supply faster, but who cares? Manliness brotha. After each shootout the level is noticably affected by it, where most first-person shooters would leave a small handful of bodies and a few splashes of blood on the walls, Wolfenstein has great bullet-impact decals, destructable cover and very nice gore effects, making the area immediately after the slaughter look like it has been completely decimated by the shootout, again, making you feel like an unstoppable bad-@ss.
However, the gameplay is not just restricted to you being an unstoppable killing force. You can also play with a more stealth-minded approach, using a silencer attachment to your pistol, satisfying melee takedowns and even being able to throw your knives for an instant and silent kill. The game is pretty adaptable and while the AI isn't too suited for stealth it still gets the job done well enough. There are four different skill-trees in the game that unlock perks for the player as the game progresses, but unlike most skill-tree based games there isn't some level-up system followed by going into the menu and selecting which perk you want, instead the perks are unlocked based on challenges such as X amount of stealth kills, X amount of pistol kills etc. so the player does not need to concern themselves with carefully selecting perks based on an in-game meta, instead simply play the game the way you like to play it, and everything else will fall into place.
And before I get off the subject of gameplay, I want to make a quick sub-note: The enemies in this game just look badass. I love the Panzerhunds, the giant robot wolves with dagger-pointed teeth, and the frankenstein super-soldiers. Just. Wow, I feel my testosterone levels going berserk just thinking about it.
Level design in Wolfenstein is also very well made, with a fine balance between being fluid and controlled when it wants to be and switching to tight and intense when it needs to be. The transition between them is flawless, and each and every level has a unique design to them, making every chapter memorable and avoids being repetitive. In each level also are several hidden secrets, easter-eggs and collectables, creating a very welcome replay value to the game. I do indeed look forward to playing through again.
Now to the story: I wasn't expecting a huge impact with the story when I bought this game, similar to my expectations with Shadow Warrior. I was anticipating a mindless, shut-off-my-brain bullet and blood shower. But to my pleasant surprise Wolfenstein did in fact create a mighty well done story, not the best I've seen in any regard but surpassed all my expectations. B.J. Blazkowicz was taking part in the final push hoping to end the war in 1946, but events did not go according to plan and he and his team are captured and barely manage to escape, B.J. suffering a severe head injury in the process, putting him into a coma for 14 years. 1960, the war is over and the world is now under the iron-fist of the Third Reich, B.J. is in a vegitative state in a hospital in Poland when he is suddenly awoken by the scent of Nazi blood (MANLINESS). Seeing the world under control of the enemy he dedicated his life to destroy with extreme prejudice, he sets off to find any form of resistance to take the Reich apart piece by piece and take down his rival, a bitter little saurkraut known to most as Deathshead.
While the story did exceed my expectations it also left a few disappointments as well. There were missed opportunities to create some very powerful and emotional moments that the game just slid over, but there are other times where the game doesn't shy away from doing just that. The story is surprisingly good, not exactly the most original of scripts but it was a very interesting idea and it did leave a memorable impact. Now that said, there are some sour-points with the story: Out-of-nowhere plot devices that are never mentioned again in the entire game, just serving no purpose other than to make the story advance. Sometimes the game will try to create some dramatic moments with some characters who are no better than cut-outs: Some examples include obvious love-interest girl, obvious trust-issues guy with a shady past, obvious Jewish guy who does everything to remind you that he's Jewish, obviously Hodor from Game of Thrones, and B.J. himself is for the most part just the heavily-muscled jarhead who always means well but will not let anything get between him and his mission. The ending was also very vague and left way too much unanswered, but there's DLC coming in so maybe that'll change, assuming you're not a cranky anti-DLC activist.

So to wrap all this up: Wolfenstein: The New Order is a game that met and exceeded all my expectations, it was a great joy to play beginning to end. I highly recommend Wolfenstein: The New Order.

reviewText:
*Firstly this game isnt really ideal for children, its pretty brutal with lots of blood and a couple of adult scenes here n there.

But the game itself is truly awesome, theres tons of enemies to blast away and a good level of destruction to keep things messy, you can use stealth tactics or just run in all guns blazing and tear the place apart, its upto you how you want to deal with it.

The storyline is great and the look and feel of the game fits perfect, its old nazi steampunk style with lots of blood and action.
The missions follow the story and are all pretty unique from each other with a good variety of interesting tasks and enemies, you also have collectables and a small perk system to get weapon upgrades etc which are also pretty cool.
The weapons themselves are pretty awesome, you can duel weild almost all of them including auto shotguns and just cause mayhem, its hella fun!

Overall this game is a superb FPS (single player only) excellent graphics and gameplay, controls are fast and responsive with keybind options too, plenty of gun action and knife throwing, the only downside is once youve completed it then thats really it, but you do have achievements to aim for if thats your kinda thing.

If your looking for a good few hours of pure action and fun (around 15-25hrs with achievements id say) then this is the game for you, maybe best getting at a discount price if you can but its worth every penny you pay, fantastic!

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is the first game this year I've actively played to completion at every opportunity. It's that good. It's a game which felt, to me, like the original Unreal, Quake 2, Quake 4 and of course, Return to Castle Wolfenstein. It's solid, polished and when the gun fights are going down it's magnificent, fluid and testing. The boss fights are testing at points too with audio hints and clues if you get a little stuck working out what to do. The main point to make here is the boss fights are well designed with an old school approach in mind. They require some quick reflexes, fast thinking and a little intelligence/perception to work out what to do. I love this, I really do.

The sound track is like silky smooth milk chocolate to the ears. The music fits the ambience of the levels/scenarios and really gets the adrenaline pumping during gun fights. The sound track changes on the fly depending on how much action is going on at any given time and never seems out of place. It invoked emotion in me. If I made a mistake while taking the stealth option and was forced to bring out the akimbo assault rifles the music adapated fueling my adrenaline and passion for mowing down nazis! MEIN LIEBEN!

The graphics are sublime, just stunning. The effort that's gone into the detail, polish and art style really fits the game. Nothing seemed out of place and no detail was spared on static props. It runs like a dream on my system:

AMD FX (Piledriver) 8350 (8 Core) 4Ghz
16gb 1333mhz DDR RAM
Nvidia GTX 670

The reports of the AI being a bit poor, in my opinion, don't hold any water. The enemies are actively taking cover, rolling/sprinting/sliding behind cover, flanking, making smart use of grenades and forcing you out into the fight.

Luckily, I have also encountered no bugs, no crashes and no funnies. I know this isn't the case for everyone but I can only speak from my own personal experience.

It took me, around, thirteen hours to complete the game on Death Incarnate, which is quite reasonable considering your average mainstream game these days are clocking in at around six hours.

The game rewards your play style too. If you want to stealth as much as you can (like me) you can and will be rewarded for it. If you'd prefer to go in all guns blazing (and I'm now going to replay it with the alternate timeline using this method) you will be rewarded for doing so. I like this and I wish more games gave you this option.

I cannot recommend this game enough if you're from the generation which grew up with id, Unreal, 3D Realms, Apogee and Monolith. I'm 99.9% sure you're going to love it and even be charmed by the little touches which blend modern technology and techniques with properly good old school mechanics which started the genre.

I give this 10 Llamas of Super Coolness out of 5 Jam Sandwiches.

Just to add, if the developers or any developers like Splash Damage see this review... Please... PLEASE... make an Enemy Territory: Quake Wars on this id tech engine. The world needs more games like Quake Wars.

reviewText:
After a 5 year absence, B.J. Blazkowicz is back in Wolfenstien: The New Order, the first title from Swedish Devs - Machine Games.

Set in alternate reality 1960s Europe, Nazi Germany has won the 2nd World War, the Allied nations are in ruins and all resistance has been crushed. Or so it seems.

Mixing surrealistic humour with dark themes, WTNO treads a fine line between serious and kitsch. I personally found the story entertaining, even though plot holes abound.

Along your journey to save the world, you'll be fighting hordes of Nazi stormtroopers and robots (robo-dogs included) in open levels that are pretty unique and well desgined. (don't be put off by the 1st level's linearity, it gets better, trust me.)

Gunplay is excellent. Guns sound powerful and bullets have real impact. Enemy a.i. seems decent (played on medium diff)

Sound design is great as well, with support for up to 7.1 surround sound. Did I mention that the soundtrack is great? No? Well, it's freakin' awesome :)

Graphics aren't the best even @ high settings due to the crappy id5 engine used. However, in certain areas, the visuals look pretty damn good.

The story does drag about 3/4 to the end, but I found the ending worth pushing through it. (My 1st playthrough lasted around 15 hours give or take.)

There is no MP component, which may be a pro/con depending on your personal preference, so bear that in mind.

tldr: Highly recommended, best SP shooter I've played in quite a while.

reviewText:
I was very surprised by Wolfenstein: The New Order. I expected an average to above average game, but it ended up being my game of the year (so far!). It’s hard to describe how much I enjoyed it but I will try.

Story wise it’s solid. There’s a great cast of characters that you meet throughout the 15 hour campaign. Each has their own story and their own place in the game world. Even the main protagonist BJ, is a much more fleshed out character than his previous depictions in the Wolfenstein games. Also, the cutscenes are incredible. They blended so well into the gameplay and gave me the impression I was watching a film.

In terms of gameplay, this is where Wolfenstein TNO shined the brightest. Every weapon in the extensive arsenal is fun to use, seriously. The weapon sounds, the destruction of the environment and the pure carnage that you can cause is unforgettable. Almost every weapon has alternate firing modes for mixing up the gunplay and making it more than just an average point and click FPS. Dual wielding originally seemed like an unnecessary novelty, but is actually a lot of fun that adds EVEN MORE variety to the way you can play (ex. one assault rifle can shoot rockets while the other fires full auto). Shooting enemies can pop heads, blast off armour, and generally shows a very detailed level of damage. Throughout almost every level there are multiple paths to choose. Because of this, most encounters can be approached with stealth or a more aggressive route.

Wolfenstein the New Order is easily in my top five games of all time. That’s not something I expected in this day and age (especially with all the crap I’ve played lately). This game is a big deal for me and I hope that others can appreciate it as much as I did, because it really deserves the limelight.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is the latest member of the Wolfenstein series, developed by Machine Games Studio, a relatively new developer founded by former Starbreeze Studio staff.

If you’re looking for a realistic shooter, you won’t find it here; you will, however, find duel wielding assault rifles, lasers death robots and plenty of Nazis for the killing. The gun-play is robust and has a lot of impact; each flavorful weapon comes with two firing modes which gives the player plenty of versatility in combat. There is a laser cannon of sorts in the game which also functions as a wire-cutter that allows you to cut through obstacles and creates new lines of sight and flanking opportunities while in a firefight, it's quite the thing.

The game features many old-school shooter mechanics but with a modern twist, per-se, you still have your overcharge health and pickups, but your health also partially regenerates, it’s a bizarre concept on paper, but works surprisingly well in action. There are also plenty of collectibles, secrets and news articles to collect around the level, encouraging exploration and provide plenty of replay values for the perfectionist. I personally have no problem with the game shipping without a multiplayer, as it can easily take you 15 hours to complete the two diverging campaigns, and to be frank, I’ll rather see a game that has a great single player experience, than trying to do both and turns out to be mediocre on both front, I personally think 15 hours of quality game-play is reasonable for a tripe A game, but you’ll have to decide that for yourself.

The stealth system is fairly basic but luckily completely optional, enemies generally have a fairly short detection range and most sections are pretty straight forward, but even if you fail you can always just go in guns blazing and clean house.

The AI is somewhat inconsistent, however, as enemies will sometimes completely ignore their dead comrades and pretend nothing happened during a stealth section, and constantly running out of cover and staring into the abyss in the middle of the hallway for no apparent reason while in combat.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a solid first person shooter that tries incorporate both the mechanics of old and modern shooters, and succeeded in doing so. The result is a very satisfying arcade action shooter with lots of angry Nazis, explosions and crashes. If you can look pass its ridiculous, but yet somehow compelling story line and a few minor flaws, then Wolfenstein: The New Order is a whole lot of fun, and will most probably leave a smile on your face every time you turn a heavily armored Nazi trooper into a cloud of red mist with a rifle rocket.

reviewText:
Like a coffee gone cold, it's been easy to forget the golden age of the World War II FPS. Albeit edible, any thirsty developer approaches hesitant to the long-gone steam clouds of its hour of freshness. Back before the famed Call of Duty franchise strapped players into the combat boots of the WWII genre, the influential, genre-defining Wolfenstein 3D plotted willing adventurers into the labyrinths of a Nazi prison, with chances of survival as slim as the knife you begin with. Fictictious war hero B.J. Blazkowicz has since become a legendary icon in the realm of interactive media. It's 2014, and MachineGames has not feebly waltzed, but boldly marched back into the dated franchise, armed with a morbid, yet brilliant new concept with Wolfenstein: The New Order.

The war is over, the Nazis have won, and the future of humanity is bleak, all in exchange for Aryan supremacy. People are dying left and right under the non-chalant smiles of Nazi officers. Rudely awoken after a fourteen-year hiatus in an insane asylum, it's an understatement to say that William Blazcowicz has returned with all the bang for your buck, and then some. It's a setup that drains the hope of the world from even the optimistically devout. Depending on your gameplay preference, you may be hesitant to drop the $60 without multiplayer, but fret not. Even as a single-player exclusive experience, The New Order shines at its pacing and the satisfaction that bleeds from the gratuitous violence on the screen and cakes onto the player.

I didn't initially anticipate myself using the game's new, excessively versatile dual-wielding system, but in no time, I grew used to how surprisingly satisfying it clicked with my input. It drifts away from extreme realism and has you off of the training wheels and behind two assault rifles within minutes of play. It's like Skyrim, with, well...never mind.

Also new to Wolfenstein is a perk system, which, like its namesake, paves the way for new abilities, or perks" throughout the riveting campaign. While the small touches in combat are welcome
date: stealth leaves a lot to be desired. It's satisfying
recommended: but I believe a lot more can be done with the mechanic
hoursPlayed: especially since every stealth-related perk is a trivial achievement that involves actions you may have performed already

reviewText:
I really didn’t want to like this game. I suppose because I’d played it briefly on the Xbox One and every time I touch a game on the new consoles I’m underwhelmed by the lack of ‘next-gen’ features and graphics. However, Wolfenstien is a very, very good FPS with a solid story, decent GFX and enforces classic FPS style gameplay. It has a neo-noir style that doesn’t plagiarize the likes of BioShock but does give me a sense that I’ve played and seen something similar before. That said, it holds its own as a unique title and stands firmly above the crowd as a respectable game.

I did not like the fact that the main character is as American as a bacon double cheese burger. Forever are the studios plugging American’s ego when it comes to war, battle and history when story boarding these games. I do enjoy the alternative universe that’s been created and it’s even quite believable for the most part, until the all American hero takes a stabbing from a Nazi only to then immediately recover. Aside from those being the main issues I had with the game, it could have done with some more weapons, a more flattering talent tree, which is unfortunately option less and an inventory system would have gone a long way to earning some extra points from me.

I’m glad I waited for this to go on sale. I’m not saying it’s a bad game, but even though I am going to play through it once or maybe twice more, it’s just not worth the full price. Either wait for it to go 50% off on steam or check ♥♥♥ or GMC for a better deal. It’s been out some months now and even brand new I don’t think is deserving of the RRP.
7/10

reviewText:
This is one of the few games that can arguably be said to be worth the $60 asking price.  It's a high price, of course, above the price we PC gamers expect of new games.  However, it must be said that no part of this game is half-♥♥♥♥♥, none of it.  You can see flaws in many great games where they obviously cut corners or ran out of budget, here, everything just works, the shooting, the stealth, the story, the production values, and there is just a feeling of quality that permiates the game.  It feels like a more modern version of HL2, in a way.

Graphics
The graphics of the game are a wonder to behold.  I played this on an EVGA 760 Superclocked, and I noticed zero framerate studdering, no tearing, just smooth as butter.  People look very striking, the skyboxes are amazing, and pretty much all the textures look and feel excellent, adding to the feeling of immersion.

Weapons
All the weapons are pretty great, I won't spoil any of them, but they all feel like they have their useful situations.  They all have real heft and kick to them, and feel suitably powerful.  Weapons upgrades also help to round out the experience.

Gameplay
A welcome surprise is the presence of stealth gameplay in what I thought would be a typical 'shoot mans' game.  Much like in metro last light you can instakill enemies by sneaking up on them.  You also get a silencer for your pistol early on, allowing you to headshot enemies across the map stealthily, which is pretty great.  It feels a little like cheating, but it's still loads of fun to clear an area with only 4 shots and 3 stabbings.

Story/levels
Another element that I thought would be lacking is actually perhaps the game's most striking feature.  Each of the game's levels feel nessisary to the plot, nothing feels like filler, there is never any question as to what you are doing to advance the plot, and all your actions feel impactful and rewarding.  to reiterate, NOTHING FEELS LIKE FILLER!  There is also a lot of optional side content, and for the most part it is very high quality.

Overall, I was extremely satisfied with my purchase of this game.  I would recommend it without question to fans of the shooter genre, especially if it was on deal.

Warnings
There is lewd sexual content in here as well as some rather cringeworthy torture, though it's a lot breifer and more tastefully done than Burial at Sea 2's disgusting torture scene, that's for sure.  Basically keep the kids away from it, this is an adult game for adults, and elder teenagers I suppose.

reviewText:
This is a review based on two playthroughs of the game and is my honest opinion on the game, I personally had a lot of fun with this game, however I feel there's a few things to talk about, so here's my review on Wolfenstein: The New Order.

Gameplay wise
This game is a massive treat, especially with dual weilding all but two of the weapons in the game, being able to unleash hell upon swarms of nazi soldiers as a one man army. Along with having the ability to either play stealthy, tactical or balls to the walls guns blazing inferno. The only downside is that you cannot shoot while sprinting but you're able to shoot while jumping, even though the jumping feels more like you're skipping along the ground. There's also a hint system that could disable or enable if you wish that'll help you out if you get stuck in certain sections including a seperate hint for loot as well for when you get close enough to them. There's also unlockable perks that in all honesty, don't really change the gameplay up.

Graphics wise
For my 3 year old computer, the game looks pretty good on average settings and runs fairly decently except for within a few places, mainly during the first few missions of the game but besides that, the game runs perfectly fine most of the time. In terms of graphics options, majority of the options have been fitted under the same option rather than them being seperate, you are also given the option between fullscreen and window mode and the screen resolution options are filtered to the ones that would best fit your monitor.

Story wise
The story is a pretty accurate on how far the Nazi's would've advanced in technology if they achieved world domination, their sole focus on these kind of things would've meant faster acceleration. However, it kinda goes a little crazy when you get half way through the story. Without spoiling it I can easily say that the ending is pretty bad and totally not what I was expecting either, which is a massive disappointment, there's also next to no replayability to this game besides chosing who dies during the intro chapter which changes one character within the hideout and provides different cutscenes & dialog in relation to this character. Oh and there's no dialog difference between the two characters that you had to pick during the intro chapter either, they say the exact same thing in both play throughs most of the time, with only very few differences between the dialog for me. So besides replaying for dialog and cutscenes and upgrading health and armor along with perk unlocking, there's nothing else worth while to make you revisit the game a third time.

Difficulty wise
Now, there was a leak before the launch of the game that revealed that melee units had extremely poor AI, which is basically true, but you only have to deal with melee units twice within the whole game, both times are prison breaks as well. The only melee unit that was actually fine was the dogs, which of course, just run up to you and attempt to bite you in a QTE.

Besides that, most of the time the AI feels like dumbed down aimbots, that just walk around and shoot at you if they see you, even if its on the otherside of a giant room, losing them however is possible, since they don't know where you are majority of the time if you choose to break line of sight often. However with two boss battles that I encountered, both times fighting giant mecha units, they constantly knew where I was, constantly shot at me even when behind cover and where basically just walking bullet sponges with turrets attachted that would rip you apart if you stayed out in the open. From what I've also noticed, is that the difficulty only changes how much damage you need to deal in order to kill enemies and how much damage they deal to you, which in honesty, doesn't change the difficulty, it just ruins gameplay, slows you down and turns the gameplay into a chore.

There's also special units that you'll encounter throughout the game, ranging from four varients, one that'll call backup if he spots you or he's alerted of your position. Bullet sponges that come with either a rocket launcher, shotgun or machine gun and robots that are also bullet sponges and will rip you to shreds if you get to close, oh and they'll also instant kill you if you attempt a melee kill. You're also unable to kill rocket launchers and shotgunners with melee as well as they just block your attack or their armor is to thick for your knife. Oh and giant attack dogs that'll only be killed by machine guns or explosives.

And as stated before the difficulty only changes the damage you recieve and how much damage the enemies can take, from what I can see the AI behavour between normal and easy isn't different, besides that basic soldiers won't lob nades at you constantly if you hide behind cover. But they'll still act like walking aimbots.

Level design wise
Most of the time you're always heading down a set path, in some sections you are granted a little more freedom when approaching areas that involve you plowing down tons of enemies or if you're in some rooms that happen to be crawling with nazi soldiers. As for detail, the game is enriched with it, every environment is unique and different to each other and really capatures the atmosphere.

Conclusion
Gameplay is pretty fun, being capable of totally destroying nazies to shreds with any weapon(s) that you obtain and being able to play differently in each section if you wish.

Graphics is pretty good, looks pretty decent on my computer and runs just fine at most times.

Story is ok, but it kinda becomes a massive disappointment with its ending and there isn't much a difference between the sacrifice choice during the intro chapter.

Difficulty is not challenging, becomes repetitive and turns the game into a chore due to the massive excess of bullet sponged enemies that can instant snap to you along with bosses that know where you are, constantly, non-stop.

Level design is really appealing, each environment is different, doesn't feel repetitive, as for the flow of movement most of the time it feels linear, you're constantly moving in one direction and most alternate paths loop.

Overall
This game is great if you just want to have fun while killing Nazi's.
This game will run decently on most computers that are around 3 years old now, older than that however you might encounter some difficulties running this game.
This game is ok when it comes to its story, but as said, the ending is a disappointment.
This game will not challenge you, as the difficulty only changes the damage and some minor AI behaviors like nade lobbing and being able to see you through walls.
This game is extremely appealing to the eyes with each environment enriched with detail, so much to look at, so much to read and listen to, it's like candy.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein - the New Order gives you an idea how the world could be liked if the Nazi's has won.
I have played this game for several hours, it has a lot of dialogue, the sound is very good (sometimes even a bit creepy).

The storyline is very good.

I did NOT expected the game would work on my desktop (AMD Phenom 9550 Quadcore with an Nividia GeForce 560 GTX, 4 gig RAM, win7 64-bit), but it is working very good. Graphics are very good.

I have not played the first Wolfenstein (not intend to do aswell), but in my opinion it is not even necessary to play chapters before this 1.

It can be a hard game, so for people like me (i am NOT good with these kind of games), make sure you do not set the difficulty on hard (but the game is much, MUCH better if you play it on the hardest difficulty!)

If you like a good shooter, with a good story and some great graphics, this is the game you need to play.

reviewText:
Hype can do wonderful things to a game that has yet to be released.
The fact that I didn't expect anything  out of Wolfenstein: The New Order made me walk away satisfied after my first playthrough!
The new devs MachineGames,comprising mainly of Key members from Starbreeze Studios who carved their niche in shooters like
Riddick and The Darkness for their effective Characerisation and non-linear gameplay.
That,to some extent,does show in the latest Bethesda outing. This is EVERYTHING that Duke Nukem Forever should have been.
And despite lacking any online features,The New Order does deliver a rocksolid singleplayer campaign that is memorable
and probably one of the best Singleplayer shooters in last 5 years.

NOTE:You are going to need a beefy rig to play it on,even High settings!
Also keep in mind that AMD card owners will experience performance issues

PROS:
+Tight and Satisfying Gunplay
+Varied enemy types.
+Old school mechanics! (collecting armor,healthpacks and no weapon carry limit)
+For a game based on Nazi slaying,TNO boasts a good storyline and great characters.
+Great looking visuals.(I've been experiencing a steady 35-40fps on Ultra settings)
+Robust Stealth system.
+Remarkably long for a modern FPS.(12-13 hours)
+Cinematic style of Storytelling!
+Alternate timelines do require second playthrough.So there's a nod to replayability.
+Stays true to its ancestors in lot of ways.
+Art Design and soundtrack is worth mentioning.

CONS:
-PC Optimisation issues.
-The main antagonist is a bit cliched.
-Some scenes you cannot determine whether they are Serious or comical.
-A handful of Mundane levels;Overweighed by the otherwise excellent action-packed levels.(Like searching the sewers for a lost gun.Ugh!)

VERDICT:
MachineGames has nailed it as their first AAA game.
Wolfenstein The New Order is something I can call one of the most brilliant shooters of 2014.
It has everything that one expects from a solid singleplayer experience. I am glad Bethesda took a risk with the zero Online feature,which
is really surprising because games like Return to Castle Wolfenstein and Enemy Territory were popular for their Multiplayer!
All said,the game still missed out a few inches from joining the leagues of Half-life,Bioshock and Metro series.
If you have no qualms shelling out $60 for a Singleplayer-oriented video game,then go ahead.Otherwise wait for the inevitable steam sale.
Either ways,this is a game you should definitely play.

reviewText:
Despite what you might think of this game as the usual shooter, you'd be quite surprised out of what you get when you try out Wolfenstein: New Order.  Besides the graphics looking and breathing huge levels of realism, the game makes a great level of story while along the while staying true to the whole background of what made Wolfenstein such a classic that it is today.

There is some good variety in both where you run and gun to where you should be sneaky and even where your there to just take in the story of everything.  Along with some fun with the variety in your combat methods, you can have some real fun in some badass moments with the arsenal of weapons or even spending the time to explore for secret goodies.

The world feels very real and detailed right down to last Nazi you take down and don't forget about the wonderful joy of the weapon wheel either.  For someone who's never gotten into the universe of Wolfenstein, this made me a huge fan.  As it should you too hopefully.

Later,

reviewText:
Alright so this game was rather unexpected to me. Wolfenstein (Goddammit, I hope I write the name well throughout the whole review) from 2009 didn't sell THAT well and I honestly have no idea about what happened to make Bethesda own the IP rather than Activision. But since Bethesda isn't all about the money (though it has it's greeds and I very much felt that on my own skin...), they are now going a bit more... old-school-y. First: this, now a new DOOM game is coming and sounds promising and I'm already hyping it alot. And we know the Prey 2 project was scrapped and handed over to the bros at Arkane (Devs of DIshonored, Dark Messiah) to make it a true sequel to the cult-classic original from 2006.

Anyways, knowing The New Order would be a return to old-school shooters, excitement grew. But then the E3 Demo was rather poor: they showed the very first level of the game (which is the most linear and cutscene-ish). It was a poor decision that then didn't stop me from paying full retail price for the Special Edition Retail Box (New DOOM Beta, yay! :D). 50€ for this.

It was totally worth it...

Alright so! Lets get on with the graphics: iD Tech 5 Engine - I'm AMD so... was I ♥♥♥♥ed alongside other AMD users?

Nope! Works perfectly on my PC, it's the 2nd game in history (afaik) that uses the iD Tech 5 technology by Carmack and thus: yes, the infamous Mega-Texture system. Sounds scary, doesn't it? Basically a regular texture game (every other game except iD Tech 5 games (I think all) have everything textured by it's own: a box has its own texture quality, the tree has its own texture-work, characters, guns, fooliage, etc. etc. Everything has its own texture-work. Mega Textures aren't like that: with this system, the whole world around you is made of 1 single texture-work. 1 texture for the environments, boxes, gun-models, characters, fooliage, etc. etc. As you can see, it's a huge texture (thus the name) so one thing you can predict quite easily if you think a bit: Lengthy texture loading! Yes! This will result in texture pop-in, especially worse in the PC version of these games, I will then talk about pop-in in The New Order).
It actually shouldn't worry you. Mega-Textures allow the game to look good or very good and also allows players with weaker PC's to run the game well! RAGE was the previous iD Tech 5 game and it was terrible on AMD, I can claim it myself, the pop-in was ridiculous!
Nevertheless, pop-in is pretty much non-existant in Wolfenstein: The New Order (hell! I've been playing Duke Nukem Forever recently again, and the pop-in is worse there!) which is great and unexpected tbh. The game runs really well and looks weird.

Weird because 80% of the game looks good, some parts even excellent. But then others... oh man! Looks 2002...
No, I'm serious! I remember a vent whose walls and it's screws were all like paper drawings, no 3D modelling for the screws or the metal bendings. Just looks kinda ugly.

Despite that, overall graphics are pretty good, not great, the game is quite colourful compared to other shooters, which is nice.
Many people still think how the game is this big. I would bet on the Mega-Textures being the reason, but I'm only assuming. RAGE was the previous Mega-Textured game and it was also really big (Complete Edition is ~24 Gb). Wolfenstein is (don't fall from your chair, please) ~45 Gb. This game is quite heavy on cutscenes so, that should increase the HDD Space count by a lot (games like Alan Wake are like 10 Gb, 6 or 8 Gb of those if I recall correctly were custcene videos!).
It will be a pain to download Mega-textured games, but there you go... it's worth it so... enjoy 5 hours of DL time.

Audio is good... for the most part. Guns sound fantastic, voice acting is probably the best this year. However, sound consistency is weak at best. During gameplay, Blazkowicz (the protagonist) will sometimes speak in a super low whisper, which is hard to listen to at times when the rest of the game sounds great and at a normal volume (gun-fire, nazi screams, cuscene voicing, etc.), thank God for subtitles!

The story, this is the most story focused Wolfenstein game. And it's a very good one at that. I love Alternate History (What If type of stories based on real stuff) and this is probably the best Alt. Hist. Storyline ever.
Nazis are winning the war,  Blazkowicz and other allies organize an attack to a castle (General Deathshead's Lair) to kill the General who is responsible for the huge Nazi upgrade and technology boost. The assault goes south, the Nazi's win and that's all I'm explaining...
A very good layer of characterization is made to Blazkowicz, making him likeable and interesting. During Hub missions we can talk to many resistance members and also characterization is well done there. There's a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥ing and screaming and raging. But that isn't annoying the player. It's just arguments and frustrations of rational people living in a sadly, irrational environment full of hostility.
The ending is very well done, and while some hate it, I found it to be pretty much perfect (and I will not explain why, to avoid spoilers, any curious people just chat with me).
The story behind this game is stronger than 90% of movies and videogames and that's a job well done, Machine Games!

There's no MP. Good, 100% focus on the story and the campaign, which is just excellent! I wish more devs were like this! ♥♥♥♥ing sick of co-op ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on my games. Everything now has to be online, ugh! Disgusting. Co-Op is dead to me. it's never well done and always tacked on. Good online is CoD and Battlefield. Good Co-Op is Killing Floor and Left 4 Dead. The rest is tacked on ♥♥♥♥ (yeah, you too Borderlands!).

Commendable to make an SP only game and have the balls to do it in a AAA title.

Moving on to the gameplay: superb. Guns feel great, the game doesn't take itself too serious (you can eat dog-food to replenish health, you can use car doors and piece of broken robots to replenish your armor).
It's just great! In what game can you dual wield Sniper Rifles and go berserk?! What game has a sniper rifle with a secondary fire mode that is an ironsight mode that fires a laser beam! And guess what? You can dual wield that too!
You can dual wield knives because Hey

reviewText:
I have just completed my first playthrough of the game. I saved the one on the right, you'll get what that means when you get to that part, as it's a pretty big spoiler and major turning point. The good news is it's in the beginning part of the game.

This game. Oh my God, this game. I have never felt so engaged, so emotionally invested.

This game puts you in the deep and dirty. It held no punches, it did not deviate. It gave you the worst ideals of the Nazi regime, the grimiest experiments and most morally-devoid acts, amplified them and spread them about a world to explore. It hits hard. There were times where I felt enraged by the actions of the Nazi soldiers before me, and I wanted nothing but to stick a knife in their neck. At the same time however, each soldier that has dialogue was packed with character. You could see how they were still human, how they momentarily hesitated in their actions or mistakes, but the deep Nazi connections blanketed all that and they continued with their action. There were also Soldiers who were as merciless as their commanders, and killed indiscriminantly.

This was an experience like no other. The writing is perfect, the graphics are appealing, the music great, and the story is phenominal. The gunplay and the shooting felt amazing. Some parts it felt a little wonky, but you get used to it.

I am very much biased towards this game, but that's mostly because the ending had me in tears. I can't play this for less than four or so hours a playthrough. I highly recommend it, get it when you can.

In short: Amazing game. 10/10. Emotions for a soldier who could not show emotions. I will play this over and over.

<3

reviewText:
The New Order is paradoxically a Wolfenstein only in name. Okay, the protagonist is the right one, we have to deal with a world dominated by the Nazis and the gameplay is heavily biased toward the shootings with a frenetic pace. But there is little of the horror of that dark and charm, almost trash, we learned about the first masterpiece of id Software and its sequel / remake, often forgettable, that have occurred over the years. And this is good because in the end the work of MachineGames still managed to carve out its own personality and above all to be enjoyable and fun from the first minute in which you take the pad (or mouse) in hand. Not a masterpiece and does not leave a mark in the Olympus of video games but I guarantee that this Wolfenstein: The New Order is left to play which is a pleasure.

PRO
-Immediate, frantic and addictive in each shooting
-The talent system works and provides a minimum of customization action
-Very good level design...

AGAINST
-... although from the point of view of art we have not.
-A bit 'of extra variety to the enemies and the weapons would not hurt.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is an FPS pitting the player in an alternate historical reality in which Nazi's won WWII and you must fight them to restore balance, peace and freedom.

Wolfenstein games have changed so much over the years and this particular Wolfenstein game is no exception. The New Order is very different from the Wolfenstein games we've come to know in the past but yet it's sprinkled with some retro surprises to take us back to those times of when the Wolfenstein series first came into existence. Still, there is enough here to seperate The New Order from any of the other Wolfenstein games.

There's something to be said about the quality of the world that Bethesda has put together when they created Wolfenstein: The New Order. I haven't really seen any game or movie put this much attention to detail in an alternative historical reality - if I'm wrong then feel free to let me know in the comments. There's nothing better than riding in a car only to see a robotic dog being walked by an off duty Nazi officer as you pass by. Small details like this show you how much the developers care about their craft.

Weapons are a huge deal in Wofenstein: The New Order, they feel more than rewarding when you see how your enemies' bodies and the semi-destructable environments react to the power of your guns' bullets. That said, the semi-destructable environments also really add a new sense of strategy and paranoia when you realize that walls, doors and whatever you hide behind might possibly be blown away at any time - depending on the power of your enemy's weapons.

Pros Hollywood worthy single-player campaign storyline
Atmospheric and dark
Fast paced action that never gets dull
Secrets, secrets and more secrets!
Full Controller Support
Top-Notch enemy character designs
Cons  V-Sync issues
idTech5 Engine doesn't give players the best graphics
Final Thoughts:
This game takes everything we've come to know FPS games like Call Of Duty and dumps that all too familiar formula on it's head by featuring a lengthy single-player campaign which even includes some story-impacting choices for you to make and in-depth character design. Bethesda put alot of love into creating one of the most atmospheric FPS games to date.

Rating (9 out of 10)

This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

reviewText:
I've been a long time Wolfenstein fan. I played Wolfenstein 3D for the first time when I was younger, and it was on one of those ridiculous shareware demo discs alongside the beloved Doom! Ever since, I've kept a close eye on the franchise and enjoyed every iteration, including the recent 2009 game that has sadly vanished without a trace for potential buyers. However, this new entry makes up for that with flying colors!

Wolfenstein: The New Order is, without a doubt, one of the most fun shooters of all time and possibly one of the best shooters ever made. Love, passion, and polish have been put into this game, and I have a lot to talk about. But let me try to make this as brief as possible, so you can get the best review possible!

The gameplay, which is exceptionally fun, allows for a great deal of freedom. Stealth, tactics, or assault. Gameplay can flow between any of these three at any moment. Although the level designs consist of corridors or big open atriums, they still allow for a lot of freedom in how you want to approach a situation. Within these levels, you can find any number of hidden goodies to find, such as collectible gold or special codes that unlock additional game modes. You also will find plenty of useful items hidden in fun locations. Although there is some level of linearity, the game still has alternate paths you can take, even if not all the time.

As you gun down waves of Nazis using some of the best gunplay I've ever heard or witnessed, the gun toting hero will unlock perks" which provide passive bonuses in 4 perk trees. Although it isn't as robust or plentiful as
