reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order
This is a shooter masterpiece continuing and maybe enhancing already great reputation of Wolfenstein series among first person shooters.

The review is divided into few parts looking at the main aspects of the game.

+ FPS Mayhem
The shooting system done perfectly. Loads of guns, loads of ammo and all to kill hundreds and hundreds of Nazis. You are one man army able to put down whole war machine alone. At least almost alone. Every weapon you can dual wield to make even greater damage to the enemy. I also like the possibilities of some weapons, for example using buckshots or shrapnel shots with the shotgun etc. I won't go much into the details, you should see this for yourself. You can also beat the whole variety of enemies from nazi dogs to panzerhunds.
There is nothing I would criticize in this aspect of the game.

+ Perks and Collectibles
The perks give you a challenge during the gameplay. If you want to achieve them all, you will try every possible playstyle there is, and try all of the weapons. Afterwards you will be rewarded with major or minor improvements to your abilities. The collectibles offer you something to hunt and the reason why to look in every corner of the map. In The New Order collectibles are not so easy to find, but if you find them all, you can experience how it feels satisfying to beat the game on 100 %.

+ Graphics
Except that the game is full of grey buildings, roads etc. where you won't admire neither scenery nor design, graphics as a whole is amazing and effects of the moments like when you cut a throat of a nazi commander are incredibly perfect.

Ø Sneaking
If you are tired of Rambo style going through the game you can sneak and take Nazis one by one with knife takedowns, throwing knives or using silencer on your pistol. Don't get me wrong, it's fun, but being able to kill armored soldier by hitting him in the leg with a thrown knife is at least a little strange. Another thing is that nazi fellows many times completely ignore their fallen brethren, step over them and continue their patrol like nothing has happened. Still it's the part of the game I enjoyed the most, reminded me of the predator mode in Arkham series.

- Story and Directness
And finally the story. The idea is great. It's the 1960, twisted history, reality where Nazis had won WW2 by having noticeable technological lead far ahead from the rest of the world. What could go wrong here? Only that the story is really awfully disapponting, simple and very predictable. Captain William B.J." Blazkowicz

reviewText:
Because everyone loves B.J.'s... I mean B.J Blazkowicz.

Wolfenstein the New Order is the reboot of the long standing franchise as envisioned by Machine Games. Wolfenstein is credited as being the first ever stealth game with Castle Wolfenstein from 1981, and it's sequel, Beyond Castle Wolfenstein from 1984. The most famous game, and the one veteran FPS players remember the most is Wolfenstein 3D by ID Software, a title that was a revolution at the time, and ID's first venture into the FPS world, even before the almighty Doom. Wolfenstein was a pioneer in 3D gaming for PC's back in the day, and The New Order respects it's heritage by taking the franchise to a whole new direction.

This is the first Wolfenstein game that has a story, a well thought, engaging, thought provoking story. The plot allows for character development, and this is the first FPS that actually made me care about what happens not only to the protagonist B.J, but also with everyone he interacts with in the fight to cripple the Nazi oppression, and B.J's main antagonist, General Deathshead.

The story takes place in an alternate timeline where the nazis have won World War II. It starts in 1946, but the majority of the game takes place in 1960, 14 years after B.J goes through a traumatic experience.  This is all that I am going to say when it comes to the game's story, because it truly deserves to be experienced spoiler free.

Wolfenstein is a tribute to the FPS's of the 90's, but mixed up with some modern mechanics. The end result is very satisfying,  and feels both modern and retro, and in my opinion the way Machine Games pulled it off, deserves praise all on it's own.

Gameplay is over the top, violent and incredibly fun. You can dual wield every single weapon in the game, knifes, shotguns, machine guns and even sniper rifles. Yes, you read that right, you can dual wield sniper rifles. I can't think of any other game that allows that. The shooting mechanics are easy to master, and the over the top violence suits the game theme well. This is a Mature rated game for a reason, there is an abundance of blood, guts and nazi brains.

The game mixes traditional shooting with stealth, rewarding both styles equally. It is up to you how you want to play the game, and you will discover that some levels are better done in a particular way. It has a perk system that allows you to unlock more abilities by performing in game actions, and these are separated into 4 different types, Stealth, Tactical, Assault and Demolition. It adds a layer of strategy that is welcome in this style of game, as far as I am concerned.

Wolfenstein The New Order uses the ID Tech5 engine, which is both a good and a bad thing, depending on who you ask. If you have a capable enough PC, you will be blown away by the detail and visual effects, particle system and the textures. This game looks amazing at 1080p with all the details on Ultra. If you have a mid range PC, you may experience texture popup, which breaks the immersion in my opinion, and poor frame rate, so be sure your machine can handle this game before you decide to buy it, it can be very resource intensive.

The music is phenomenal, and gets your adrenaline pumping when the action gets hectic. The stealth takedowns are brutal, and are not for the faint of heart. The campaign is long, and very satisfying. This is triple AAA at it's finest, and a game that deserves every penny, in my personal opinion. It also has 2 different timelines that alter some details of the main campaign, based on a decision B.J has to make early in the game, and even though it can be seen as a gimmick, it adds replayability.

Wolfenstein The New Order is one of the best shooters I have ever played, the story, mechanics, graphics, and sound offer a complete package for both veterans and newcomers. Don't miss out on this title, shooting nazis doesn't get any better than this. Kudos to Machine Games, their vision of Wolfenstein made B.J a force to be reckoned with amongst FPS heroes.

The Good

-Graphics and sound
-Story
-Thought provoking
-Shooting mechanics
-Long and varied campaign
-Dual wielding guns adds an insane amount of fun to the game
-Shoot nazis on the Moon, on a U-Boat, In London, kill mechanical dogs, and a whole army of high tech/retro enemies
-Sex scenes are both ridiculously funny and out of place, and emotionally enganging at the same time

The Bad

-Single player only, Not a problem for me, but worth pointing out

9.5/10

reviewText:
Before playing this, I had read a lot of internet hype saying how amazing this game is and how fun it is. This could not be more true. Wolfenstein: The New Order is one of the best FPS I have played in a long, long time ranking up there with Bioshock Infinite and Singularity.

The game excels in all areas: gameplay, narrative, sound design, graphics, atmosphere, you name it. What immediately struck me while playing was the physicality of the guns. When firing a shotgun at a Nazi's head it feels oh-so satisfying. The guns have weight to them and feel tremendous. The story, however, is far better than I think anyone thought it would be. The alternate history is not just filler for the gameplay as I was fascinated by the alternate take on WWII and the events that unfolded. The cinematics are presented beautifully and the voice work is fantastic.

In short, Wolfenstein: The New Order is a MUST BUY for any and all FPS fans.

reviewText:
Probably my favorite shooter of this year, Wolfenstein The New Order does a great job of combining old school and new school mechanics of shooters into an awesome FPS game.

The thing which surprised me the most is the story, it's really well written with many intreasting and memorable characters, honestly i think the reason I'd recommend this game is primarly due to the story.
It's one of the rare games where i actully enjoyed reading logs,newspaper articals or diary entries because i was intreasted to see how different this world is since the Nazis won the war.

The shooting mechanics are solid and filling Nazi bodies with bullets never gets old during the 8 to 10 hour single player campaign, which is well worth re-playing a second time since an early decision at the start changes a fair amount of the dialog in the game and even cutscenes.
The game even offers you a sneaking mechanic, alot of (but not all) parts you can sneak thru by stabing nazis silently or killing them with a silenced pistol but it's never required, it's an optional playstile. Personally i would switch all the time, some parts I'd sneak around and try to find hidden areas that will help me get by unnoticed but other times i just wanna let go and kill every Nazi scumbag with my trusty shotgun.
The health system is very old school, you have 100HP, you can overheal yourself above the maximum HP for a short time and you pick up armor around the map to take less damage however there is a lil bit of HP regeneration but not much, you will always regenerate about 10 to 20HP, so if you drop to let's say to 5HP after a fight it will slowly go up to 20 so you at least can take a bullet or two if you bump into someone and have not managed to find a health pack, i think it's a very nice combo of old and new.

It's well worth the money during an okay sale, imo it's worth picking up even for 25 or 30 Euros but full price (50 Euros) is imo a bit to much for an 8 hour (or so) Single Player campaign, yes it's worth replaying a second time but still theres other games which would offer more hours of entertainment for less money or the same amount.

So yeah, pick it up even during a small discount sale , it's totally worth it.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a great addition to the Wolfenstein series. After a long sprint of mediocre games, Wolfenstein triumphantly returns with an excellent story-driven arcade FPS. It tends to feel a lot like playing a Bioshock game, which isn't a bad thing. With its' divergent storyline, Wolfenstein has managed to capture my attention. Fans of would-be history games will love this.

Story
It is the 1960s and the Nazis have controlled the world for quite some time now. B.J. Blazkowicz, the protagonist of the series, awakes after a head injury to find that the United States no longer exists and is determined to find a resistance. Once he does, the Resistance, led by a charasmatic woman named Caroline Becker, embarks on a quest to take down the Nazi empire from the inside.

Pros:
- An incredible storyline set in a 1960s Nazi ruled world.
- Aestheticaly pleasing :]
- Mixed loud and stealth play
- Great divergent-style weapons; Weapons that could have been.
- Great mix of enemy personel.

Cons:
- A break from the traditonal Wolfenstein games (Which isn't such a bad thing)
- Protagonist's voice acting can be a bit annoying (constantly whipsering soliloquies in a Christian Bale Batman way)

Verdict?
7.5/10 - Wolfenstein: The New Order is a very fun game. When it comes down to the wire though, it is still simply another arcade FPS along the lines of Bioshock, Serious Sams, etc. The saving grace of this game is the great story. The action is also quite fun. The weaponary you will use in The New Order are divergent designs of real weaponry from the WW2 period. Overall, I enjoy playing this game and the replay value is on the higher side of the scale. If you love killing Nazis, WWII history, or even just Wolfenstein in general, I recommend!

reviewText:
Pros:
Varied locales. It'll take you to some unexpected places.
Strong narrative. I don't understand how they pulled this off; they took the most campy and tacky concept there was (Science-fiction nazis rules the world! Woo!) and took it really seriously and it paid off. I felt satisfied by the story.
Solid shooting. It's nothing new or too spectacular but the shooting works and it does it's job just fine. There is some elements of optional stealth which I enjoyed.
The worldbuilding is very strong. There are journals, news clippings and even pop songs to flesh out the universe nicely.
While the pace wasn't perfect I do feel that the campaign was long enough with dragging on too much.Neutral:
The game is very linear.
The graphics looks okay. With the exception of some textures the game looks fine.
The enemy AI is very stupid when it comes to stealth, almost offensively so. You can shoot a guy in the head in front of his ally and he won't react at all. They won't react to bodies, etc. I put this as a neutral thing because it makes stealth a bit easier if you want to play stealthly but aren't too good at it. If you were expecting stealth mechanics and AI like Thief you can put this as a negative.
The boss encounters were okay. Nothing too interesting but not awful either. They work, but are not very memorable.
There are collectibles in the game but they aren't too exciting, but if you like exploring and collecting you may enjoy it.Cons:
Lack of guns. The guns that are here have alternate fire modes, but at the end of the game I was tired of using the same old ones all the time. Some guns also lack a sense of punch" - the shotguns felt very weak to me

reviewText:
I wasn't expecting much when I picked this up, but I was pleasantly surprised by what I received: A game with an equal balance between old and new school FPS action, a great story that kept me interested throughout, and smooth performance without any hitches or hiccups.

The gunplay in this game is superb, with a variety of different guns to choose from as well as secondary fire modes,  which can be unlocked, that alter the way some of the guns fire by such a degree, that they are practically a brand new gun. The game can be played somewhat stealthy with there being some back rooms and places where you can sneak up on badguys,  a silenced pistol and throwing kinves - but you'll be most happy dual-wielding assault rifles or shotguns and blasting your way through rooms like an action hero.

I played on uber difficulty, so there were some rooms that I had to repeat once in a while because the baddies become pretty heavily armoured toward the last third of the game, but I was never stuck long enough to get frustrated. If I had to knock the game for anything, it would be the checkpoint saves (though I never had to replay too much action upon death).

The story unfolds both in cutscenes and by reading newspaper clippings and talking to characters at the base (between story sections). These parts can be slow, but they break up the action so you're not constantly fatigued.

Honestly, this has to be one of my favourite shooters to date, and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes singleplayer action games. Don't let the fact it's a remake fool you, it's well done and a good tribute to past games that shared the Wolfenstein name.

reviewText:
A brutal, often gory but satisfying FPS. The setting of this game is awesome. You're B.J. Blazkowicz, running through all kinds of environments in an alternate 1960s, killing Nazi's the second you see them. The difficulty and gameplay of the game is pretty balanced. The dual-wielding gun mechanic actually works pretty well, for example, launching grenades with one gun and shooting with the other. You can even shoot with two sniper rifles simultaneously if you want. Melee attacks work fluently and effective. There's no real cover system; this is picking up huge guns armor and bullets, storming through the level whilst blowing up huge Nazi robots and metal robot dogs.

The visuals look really well, everything is very detailed and you have your typical corridor FPS level designs. The surroundings are so highly detailed and well-made so that it's worth exploring, which can even result in finding some collectables for those interested. The guns look awesome, the flashy effects look great, and the sound effects and voices are top-notch. The characters are interesting and B.J. Blazkowicz narrating certain things was a welcome thing, too. Without spoiling too much, there are two different 'storylines' which add a bit of replayability to the game.

While Wolfenstein: The New Order didn't really come up with anything 'new', except for maybe the ability to dual-wield guns this way (which I've never experienced before personally), it did breathe new life into the Wolfenstein franchise. Unfortunately it still is a pretty generic sci-fi shooter and the story may be kind of forgettable, but Machine Games did a very good job on creating a very unique, good looking and well playing game. The story keeps you entertained and hooked throughout the whole game and there's never a dull moment. I can safely say that this is one of the best storyline-driven FPS-games of all time.

This game has a genuinely good single-player campaign, with a story that's action packed and brutal. The gameplay is very balanced and smooth. Everything looks gorgeous and detailed, supported by a tensing soundtrack and story. One of the best FPS-games from this era, highly recommended.

reviewText:
I see dead Nazis. Everywhere. You shoot them with pistol, assault rifle, shotgun, sniper rifle as well as their future version. You can dual wield too!

The game is a nice mix of oldschool gameplay and modern approach to shooters (pretty unique health system). It offers two timelines (it depends on choice early in the game) - there isn't a big difference between two, but sometimes levels play a bit different. Dialogues slightly change, but the story is the same. Voice acting is excellent and the main hero (voiced by Brian Bloom - Kane in Kane and Lynch games and Jackie in Darkness II) is a perfect match. Other characters are doing very well at least. Story is good, not outstanding but solid. Maps are long, but since it is a linear shooter it doesn't hurt. They allow freedom to a degree. What surprised me - this game has a simple but very satysfying stealth system. Stealthing was very enjoyable and I devoted a full playthrough to it.

Guns are great. They sound absolutely massive (assault rifles in particular). Their models and animations are excellent. Enemy variety isn't big, but every character is detailed and has great animations. They sound very well too.

Collectibles - YES! It wouldn't be a proper Wolf game without those. They are nicely hidden and there is sort of meta game related to them and Nazi Commanders. You have to find out yourself, but this is a really nice idea and I loved it.

Graphics - great. Graphical style - outstanding and certain vistas are stunning - not that they are beautiful, but impressive. Music is great - a mix of metal and industrial - excellent match to atmosphere. Performance is good.

PC version has FOV slider as well as toggle option for crouching, running and iron sights. Everything else that should be in PC game is present. Very good port.

By now you should have an impression that new Wolf is a good game. It isn't. It's excellent in every department. If you like eliminating Nazis then it's a game for you. A worthy RTCW and Wolfenstein (from 2009) successor. Dual wield and wipe them out for good.

reviewText:
Just Simply Beautiful!

Wolfenstein: The New Order is set in a Nazi controlled world, where the Nazis won World War 2 and now have power over the world. The campaign tells a fantastic story, one of the best I have ever played, where you feel as if you get to know the characters in a mutual way. The gripping story is fantastic with many different items to collect and is all good, but once you have finished the campaign, that's it you have finished. There is nothing else to do when you complete the campaign and is most certainly not worth £34.99 (approx $59.99) due to there being nothing else to do once the campaign is complete.

In some missions, the game gives you the choice of either going in guns blazing or playing stealthily which both have their pros and cons depending on how you want to do it. This gives the player some freedom and I personally find this very good as you choose how you want to play the game. The gunplay is also responsive and fluid but I found that the gun models were a bit big and took up most of the space on the screen, but I wouldn't let this put you off.

I was running this game with these specs:

AMD FX-4300 @ 3.8GHz
8GB RAM
AMD R7 250 DDR3 2GB OC

The frame rate was relatively stable with only some lag on huge explosions, but the frame rate is stable 99% of the time. However, whilst I was playing the game in some missions I found that it took a little while to render some textures when I moved the camera and this was frequent throughout the game and bugged the hell out of me!

In conclusion, I think that anyone who loves fighting Nazis and who loves First Person Shooters with a gripping and compelling storyline will adore Wolfenstein: The New Order. I think that Wolfenstein: The New Order deserves an 8/10 as the storyline is one of the best that I have played, however once the campaign is complete, you won't touch this game for a long time. However, I would wait until the next Steam sale as this game is definately not worth £34.99 ($59.99) for the short hours of gameplay that it has.
voteText: 18 of 23 people (78%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Wolfenstein The New Order is one of the better first person shooters of the past (half) year. It has a nice science fiction story about what would've happened if Germany won WWII after all. It starts off semi realistic but the action and settings become more over the top halfway through the story. The shooting aspect feels very solid and dual wielding guns is a nice touch, even if it isn't all that accurate and becomes less helpful later on in the game when tougher and more enemies appear.

The stealth aspect was, for me personally, the best part of the game. Enemies are sometimes stupid and they won't even spot you when you're practically hugging them and other times they see you when they're not even supposed to but knifing enemies (and especially throwing knives) just feels awesome and satisfying. I was actually disappointed every time I was (incorrectly) spotted.
Levels are also less linear than the previous Wolfenstein games so you can sometimes take a different road. These seperate roads aren't long but they give a nice illusion of freedom. An illusion the Wolfenstein games absolutely need to keep it more fun.

The perk system is also a nice addition and a bit different than what you're used to. Perks can be unlocked only in a certain order and it's entirely up to you what you want to do first. Do you want to unlock the stealth perks first, or the more explosive perks ? It gives you freedom in how you want to play the game, which is refreshing. Even if the backbone of this system is still the same as in any other game using perks.

The voice acting is excellent, and the soundtrack kicks in nicely when a shootout is about to begin. Nothing to complain about here. The graphics on the other hand don't feel very next(/current)-gen, but are still good (especially the characters), and texture streaming is still a problem with this engine and this impacts the overall experience. Performance in general seems to be terrible, even with the most high-end systems. But you can still get it to run at a solid 60FPS with a little tweaking here and there.

Wolfenstein The New Order took me 10 hours to complete, which is pretty long for a shooter these days. And if you read the entire review you don't have to ask me why I would recommend this game to anyone. It has my seal of approval. *Stamp*

[Rating: 86/100]

reviewText:
TLDR VERDICTWolfenstein: The New Order is a pleasantly surprising mix of well designed, amazingly fun FPS mechanics with complexly written, emotionally invested storytelling. Don't judge this book by its cover as what appears to be another Nazi slaying shooter is in fact one of the most memorable and powerful gaming experiences I've ever had. This is definitely worth a look on sale, even if you're not ordinarily a shooter guy/gal.

FULL REVIEW BELOW
While I was gone
date: they set the world on fire. It wasn't a war anymore; it was a remaking. Some losses are inevitable. Some... unthinkable. Now they've built a new world. Armies of steel and thunder. They're rewriting history. But they forgot about me." - William BJ Blazkowicz\n\nFollowing a near-fatal head wound during a crucial mission that would determine the outcome of World War II
recommended: Captain William BJ Blazkowicz has been in a comatose state for 14 years. He wakes up. The year is 1960. The war is over. The Nazis won. The New Order rules all over the world.\n\nThis review is written from the perspective of a fan of action shooters and story driven games

column33: armor and ammo pickups laying around.\n\nSTORY AND NARRATIVEFor someone going in expecting a mindless Nazi slaying simulator I was supremely surprised by this games narrative. The story is excellent and the voice acting performances are top notch. All the characters are very well fleshed out and varied and it all feels very original and unique compared to other shooters out there today. It's a new twist on the classic World War II shooter. I went into this game having never played a Wolfenstein title before and I came away incredibly impressed. There are some really harrowing and tense moments in this game that made heart sink into my stomach or try to beat out of my chest. Even the villains are given more background beyond the fact that they are Nazis and that's why we should hate them. The soundtrack is great and always fits whatever happens to be going on perfectly whether it's pumping me up or freaking me out. There are even two branching storylines that make a few changes to the game both story and gameplay wise if you’re after some replay value. There are however a few moments in the game that are bit confusing in the sense of the tone and emotion the writers are going for in certain contexts

reviewText:
The New Order is a game attempting to walk in various directions at once. It's also a title attempting to maintain old conventions of particular shooters whilst adopting modern expectations of what constitutes an FPS experience.

On the one hand, you can dual-wield shotguns and speed-run a level. On the other, you can forego the craziness and take a safer, more cerebral approach to the killings, with single fire options available on your automatic rifles and the option to lean in and out of cover. Then there's the ability to stealth your way through the entire level, with suppressed handguns and silent take-downs with knives.

You can generally play to whichever of the three conventions you wish to adhere to, but the first is somewhat of an illusion. This is one of my few critiques on the game: The New Order gives you the option to Serious Sam your way through a level, but it feels rather tacked on and counter-intuitive when you can steadily die if you decide to run through the whole ordeal. Sure, you can Rambo your way through a level, but in-between spurts of action you'll need to take cover and let the health-regen kick in. You'll also need a substantial amount of armor gathered to be able to take enough damage to do any sort of dent in the enemies defenses while you're running all over the map. Armor that needs to be collected by foregoing the action, which, from a design perspective, ensures that the player is at least encouraged to try a stealithier approach and play the game in more than one way. Not that this encouragement is necessary as the game has plenty of sections that require you to stealth your way through a map, due to the absence of weapons other than knives.The game is ultimately meant to be a light cover based shooter with stealth elements, consider the 'Rambo' option more as an option that comes with conditions.

That critique aside, there's not much more to pick at. The stealth and gunning elements work well in-tandem, and the maps are created in such a way to allow either option to be viable. I wish the stealth portion had a few more mechanics at play, since Metal Gear proves you can have robust stealth elements whilst maintaining FPS elements without sacrificing from either. Otherwise, there's nothing to really exalt in this department; the maps allow tackling tasks in a few different ways and allow for diverging paths but there's nothing extraordinary to report. This isn't a critique, it's a standard all games should strive towards, which is competency and congruety.

The New Order is a competent shooter that entertains throughout its duration, but there's nothing particularly eye-catching or ground-breaking here. But there doesn't need to be to justify a purchase, whilst nothing is eye-catching its akin to a summer movie that's still worth the price of admission for entertainment's sake alone, which this title fulfills in spades.

reviewText:
THIS is what a first person shooter should be to me.

Wolfenstein: The New Order put Wolfenstein on the map again, with outstanding gameplay, great level design, amazing characters and an overall great experience.

When I embarked on my Nazi-Killing quest, I was having fun right off the bat, the weapons feel great and as I played I unlocked perks for my preffered playstyle, it was a lot fo fun to try and unlock them all, there were also a lot of collectibles to be found, some even unlock special game modes.
But as I played on, I was pleasantly surprised by the great deal of story and depth this game has, I was expecting a FPS in the area of Serious Sam and Doom, but what I got was a fun FPS that not only provided me with 30 hours of entertainment, but also with a story that sticks and characters I actually cared about, and most surprisingly I shed a tear in the end

As strange as it may sound, I feel like this is a more mature shooter, not because it has sex scenes or violence, but because it presents you things like genocide, loss, racism, opression and hate.
These things are not shoved in your face, but it's what drives your small group of resistance, for example; you overhear a conversation bewteen a woman and a nazi officer, the woman wishes to file a report of abnormal behavior about her neighbour's son because she saw him trying on his mother's lipstick.

It's not all super serious-business ofcourse, as Wolfenstein sometimes embraces the ridiculous, like dual-weilding Sniper/Laser rifles, drowning nazis in toilets.
After an hour or so, the only thing I was still sceptical about was the level variety, but it turned out this is something the game does really well too, you travel all over the world even off-world, to the moon, each level feels unique and memorable.

If you enjoy a good shooter that doesn't hold your hand and has a great deal of fun with some depth to it, Wolfenstein: The New Order is just what you're looking for, I know I certainly was.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a reboot/fps game developed by MachineGames, based in Sweeden. It's interesting to see this franchise being brought to life by a studio that had no active games developed. And wow, what a game this turned out to be. These guys really showed love for the source material, don't get me wrong, it's not a perfect game but damn does it come close to one. The sheer amount of carnage on display, the gunplay, the health bar system, these guys blended modern FPS tropes with old-school run and gun mechanics so well, it's almost seemless. It's good. Really, really good. Well, Wolfensten TNO starts out fairly lame, with a turret section and we're being introduced to BJ once again and his co-pilot. It's a WW2 alternate mission, which sets the tone of the game fairly on. BJ talks in a Batman-esque voice, narrating stuff the entire game, but it's fairly well writen and voice acted so it's ok. After this we wake up after 10+ years in Poland, in an insane asylum. After BJ gets ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off he even gets out of his catatonic state and starts tearing nazi's a new one. It's fairly stupid at times (the story) but they really do try hard to evoke empathy and legitimate emotions from the player, but at times this fails because it's simply too over the top for my taste. Like the story doesn't quite fit the overall game (Looking at you GTA 4). But anyway, it's not bad or anything, given the fact the BJ was well known only for,well, killing nazis. It's decent enough to drive the plot and it's setpieces forward. The supporting cast is also excelently voice acted and everyone seems to be farily well written. The anthagonists in this game are superbly done. You need to view only one or two cutscenes to drive you mad and fill you up with the thirst of revenge. The game manages to make nazis even more hateable. But anyway, I could talk more in depth about the game, but the less said about this game the better, trust me
So let's break things down into two categories: Good and bad.
The good:Superb gunplay, old school run and gun mechanics blended perfectly with modern shooting
Linear level design but with plenty of exploration, side paths and such, good enough
The graphics are really good for an iD tech engine, we know how Rage turned out on this
Awesome enemy/backdrop designs, most of the time the architecture of it all steals the show
Dual wielding any guns (Assault rifles, shotguns etc)
Overcharge system for full on carnage and a well designed stealth system, play the game your way
Polished single player experience, 10-12 hours on a first playthrough with a 2nd one ensured by a binary choice early on
Excelent voice acting, character development and decent storyThe bad:No multiplayer
Some texture pop-in may ♥♥♥♥ some people off
Stealth could use some fine tuning (knives are fairly underpowered compared to the silenced pistol)
Some plot stuff is a bit too over the top(Personal taste)
The whole Nazis rule the world concept isn't fully explored, lost potentional in some areas (Altough they did do the concentration camp part really well)This is my personal 2014 GOTY and it deserves it. 9/10 for this game, I recommend playing it on Uber since the game is fairly ballanced with the exception of a few ares where shotgun heavy dudes will gun you down easily and some cheap deaths will ensue.
P.S: you fight nazis in space, underwater, in concentration camps, in a mental asylum. Variety is strong with this one!

Definitely do reccomend.

reviewText:
The short: Semi-old-school style shooter with modern graphics and a surprisingly decent story that edges the border between serious and hilarious, but was more fun to watch and think about than actually playing.

The longer: I call it semi-old-school shooter because although there are many old-school elements in there, such as very accurate hip-fire and overcharging health encouraging run-n-gun style, there are few enemies and other design decisions that keep it from being a run-n-gun style.  It's playable, but was a tad more frustrating than enjoyable.

The story made good attempts at characterization within a grim yet laughable plot, making just enough coherence to be passable.  Nothing extraordinary, but felt a lot like a typical blockbuster movie with a silly plot but tried to have a serious overtone.  Enjoyable to watch but forgetful within a week.

Recommendation: If you enjoy hollywood-style macho-man movies and FPS shooters, I would suggest getting this game on discount and spend a weekend on it.

reviewText:
I really didn't expect much beyond a generic shooter with this.

I'm pleased to have been entirely wrong. This game harkens back to 'old school' shooters in it's approach of loads of guns, loads of health/armour and loads of stuff to shoot. It couples that however with oodles of character, an enjoyable scattering of lore and some impressive over all design. Couple that with the well paced story and unexpected additions such as the ability to play through levels using stealth tactics in a number of areas, an unlockable perk system and loads of secrets/unlockables and you have one of the best shooters of the last few years.

Your mileage may vary with an 8-9 hour campaign and no multiplayer but this is a great return to excellence for Wolfenstein.

reviewText:
Before playing this this it would suck, due to it not being made by ID, because the screenshots all look grey, the enemies are grey, the walls are grey, everything looked grey.  The verdict is in, Wolfenstein is AWESOME!   The screenshots chosen for steam suck, the game is very colorful and does what Thief tried to do but failed.  Machinegames showed they are worthy to wear the jewel in their gaming crown that is Wolfenstein.  From the story which includes things I thought I would never see in a game such as how the Germans treated people in concentration camps, to the visuals of driving a car off a bridge to smash up some Nazi scum.  Feels so good giving that payback they deserve so much.

The game has been criticized for being HUGE, people say its because of the textures.  They seemed ok, some parts like the bridge, they look PS2ish if you look up at the actual bridge.  Viewing the city, it looks dead, I saw a couple cars on one street, but that was it, no other cars moving, even Kane and Lynch had cars moving when your doing the window washing.  To minimize download, developers need follow what Sleeping Dogs and Skyrim did, have an HD texture download separate from the base download, if people want 100gb of textures fine, if not then dont shove it down their throat, we can have both.

Picking up treasures, or unlocking characters are not that rewarding, you cant view the models in 3d, but oddly all these things even the treasures are rendered in 3D but all we get is a screenshot of the object to look at which kinda sucks. I suspect we were supposed to be able to view them but the team ran out of Wolfentime to make the UI.  You might think thats a made up word, but its a real word right off Machinegames site, suck it google spell check!

reviewText:
Welcome back Master!
First Person Shooters has been around since decades, it is one of oldest gaming genres that hasn't much evolved since it first came out.  The foundation of it was so solid that despite with relatively minor tweaks here and there, the genre still sells millions and millions of copies annually with likes of Call of Duty and it provided one of the key platforms for competitive gaming through the likes of Counter Strike for example.


Leading up to the release, I thought it was going to be just another shooter trying to market itself using the franchise's legacy. For the case of Wolfenstein, the legacy of being the first one there - thats right, the original Wolfenstein from id software is pretty much the first game that let you see through the eyes of the protagonist as you go from room to room, clearing enemies while wielding a gun on the bottom of the screen. Yep, it was the very 1st FPS in history.


The story takes place during the high point of World War 2 in Europe, you crash land into a Nazi occupied castle, accompanied by a small group of soldiers scattered from various regiments, you have a clear task of cutting the head of the snake and end this war. The game captures the agony of defeat at your most vulnerable time -  just when you thought you had it won. It carries a very powerful and emotional punch to the gut itself, but what transpires during those darkest hours will haunt you throughout the rest of the game. It further connects you to the game on a very personal level. The characters that you meet to help you fight against the Nazis aren't just there to move the story forward, they aren't your typical forgettable characters you find in most shooters, oh no, they feel like real people going through real hell thanks to the New World Order of the Nazis. Everyone here lost something dear and precious in the 'Old World' to the Nazis and hence have very personal vendetta against them. While on the other side of the fence the cruel and horror nature of the Nazi is brought to life through very well written, well designed and I can confidently say, well hated antagonists in the game. You just don't want to save the people around you, but you also really want to hurt the Nazis and give them no mercy of a quick death.


First impressions are always going to be the visuals, and this game looks good, very good. Not just id tech 5 looks amazing here, from ultra crisp textures, great attention to detail in every corner to bring the world to life. What really caught my attention was the cinematography and the art style of the game: The game uses colors and their contrast to great effect, combined with the sheer attention to detail I mentioned before, it creates a visually ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic experience! The environments are very distinct and crafted with a lot of care and thought just like the rest of the game, no two places ever feels the same. Another thing to note, not only the game takes you to a wide variety of places across the world, but across the time as well. The art style, the condition of the world and it's inhabitants reflect this brilliantly.


The level design also gives the player a lot of options in dealing with situations and change tactics on the fly, which the game actually forces you to do so when playing in harder difficulty modes, which I suggest. The weapons are mostly standard you would expect from a sci-fi shooter with some cooling alternate firing modes and there is something incredibly satisfying when you can dual wield weapons like assault rifles, shotgun and even...rocket launchers..thats right..dual wield rocket launchers.


What really stood out for me is also the main reason I will continue to come back to this game long after I finished it is how precise and satisfying the shooting mechanics felt. It is just pure joy to point your gun and just shoot. Further, the weapons feel solid, distinct and carry satisfying feedback all of which combine to make one of the best shooting experience possible . It is the most basic mechanic for a shooter, but you would be surprised that most fail to deliver here. Modern shooters have made great strides in graphics and other enhancements through this medium, but it also came at a price of deteriorating the key functionalities which made this genre timeless. A lot of the essence of the genre is getting lost with modern 'refinements' being made into the genre. It is very pleasant to discover that Wolfenstein have gone back to basics with their approach to shooting. I found the firefights challenging without being frustrating most the time on the 2nd highest difficulty mode I played. The AI was definitely smart to box me in, flank and even find higher ground to get a upper hand during combat situations.Oh yeah one more thing, the game doesn't even have regenerating health, Win!


There really isn't much negative I can think off to be honest, I guess I have to really nitpick and can I fine just one - some of the textures are oddly of low resolution which really catches the eye because they are at times placed right next to the usual high resolution textures of the game, making it a bit distracting. Also I am not sure why, but the game doesn't have proper anti-aliasing support on the PC, kinda shocking really as it is a standard feature of PC Gaming. Not that the aliasing is too distracting or anything, but it is always nice to clean those jaggies when you have the power at your disposal.


Wolfenstein is very likely not just my game of the year, but it is one of the most important games to come around in my opinion with a clear message: sometimes you have to embrace the past to guide you a better future.


Editor's note: Since Bethesda also acquired the rights to another legendary shooter, DOOM. If they give that game the same level of treatment they gave to Wolfenstein, we can safely anticipate for another solid good comeback!

reviewText:
Classic shooters like DOOM, Shadow Warrior and Duke Nukem are slowly being killed off by generic and linear first person shooters. We were treated to quite some reboots and re-imaginings of classics lately, like Rise of the Triad, Duke Nukem Forever, Shadow Warrior 2013 to name a few. Some were good, but some were severely lacking their original vibe (for example regenerating health or a weapon carrying limit). Hearing about Wolfenstein: The New Order rekindled the old flames inside me that enthousiastically was waiting to bring some of those classic shooters in a modern coat, but I remained sceptical, because the line between a classic shooter and a modern-day parotic reboot is surprisingly thin. I expected it to be a seven-out-of-ten game based on what I had seen and heard about it, and for the first two hours of the game it was exactly that. After that, however, Wolfenstein: The New Order downright blew me away and immediately did everything right in a matter of minutes, raising my final score to a nine out of ten.

The Pros:
· Classic shooters and killing nazi's fit together like pancakes and Nutella: it may be a bit sticky and eye-rollingly cliché at first, but damn is it good and satisfying.
· A high-quality story with fantastic voice-acting and an sickly interresting main villain like we rarely/never get to see in modern-day shooters anymore.
· Wolfenstein: The New Order's gameplay feels authentic without ever feeling like you've already seen it all. Guns handle very well and have a great feel to them, stealth options allow you to approach certain situations differently without  giving you the feeling that you have to go down that certain path, levels flow from tight corridors into larger open areas, and so on. It's jam-packed with features that are bound to attract almost any kind of gamer.

The Cons:
· Every item has to be picked up individually. For example, you can't just run over weapons to collect their ammo or run over armor to wear it. It's not the biggest problem in the world, but I felt like it interrupted the game's pacing at some points.
· For a single-player only game, I personally think 40 GB is a whole lot of space to spend on it. Not that it affects the game in any way, but some people simply can't spend that much space on installing a game. (Even though it's not really a gameplay-related downside, I decided to list it anyway just so you're aware of that. Hell, I have to list SOME downsides.)

The Visuals:
· A-f**king-mazing. Stunning lighting, very solid animations, indrecible textures, fantastic overal design and so on. Definately one of the prettiest games in recent memory.

Final Verdict:
· Wolfenstein: The New Order is easy to love and hard to hate. Some of its minor flaws can easily be overlooked with the high quality it delivers, as it finds the perfect way to bring a classic shooter in a modern-day coat without losing ANY of its charm. 9/10.

For me it's best FPS I've ever played.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a mixed bag. Is it worth the price? I'll break down what I feel are the strong and weak points.



Pros:

- Definitely worthy as a successor/reboot of the series. Gunplay is solid and the action is responsive.
- No major bugs and zero crashes in my playthrough of the whole campaign.
- Ran very well on my 4+ year old setup (GTX 570 and an older i7, 8 GB of RAM) on a mix of High and Medium settings.
- Not afraid to display the swastika and Iron Cross absolutely everywhere. The cityscapes of a post-German WWII victory look fantastic and memorable. Badass and brutal environment for a FPS.
- Optional newspaper clippings and other documents expose the player to how this alternate history scenario happened.
- Looks very nice and has a surprisingly high standard of voice acting and cinematography.
- The German dialogue is very well done and you'll be hearing a lot of it throughout the game.

Cons:

- Takes an extremely interesting alternate history scenario and doesn't take itself seriously enough to really flesh it out. This is more of a personal opinion and can be seen as a neutral point given the fact that the Wolfenstein series has always been about mowing down Nazis, not elaborating on them. The alternate history is very sci-fi, which is fun stylistic choice and serves the game itself well.
- The newspaper clippings and other lore are nice tidbits, but they feel like they're just teasing the player when you realize that there is never any major exposition. What IS revealed though, is very interesting (Manhattan hit with an atom bomb to force the USA's surrender, the Nazis build a bridge across the Strait of Gibraltar, etc.)
- Oddly disjointed storyline that doesn't feel rewarding to the player due to its sporadic focus and odd jumps in continuity (Minor spoiler: deciding to be purposely captured to be placed into a forced-labor camp with NO decision or setup from the player whatsoever - what?!).
- Little variety in enemy types and overly high margin of difficulty between them (light enemies are trivially easy, heavy enemies can be a slog).
- The unlock system only enables alternate gameplay modes, which doesn't contribute greatly to replayability. Definitely a one-and-done game.



Overall, this is a solid pickup if you are looking for an enjoyable single-player FPS experience, but you may be lefting wanting more in the narrative. Very solid FPS gameplay and OK on the narrative/storyline. This game is worth picking up for at least one playthrough.

reviewText:
Short review:
It's absolutely brilliant, one of the best shooters in years, buy it now, you won't be disappointed!

Longer review:
I'm stingey when it comes to PC games these days, I don't buy at full price simply because by the time I get round to playing a game it'll be on sale.

Wolfenstein is a rare game that's absolutely worth the full price. The levels are large, the visual effects are great, the sound likewise and most importantly the gameplay is superb!

So may shooters feel 'wrong', like you're on roller skates all the time gliding through levels. In Wolfenstein you feel yourself running, you fling yourself behind cover when under fire only to have chunks of it blown out around you (which you can then shoot through). It's absurd, over the top and thrilling.

There's so much else to recommend though...

The cutscenes and acting are some of the most realistic I've ever seen and really pull you into the story.

There's upgrades so you can enhance skills!

Finally...once you finish the game...play through it all again making a different choice at the end of the first level, I'm doing that again now and seeing characters I hadn't seen before, it's a great idea!

Absolutely finally...the achievements are sensible and quite easy to get, this is definitely a game you can avhieve the perfect game rating in Steam.

As I write this it's even on offer as part of a weekend deal...don't hesitate at this price.

Needless to say, I'm really hoping they make a sequel!

reviewText:
If you're looking for a familiar old game with a massive update, then Wolfenstein : The New Order is most definitely the right game to bring back the updated Wolfenstein with an interesting story.

- Story : The main protagonist is Captain Blazkowicz, a US marine captain that fights the Nazis in an alternative 1946 timeline, where the Germans are close to winning.
As he's hurt in the process of trying to kill the main vilain, Dr.Wilhelm Strasse. He sleeps in a coma for 14 years and when he finally wakes up, the world is now under Nazi rule. Your job is to find the resistance and have your revenge to kill Dr.Wilhelm Strasse.

- Graphics : Even if this game came out as recently as of may 2014, the graphics are surprisingly gritty, flashy at times and realistic. The light reflections, shadows, explosions and soldiers, all look great.
The environments are very nice looking and you can definitely see how gritty and realistic the character's faces are. Maybe it's because I don't play a lot of recent games but I now realize how good the graphics are in this game.

- Sounds : The sound effects of the weapons, the echo screams and vehicules are in excellent quality, the music is well done but tuned down a little in the main game to excite the players with more action packed gameplay.

- Gameplay : The game is odviously a first person shooter, so the game needs more variety, options and difficulty to make it playable and adaptable.
But even though the main game is linear, it adds other paths to choose, different ways to kill ennemies, and, (like the old wolfenstein games), you can hold two weapons and shoot at the same time like a badass. there are of course the standard, shotgun, and massive ennemies.
Even mechanical dogs try to jump at you. You can also rip the heavy machine gun turret to have it in your hands, which is something i personally haven't seen before.
There are some areas that you can kill everyone in stealth, so it's good to have that option but for me, I just like to go all out, straight out killing Nazis.

But it's not a perfect game of course. For example, most or possibly all boss battles are so easy, I really wish they added soldiers, making him more difficult to kill or anything creative to build the tension and releif of beating a powerful boss.
The moon mission was so interesting to me but it was quite rushed, get ready to have 3 minutes in space, have fun !
And lastly, personally, i'm not particularly interested in the other vilains and other characters. I like the personalities of your crew but some are all around forgettable.

It's the basics of a fun first person shooter and this is the game that launched a new genre in gaming and manages to shows no signs of aging and/or distortion.
I recommend playing this game on sale if you want a familiar look and feel of a classic, yet modern look, of one of the most important games of it's time.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is one of the few FPS where I've actually cared about the characters in it.

Perhaps it's the inherit nature within me as a British Citizen, as a proud member of Her Majesty's kingdom, a defender of this small little island, but I really, really, really enjoyed shooting Nazis. I can't explain it any other way. It must be something within the core of my being, I just loved this game. I'm not really doing Wolfensten: New Order (WNO) any justice here by saying that, as the game is just plain old fun - and not just because you get to shoot nazis.

WNO managed to take me back to a time where FPS weren't about huge cinematic set plays within the gameplay, it was simply about being fast, frantic and frenetic. When all you wanted in a game was to run through corridors guns blazing  and to kill everyone standing in your way -- and this game delivers.
The game offers this in abundance with a huge range of guns to use along the way too, however it's not all about blazing through the levels. WNO offers the option for stealth with some very satisfying takedown kills. In fact 'satisfying' is a great word to describe WNO as a whole. The pacing, the soundtrack, the characters, the level design, the use of actual REAL accents from the voice actors make all of this satisfying. The developers have done a great job of balancing the pace of the game, knowing when to ramp it up and when to let it cool off for a bit before ramping it off again.

All in all WNO remembers what it is - a FPS. It some ways it manages to acheive something that the original Wolfenstein did over 20 years ago in defining the genre. I felt reinvigorated about playing First Person Shooters again after experiencing Wolfenstein.
I'm sorry I hadn't played it sooner, if I had played this back in 2014 I'm pretty sure it would have been my GOTY (just beating Rogue Legacy). Essentially, it's one of the best FPS I've played in a LONG time and I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText: I went into this game thinking it was just another shooter. I typically don't play too many FPS's and I heard that this game was worth my time so I gave it a go. That alone would have been enough for me to give this game a good rating.\n\nHowever, what makes this game an easy recommendation is the story. Who would have thought a Wolfenstein game would have solid characters and a storyline that makes you want to see how it finishes. The story definitely goes places and it gets DARK at times, but war is hell and there is something worth fighting for.

reviewText:
So I have been on a rampage of getting games and not getting hooked to them, either because I get bored, the game ain't good, or simply I don't have time. Wolfenstein: The New Order is way different.

I'm playing on the hard difficulty for the first playthrough, and let me tell you, this is no joke. The game is immersive in the long intro, and transitions into the new setting pretty well.
I'm running it on a laptop, a crappy one, on lowest settings and with worst quality settings, still getting low frames per second, but it is worth it. This game is brilliant.

Pros:
-Satisfying Kills
-Amazing graphics (watched gameplay on ultra)
-Guns feel powerfull
-Dual Wielding assault rifles, shotguns...
-Various routes for each level
-Stealth is a viable option in some cases
-Cover destruction on some parts
-You can detach a bloody mounted machinegun and go guns blazing like no Nazi can stop you
-Fairly challenging on the highest difficulties
-Choices that may or may not affect the story

Neutral (?):
-The skilltree is based on things you achieve in game, for example, kill -x- amount of guards with throwing knives to get a skill.

Cons:
-Requires a beefy computer
-Texture popping is common
-Expensive, not usually on sale


I highly recommend this game, it's surprisingly fun. Wish me luck on my hard quest!

reviewText:
First Off. I want to say this is Hands-Down the best first person shooter I've ever played. As far as Story, Game-Play and Design go.

This isn't just a game where you don't care much about the characters. Each character is unique in their personality. While this game often takes a serious tone, there still is humor at some points that'll at least make you chuckle a bit. The story is well done to the point where I repeatedly told myself only one more level and went on to do another

The game is well paced and doesnt just have you moving through areas gunning down tons of enemies every time. There'll be times where the stealth approach is better and there'll be times where it be best to go guns blazing. However, you do not have to play a certain way. With destructable cover, you'll find yourself running from cover to cover as the concrete blocks or metal panels you're taking cover behind get shredded to pieces.

Throughout the game, you'll find different upgrades and variations of the weapons you have that keep the game feeling fresh. Never in this game did I get tired of the combat. From the beginning of the game, I knew I had to do at least a second playthrough of this game soon

All in all, if you enjoyed Bioshock and like a game that makes you feel badass, look no further. Cause this game is the ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein The New Order is without a doubt in my mind an amazing game.
Machine Games knew the risk of developing this and I feel they pulled it off.

The gameplay is an incredibly fluid and accessible experience. The variety of not only missions and situations but also your own equipment and tactics is staggering. Just like in classic old school shooters you're allowed freedom in how you tackle situations. The gameplay never feels rigidly scripted and the player is free to break stealth into a deadly assault at their own choice.

For many people this will range from silently evading and assassinating targets one by one to running in guns blazing with your dual assault rifles in a relentless assault. The game promotes and encourages the player to experiment with a variety of both weaponry and multiple paths throughout the mission area. Despite being a game with linear progression, it never truly feels that way and offers a high amount of re-playability.

One notable example is a night time assault early in the game. While it encourages stealth, it is completely possible to run in loud. In-fact it is even possible to combine the two, silently killing the commanders and then zip-lining to the nearby roof. To open fire with your dual assault rifles on the Nazis below you. The possibilities presented are endless and just as open from one mission to the next, with minimum control by the game for certain story related events.

However, I feel the true defining factor in TNO is the gripping weave of both intense gameplay and touching narrative. Despite being in an alternative universe with retro-scifi robotic Nazi soldiers, Machine Games was able to produce a world that contrasts clearly with ours and holds no punches back with its brutal reality.

The idea of a world controlled by the Nazis is very real and incredibly chilling. No expense is spared to show how such a world would function. The world is perfect"

recommended: the world is purged of the inferior; science is amoral and followed fanatically with a bent to weapons research to ensure maximum control and dominance. The world is rigid

Machine Games also had no problem showing the extent of human psychology and the way people attempt to justify their actions. The main antagonist justifies not only his creations but also of the Nazi idealism “It matters not what you destroy

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order just goes to show how great singleplayer games can still be! From the moment it first started, I was hooked. It just goes to show that not every game needs some crappy tacked on multiplayer component to sell or be good, and because of that, they have created an amazing story that is fun and engaging which i look forward to replaying.

All of the characters are likable, especially BJ, which is important as it gives the player a reason to be invested in him and the story and see him suceed against Deathshead, who you can't help love and also hate at the same time, a great villain. The character design is just as good, with great looking vehicles, weapons and unique enemy types such as the panzerhounds. The gunplay is fun and excting, most weapons come with secondary functions such as adding silencers, to changing the fire mode and the ability to duel weld them.

You can also unlock passive perks as you play, depending on how you play. Such as if you tend to play more stealithy, you will unlock the ability to pick up and throw knives. All of this works in the background so you don't need to manage any of it.

The game is full of collectibles as well as bits of paper cuttings and intel that expand upon the game world, and you actually want to read these, as they can be at times very funny as they try to link what would have happened if the Nazis had won. Such as The Beatles being forced to sing all of their songs in German, and their newest album, Das Blaue U-Boot". There is even a nice easter egg
recommended:
but it caught me by surprise and made me smile from ear to ear.

This will be my first review I have wrote because honestly this game deserves all the praise it gets. It blew me away and I was surprised at how well made it is and how much I enjoyed it. I encourage everyone to play this game and I hope more game companies realize you don't need a multiplayer slapped on.

10/10"

reviewText:
Approach a series of rooms filled with nazis and secret paths. Silently kill as many as you can working your way to the reinforcement-calling commanders. Attempt to assatinate them with knives and silenced pistols before anyone gets wise.

♥♥♥♥ up your solid snake routine inadvertently and whip out double auto shotguns and go postal HAM. You become like general grevious but instead of light sabres you weild a rocket launcher in one hand and an assault rifle in the other.

Areas favor exploration with rewards (higher hp caps, armor, health), and the game will buff your weapons automatically depending on your playstyle. Over the top firearms and future tech complimented by a dark and serious story. Game includes a wide variety of fantastical environments, non-cringe inducing sex (eat ♥♥♥♥ Mass Effect and Metro 2033) a couple game-defining bosses, and a decent length clocking in at ten hours.

Negatives are that the game's progress stagnates as you search for the item or passage (hinted by a blue reticle event flag) that will enable you to move the hell on. Your future light gun runs out of ammo way to fast and recharging it is a tedious pain in the ♥♥♥. Also you have to beat it twice to access the slight differences in gameplay (one character lives vs another in an early mission). Default bindings for firearms blow my ♥♥♥. It's sometimes wiser to just skip a group of enemies rather than gun them all down if you know where to exit.

If it goes on sale again you should buy it.

reviewText:
Well, after Raven's Wolfenscheisse 2009 things simply couldn't get any worse. Task was simple: make an average old-school First Person Shooter game, and fans will say thanks for resurrecting a franchise. And MachineGames did it. They did it well, but unfortunately they couldn't get it any higher.

Gameplay MechanicsGood old FPS genre is back. No more magic, no more trading and other RPG parody that Raven tried to bring us in 2009. Classic guns only: pistol/machinegun/shotgun/sniper/grenades + new LaserKraftWerk (LKW) weapon, which after a few upgrades reminds me Railgun from Quake. Yes, there are weapon upgrades, which bring new fire modes and ammo types. There is a Minigun too, but it can't be stored in the player's inventory (both B.J.'s pockets are full with huge automatic shotguns, no place for minigun there), so it can be used until dropped, i.e. in specific areas only.

Wolfenstein: The New Order supports 3 playstyles:
Run'n'gun. Introduced in Wolf3D, widely used in Doom and Quake and brought to ridiculous level in Painkiller and Serious Sam. All weapons can be dual-wielded, even sniper rifles. Converting Nazis into pile of meat with dual automatic shotguns is fun. Unrealistic, ridiculous but fun. There were several pictures of B.J. Blazkowicz holding two miniguns back in Wolfenstein 3D. And it was finally implemented in The New Order. +1 for sticking with roots.
Covering. When you are low on ammo (dual-wielding eats ammo fast) or just prefer precise shooting over Ramboing"

reviewText:
I will go on record to say I fully expected Wolfy TNO to suck. From all of the previews and trailers, it came off like a wacky but derivative Call of Duty game with Nazis in it. I'm very glad to say I was completely dead wrong.

Wolfenstein the New Order is surprisingly enough a sequel to Wolfy 09 and Return to Castle Wolfenstein. It has a vastly different approach then either of those two games. TNO takes place in an alternate reality 1960 where Germany won the war after discovering the Atom bomb. This allowed the game to have extremely good imagery like sci-fi war mechs and power armor alongside classic Wolfenstein tropes like over the top guns. You have a really cool arsenal of weapons ranging from dual wielding assault rifles to hand held lasers that let you melt holes in walls.

However what TNO does best is it expands upon previous games. The protagonist Bj Blazkowicz isn't a static brick in this game like he was in Wolfy 09 or RtCW. He has a surprisingly good internal monologue that portrays him as a very shell shocked and emotional individual, completely unlike the stock American action film portrayal previous games had. This actually makes the storyline far more relatable then it was in previous games.

With the gameplay and story locked down, the last most defining feature of TNO is it's art direction. From it's enemies like I mentioned earlier to it's really top notch aesthetics. The maps remain fairly linear and enclosed but it makes up for it with the impressive attention to detail in many of the levels.

Wolfenstein the New Order is how you do a sequel to a retro game series well. You do your research and pay respect to earlier games while also expanding upon the mechanics. It's a very charismatic yet humble game, and it comes very highly recommended from me.

reviewText:
Alternate history of the after effects of World War II had the Nazi's won and Joe America, the reluctant hero destroys a nation and the tyranny sought by those who wish to see you beg.

I was first interested in this game because I'd heard that many folks were surprised at the character depth and downtime spent with the people in your bunker. As Wolfenstein of the past is more or less just a twitch-y first person shooter and this one has more cut-scenes than it did previously. The gameplay loop goes something like this; Shoot all the things, make it go boom. America is the best. BJ Blazkowicz regrets his past, walk around with some people that are vaguely interesting. Maybe collect something for one or more of them. Shoot all the things, make it go boom.. America..

And it just goes on like that. There is nothing wrong with this game. Its just innocuous. I am neither mad at the time I spent playing it nor am I glad I bothered to take the time. It has it moments, its a true summer blockbuster. I personally just didn't care for it in the end. But it is extremely competent mechanically. The stealth feels good. Weapons feel properly powerful. You get to cut metal with a plasma cutter that would make Issac Clarke jealous; but it all comes to together in this package that feels immediately forgettable. I'm tired of shooting Nazis; no matter how cool it feels to do while a rocking soundtrack blares as you move in slow motion. This was obviously a game with a huge budget. Its a shame they didn't do much to make it unique.

There is a faintly interesting moment where you make a relatively prominent choice in where the story goes. One that might make some of you go back and replay the entire game to see what changes but for me; I'm satisfied.

THE GIST
A very competent though relatively unchallenging big budget shooter.

reviewText:
1- Great story = Check
2- Great Gameplay = Check
3- Great Music/sound quality = Check
4- Great camera movement = Check
5- Dual Wielding everything = Dual Check!

The FPS genre is really overused these days with nearly all games are first person shooters. but not that it matters to Wolfenstein, why? because this game is just unique in the story itself, the way it is presented to you. how william whispers to himself, communicating his thoughts to you. it is just brilliant. its nice smooth and well executed. I finished the game with a smile yet sad face, a smile on my face because I enjoyed the game. a sad face because the ending crushed my heart.

Gameplay:- Now Wolfenstein isn't any different from other FPS games. you point and shoot. pick up ammo, pick up health and go destroy some nazi's. in any brutal way you see fit. what's different in Wolfenstein however, is its perk system. You dont have to accumulate some exp and waste its point on the perk. you actually need to fulfill some objectives to each perk in order to activate it and unlock the next on the line. I find that system a bit challenging. specially when I try to sneak and assassinate. I dont have the patience to sneak anymore... so I go in guns blazing and shooting the hell out of the nazi's.

Sound/Music:- The Voice acting is amazing. everyone did their roles perfectly. and so much that sucked me in the game. This is a critical part for me. if voice acting sucks, I wont be dragged in and I will probably lose interest in the game. Wolfenstein however did not disappoint, the cast was brilliant. The music also was great. well done, well placed. gets you hyped in locations where you need to be hyped.

Graphics/animation. Wolfenstein is not a major leap  in future graphics. the graphics are just well done. Not amazing, not eye candy, Just normally right. it feels like the people who made it poured their souls into it. these kind of games I really like to support. Unlike the crap crysis 2 and 3... sheesh. these games are graphically nice, but felt dull and boring.

Overall, Wolfenstein The new Order is a great game. I enjoyed it fully. Not disappointed. money well spent! would totally recommend it!

reviewText:
This game starts off as a brilliant combination of old-school and new-(ish) school shooters, with a fun premise and a reminder of how much fun it is to blow away Nazis. I recommend the game for that initial rush of excitement, and because it's a mostly well-executed shooter with satisfying, if simplistic, shooting action.

But there are a ton of flaws. It does that thing where you stop just shooting Nazis, and spend more of your time fighting mecha-Nazi whatevers. The boss fights are uninspired and more frustrating than challenging. It has checkpoints. The bad guys best you in cut scenes in ways that would never work if they didn't take away your control. There are a bunch of doors that don't do anything. There are some supremely boring HQ fetch quests where you can't even fire your weapon at imaginary Nazis, and there are puzzles that aren't puzzling during the game.

This game commits a lot of design sins, but it still leaves you feeling good about your purpose. While my list of cons is longer than the list of pros, I don't regret playing through this game at all.

reviewText:
Does this game break any outstanding barriers when it comes to FPS? No.

Is this game's single player FPS just as good or even greater than Metro? Yes, and depends who you are.

When I was first recommended Wolfenstein, I really couldn't care for the series. I knew it was some old time Doom sort of game that probably hasn't seen a good upgrade. It was recommended again and I caved. I'm glad I did.

The story starts off with you, an American soldier, in WW2 fighting off nazi's. Not just any nazi's though, these ones are quite technologically advanced and have some odd soldiers on their side. Eventually, the main character  becomes captured by one of the scientists and years pass as the main character is in rehab in Poland after taking shrapnel to the head. The character then leaves rehab as patients start disappearing and the home care workers are forced out. The real story and fun starts around this point.

The story lead up is a bit slow, but the game has no problem giving the player different experiences as an FPS. You will fly a plane, you will drive a car, and other small gimmicks that make the game enjoyable. It adds depth and makes the game that much more profound to continue playing. I would put this shooter on par with metro as dismemberment and effects when shooting a soldier are quite spot on.

My absolute favorite feature about this game (which I hope every game may incorporate) is the ability to control your movement behind cover. Are you behind a wall? Are you crouching behind cover? In any scenario, the player (on a controller) can hold L1 and with the joystick position the player around a wall or over cover to minimize exposure to enemy bullets. There are no shortage of weapons to choose from, and they made it possible to dual wield almost any gun. A specialized laser weapon is also given to cut through certain obstacles to enable progression throughout the story. The laser weapon can also be changed into a high burst beam where it can be used against enemies. Other weapons feature some sort of modification when it comes to shooting (often right D pad changes the fire settings). What is quite remarkable is the scenery's reaction to bullets. Enemies that are hiding behind cover can have it be shot away by the player leaving them vulnerable. This also applies to the players scenario where taking cover for too long behind a breakable barrier will lead to damage due to absent cover. Unlike call of duty, the environment can be to an extent blown away and damaged by bullets or explosions. Although it's not to the extreme where things will start disappearing, the concept of being able to almost destroy any cover an enemy is hiding behind is quite appealing, visually and for the game play. The AI's do not seem linear and will seek to come to you from any side. Flanking is not as popular as Deus Ex in this case, but traces of enemy brilliance are there.

The visuals are quite neat and the graphics play well. The game can ask quite a bit from your machine at times. I have not noticed any frame rate issues (either than you may need to V-sync) and that the sounds are rich and plentiful.

The story is great, and even develops the main character. I was hoping as so because killing nazi's" attitude gets real old
date: real fast.\n\nI want to give this game an 8 for being a good FPS shooter giving the player quite a bit of control over what goes on
recommended:
but I feel like that little bit more is missing. Could easily be an 8 with local co-op or multiplayer.


RATING : 7.8/10


For future Wolfenstein's
