reviewText:
Wolfenstein hasn’t been a strong franchise since Wolfenstein 3D. I’ve had a reasonably good time with all the later titles. But I wouldn’t hold up any of them as particularly strong shooters. I went into The New Order with cautiously optimistic expectations. I’m glad to say it exceeded them.

The mood of the game feels almost ethereal. It reminds me a lot of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay. Which maybe shouldn’t be a surprise since it’s by the same people. The New Order goes for the “play the way you want” school of FPS design. Combat arenas are open with plenty of alternative routes, and the AI is designed to allow for both stealthy and gung ho play styles. And it works! It doesn’t have sophisticated stealth mechanics, but they do the job. And what I mentioned earlier about the mood is conveyed in large part by the music. It hits just the right note for this type of game. It doesn’t stress you in any way. The voice over and dialogue is similarly subdued to not make you feel stressed. All this made it feel nice to be in the game world.

Despite this the game has a slew of problems, like the combat. In other FPSes like Serious Sam or Shadow Warrior you learn instinctively how to react to certain enemies. Like how you’re supposed to move in order to avoid their attacks. In Wolfenstein I never had a solid idea of how enemies really behaved. I’m scratching my head just thinking of how I’d describe the optimal strategy to taking out normal soldiers, or shotgun dudes, or the tough armored soldiers. It doesn’t feel like they’re designed to have an optimal strategy you can learn. Just shoot them all in the head and hope for the best. The design just isn’t good enough for a game of this length. It’s the same with the health system. It doesn’t have regenerating health, but I wish it did, because this wasn’t designed well enough to work without it. Sometimes there’s not enough health packs, and sometimes there’s way too many. It was rarely “just right”. It’s not a complete disaster, but far from ideal.

It has other minor annoyances like how it randomly chooses which weapons you have at the start of each level. Sometimes you get to keep your sniper rifle between maps. Sometimes you don’t. At one point it disappeared for several hours, only to reappear in my inventory for no reason, with all my other guns removed. There was no satisfactory in-game excuse for this, so it seemed like the game was screwing me over for no reason. Let me keep my guns you ♥♥♥♥♥♥!

The story also had obvious problems. There’s subplots that don’t go anywhere, and the drama curve is off. Meaning that when you reach the finale there’s no sense of occasion. The game hasn’t built up to that moment properly, so there’s no feeling of anticipation or excitement. Instead it just sort of happens. Overall I liked the story. It tried to make the main and supporting characters into actual characters, and it kind of worked. I’ve seen some describe it as laughably bad, and I don’t agree with that. This is head and shoulders above the current FPS average. It needed more time in editing though. The issues are glaring.

Despite all the problems I really liked the game. The stuff that sucked didn’t ruin the game for me. It still had elements strong enough that the problems didn’t matter. It would’ve been nice had the combat and story been better. But even with those issues it managed get enough things lined up right that it clicked. I wanted to see what was around the corner. I was never bored. That’s why I hope this team gets to do another singleplayer FPS. They’ve got a good thing going here. Try again, and maybe you’ll make a classic.

reviewText: So I'm a big Wolfenstein fan going back to the original 1992 version and there was no way I was going to pass this up.  The game overall is great looking; backgrounds and world look fantastic even in lower resolutions.  The game play is pretty typical of any FPS with the exception of the dual wield function which you can do with almost any weapon.  You can really do some damage when you fire with both of the assault rifles or shotguns at the same time, or better yet set one assault rifle to fire rockets and one to fire bullets.  The dual wield sniper rifles are a little silly but novel and fun to try.  You cannot mix and match (ie one shotty and one assault rifle).  Game play is mostly shoot'em up, but there are a number of areas where stealth is strongly advised and encouraged.  There is a pretty good selection of weapons but typically at the beginning of each level your weapons are removed and you have to start with what the game gives you for that level and what you can find during the mission.  Weapons include knives, grenades, pistols, assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles and the laserkraftwerk which is a laser rifle with a number of upgrades available (its cutting feature is also important).  All the rifles have alternate fire modes (ie rockets on the assault rifle, shrapnel ammo for the shotty etc.)\n\nControls are pretty standard.  One thing I didn't like was the slide function.  On a standard keyboard you have to hold down W and SHIFT" to run forward
date: then tap CTRL to slide under obstacles.  It's fairly awkward and you will have to do it half a dozen times throughout the game
recommended: plus 3 times while killing an enemy to earn a perk.\n\nPerks are a major feature of the game and are split up into 4 categories (Stealth
hoursPlayed: Tactical
voteText: Assault and Demolition) with 8 perks per category.  Earning perks gives you access to better weapon mods and features .  Killing enemies with knives in various ways and in certain numbers will earn you stealth perks while killing with grenades or rockets will earn you demolition perks as an example.  The one downside to this system is you generally must obtain one perk before moving onto the next.  So in the case of Demolition you must kill 10 enemies with grenades before you can work on the next perk which is to kill an enemy commander with a grenade.  Even if you already killed a commander in the first 10 enemies
helpfulPercent: it won’t count toward the new perk.  Perks are permanently part of your character once earned.\n\nThe game has a deep story and cinematics
votesHelpful: most of which can be skipped on a second playthrough
votesTotal: but some you will have to sit through a second time (ie the train scene).  Most of the story is good
votesFunny: but gets a bit tedious in spots.  Fighting Nazis on the moon is tough to beat!\n\nIf you are a person who likes a lot of collectibles
commentsCount: this game has them in spades: enigma codes
column16: gold pieces
column17: health boosts
column18: personal letters that give various peoples stories of the Nazi world etc.  They’re all relatively easy to find (I got 75-90% on my first play through)
column19: but a few are tricky and Steam guides are a big help.  There are a couple of others (concept art and characters) that are triggered automatically when you encounter a character or area of a map.  The enigma codes unlock other game play modes when you manage to crack them.\n\nAchievements are all pretty easy to get; there are 50 overall.  All of the 32 perks generate an achievement when you get them
column20: most of the rest are for collectibles and making it through various stages of the game.\n\nSome of the downsides : too short overall
column21: no multiplayer
column22: AI is wak in spots (this is NOT Dishonored)
column23: highly linear (this is NOT Fallout New Vegas) whihc affects re-playability and the save feature is limited to game autosaves.  The autosave is especially annoying as it overwrites if you decide to replay a previous chapter from the menu.  If you do decide to re-play a previous chapter
column24: do it once you have finished your current chapter so as not to lose any game play.\n\nOne word of advice with respect to the perk feature
column25:
keep an eye on it constantly and try to determine if a given situation you are in most suited to obtaining a certain perk.  I would even go so far as to recommend playing the first mission a few times over before moving on to try to pick up as many perks as possible.  Otherwise you may find yourself playing the game the way the perk system forces you to instead of the way you want.

I’m not sure whether or not this is worth $60.  I think the casual FPS fan would feel it is overpriced.  Probably $30 is a good trigger price.

As a final note unlike others I did not have any hardware issues (i7-960 Bloomfield

reviewText:
When I started playing this game, I expected pure Nazi mayhem, where feels were gone, and guns were in. Oh how I was wrong.

Yes, I still got all the Nazi mayhem I wanted. Duel wielding automatic shotguns, assault rifles, rockets, and heck, even sniper rifles. Is it plausible or nessecary? Nope, but its Wolfenstein so why the hell not? All the run gun fun from older shooters has made it into this game as well as the level design. Most levels allow for a nice amount of exploration, and award the player for exploring secret passageways by gifting them various upgrades and ammo. There is an option of going sneakily, with silenced pistols and knives being present in your inventory for this(and yes, you can duel wield both). Gameplay gets a 9.5/10, the .5 being shot off by a stray shrapnel shot by a shotgun Nazi because he violates everything in the vicinity.

Now... the story. Comming into the gameplay, and remembering this is the Wolfenstein series, one would expect very little justification on why we should kill Nazis, when its the main reason we bought this game. Yet the story takes a very surprising turn when it actually starts depicting the horrors that they have put upon the world, giving you fresh new reasons to brutally murder them. As the story goes on and on, your rage against the Nazis increases further and further, and luckily, the game knows it, because by the end when you reach the final level, ready to shove your knife down the main guys throat, all that stands between him and you is fifty million Nazis and Mechs, giving you plenty of room to work off your feels. And speaking of feels, this game just loves making you feel. All the characters displayed have some sort of personality, have a goal, and are flawed. I really liked each character, and how their story progressed. Without any spoilers, the story progressed in a direction I did not like at all, making me hate the Nazis with an even stronger passion. When I got to the last chapter, I was livid from what happened eariler, and simply couldn't wait to start tearing that place inside out. Once I had finished the chapter and saw the ending, my feels went supernova, and it was quite a heck of a ending for the game. There is the whole dual path thing where you can choose the outcome of a certain choice in the beginning to alter the timeline, but this doesn't change much besides a few paths and dialouge, the story is still intact. Also, being a Wolfenstein game, this game does have some weird spots here and there so that the plot can progress accordingly, while making little sense in the progress. Those are far and few and between though, earning the story aspect a 9.5/10.

Final Verdict: Want some of the funnest old-school gameplay this year has to offer along with a surprisingly well crafted story designed to make you feel and to engross you into the game even more? Pick this up at your next summer sale! One run took me 14-16 hours, and I'm planning on hitting up at least two more runs(alternate timeline, and a custom game mode one).

reviewText:
I was expecting to kick some Nazi butt. This expectation was fulfilled.
I was expecting to use really awesome guns to do so. This too was fulfilled.

The gameplay rocks, the replayability is great (I've just put in 20 hours to complete my first go through, yet now I have another timeline to experience and up to four different game modes to challenge me), and the story is so enthralling, you actually become William J. Blazkowicz. You feel his joy, his pain,  his anger and his sorrow.

Get psyched.

reviewText:
Get Physched!

The perfect blend of what's modern and what's old. It takes the best of both worlds and runs with it. With it's singleplayer focus, it adds a much more meaningful experience. It might not have multiplayer, but I will be playing this over and over again, trying out the different paths in the solo experience that I hadn't before.

Gunplay? Satisfying as all hell. Good god, not once since Sniper Elite have I ever thought shooting a guy in the head would be so satisfying. This game is literally gunporn. You can dual weild guns, which does slow you down and adds inaccuracy, but definately packs a punch. You can slide across the floor and shoot your gun, take cover and shoot, pull a lever and shoot simutaneously. It's just so convenient and satisfying. There's tons of room for trickshots. It's even better with its fictional guns, which are seriously AWESOME.

The gore? Awesome. I ♥♥♥♥ing love all the blood and guts. This is one of the bloodiest games I've ever played in recent years. You can blow a guys head off and see all the chunks, throw a grenade and see the body blow up, defeat a boss and see his chunks splash all over. Holy ♥♥♥♥, it's awesome.

I recommend playing on harder difficulties to get the most out of your experience. I personally find the lower difficulties and even normal a bit too easy.

This game is highly recommended for people who love shooter games like myself. Plus if you have a uniform fetish, you'd probably like this game as well. Lots of neat designs for the National Socialist enemies.

SHOULD YOU BUY IT: Yeah!" -BJ Blazcowikz

reviewText:
One of the reasons I bought Wolfenstein: The New Order was the astonishing rate of positive reviews. But were they true?

HELL YES! I enjoyed the game from the first moment to the last, the plot is really well written, and even a person who haven't played its predecessors will quickly find himself in the world of Wolfenstein. Playability of this game is through the roof - you can almost feel the joy of killing every damn Nazi (maybe I'm just a sick person). Graphical side of the game is generally satisfying.

The controls are very responsive and after a few hours of play you already feel like an MLG pro. Perks are cool addition (they are kinda standard in most FPS games) and are not that hard to get. Same goes with achievements, most of which are progress related or simply obtainable by getting a certain perk. The characters are very well designed, e.g. Deatshead makes an impression of a real sick mind, striving for power, and through the cutscenes you can almost see why so many people fear him.

Minor flaw of the entire production is the level of difficulty. Personally I think that the hardest difficulty is relatively easy, and for an experienced player finishing Wolfenstein on UBER is not that big of a challenge. Also I can admit that lower difficulties are designed well to fit the casuals that don't want to challenge themselves, but to enjoy this amazing plot.

Last but not least, let's talk about collectibles. Some of them are quite hard to find, but that only makes finding them more satisfying. Moreover, the Enigma Code puzzles are cool addition to the game, and allow us to unlock bonus game modes.

To summarize - I really enjoyed every minute of the gameplay, and I think the game is worth every penny. I'd recommend it to everyone 10/10

Pros:
Well written plot
Playability
Good character design
Achievements and collectibles
Overal fun of playingCons:
Lack of a really challenging difficulty level

reviewText:
I've been extremely surprised by this one. I was expecting a badass protagonist with badass (dual-wielding) weapons, and I got that. I was expecting quite gory, over-the-top fights against Nazis with explosions left and right and I got that too.

But I was not expecting stealth elements, nor a pretty solid narrative backing the entire game.

It's a great take on the classic from 1992, Wolfenstein 3D, brought to modern graphics and gameplay. It is also moderately replayable due to choices that will affect some events of the story.

If you want to play a solid and mature single player FPS game that doesn't pretend to be yet another RPG hybrid... get this, and you won't be disappointed.

My vote: 8.5 / 10
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a easily one of the best FPSes of the year.

The shooting itself is so satisfying that it easily stays fresh for at least two playthroughs. Add some nice level design, multitude of weapons, a lot of gore and a lengthy campaign, and you have an awesome game that is very easy to recommend for fans of the genre.

A good comparison to make here is with the new Shadow Warrior: it takes the gameplay to new directions while it does not forget it roots. For this reason, I wouldn't call the New Order an old-school FPS but thankfully, it is FAR away from the typical, dumbed-down modern shooter.

I have only three gripes with the game:

- I hope it won't come in a DLC or something but when you establish a really twisted boss throughout the game (and I'm not talking about Totenkopf), it is downright painful to see that character (though not unscratched) get away .

- While the levels are varied enough, there were some opportunities that the developers missed out on especially if we look at how over-the-top the game is. For example, if you put us on the Moon, have some nice fights on the surface with low gravity or something! (Instead of just shooting down three drones over the course of 2 minutes...)

- The game presents two timelines that are essentially two playthroughs, however the differences are just too small to bother. Sure, it is worth is because of the gunplay, but it would have been nice if at least some of the scenes are different. (Apart from meeting another side-character and getting another type of collectible, it is pretty much the same. Wyatt and Fergus even say some of the same lines, like how both are mad at you for making the wrong choice.)

But these are just very small concerns for an otherwise fantastic game.

While I am a bit hesitant recommending it at €50, I got it during the Steam Sale for half its price, and I must say it was very, very worth it.

P.S.: I can't stress enough how satisfying the shooting is. Seriously, dual-wielding shotguns (one that shoots the regular pellets, the other shooting ricocheting pellets) and mowing down a bunch of enemies is majestic.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: New Order is a very weird game to examine from a narrative stand point.

Prior to the game's releases, the dev's emphasized the bizarre campiness, with the nazi moon base, the nazified versions of pop culture classics, and the general speculative nature of the setting.

When I played it, it seemed like this was how it was going. I'm riding in some sort of super B-17/cargo plan hybrid in 1946 fighting off jets, land and fight off robo dogs, and then have to stop a giant mecha. I meet some stock characters, who are likable, and the gameplay is oddly open.

Then we get to the end of this first act and instead I expierenced one of the most gut wrenching scenes in a game that honestly left me feeling awful, and what follows next is a sequence where an almost braindead BJ reflects on his life and helplessly watches the world change around him.

The game does a good job with establishing pathos. Nazis are evil, so here they act evil, but they also do a good job of adding human elements. The main antagonist, aside from Deathshead, is shown having a loving, if rather sleazy, relationship with a younger man but it seems rather earnest. I had this weird feeling about this woman, who basically forced me to pick cards to determine my idealogical background, who is also a normal person with a relationship.

Your staff of allies are also well developed, Max Hass could have, especially, been a character to make my eyes roll but I got a feeling of earnest care for the character for the game. He has no understanding of the world, and the closest thing he has to a father was once a hardcore nazi who backpedeled once he realized what he was doing. The character dynamics are subtle and engaging.

The world itself has a lot of thought put into it. Its certainly not realistic, but it captures the Philip K. ♥♥♥♥ style of a believable fantasy world. There's a sense that this world has aged, even though its new, and that there is a lot of history.

There is also a prison camp scene, and I was worried here. The holocaust is something that has never been touched upon really in gaming, and I was worried that the game's tonal shifts would end up creating a farce but it did a good job. Its a case where I can say it ending with you piloting a nazi mech blasting apart the camp feels appropiate since the entire level is building up to that point. You get the feeling of having to carefully plan and move your way around, and there is this omnipresence of the regime.

And the ending itself is special because it does a good of fleshing out the series' longest lasting Villian, Deathshead. Far from the stoic figure he was in previous games, known for his snark, he is a much more jovial figure. I think the game should have emphasized what the logs only touch upon, that after his near-death in Wolfenstein (2009) he found a new love for life, that he is unhinged in a very different way. He, in own way, views himself as a creator, someone who has used his abilities for the betterment of humanity. And then casts Blaskowitz as the villian in his story, a relic of an old world that can only destroy but cannot create. The line, When the end comes

recommended: not what we have destroyed"\n\nNot saying that Deathshead is right

reviewText:
Pure over-the-top violence meets an old school FPS. A post-WW2 era dominated by nazis with a futurist tone. The game does the little things right: fabricated newspaper clippings of pre/post WW2, cheesy smartass dialogue, and various unique weapons w/ available upgrades.

The Good:

-Upgradable Weapons
-Interesting Setting
-Incredible Graphics

-Viele Deustch!
-First level of the original Wolfenstein is playable

The Bad:

-44gb Download
-No Multiplayer
-Limited Replay Value (about 10 hours per story)
-Repetitve at times

9/10 would buy again.

reviewText:
I enjoyed my time with this game. I'm not totally sure how I feel about it overall. I feel pretty neutral about it tbh.
The tone of the game kept wanting to be, I believe, quite a lot like a Quentin Tarantino movie, but that tone was frequently overshadowed by how serious and grim it was overall. Not enough campiness in my opinion, and not often enough during gameplay, where all the personality often gets thrown out the window in light of worrying about health and armor. The cutscenes and gameplay were way too divorced. The marketing for the game was where the cool factor lived the most, sadly.

Anyway.... the overall difficulty of the game is reasonable, but overall felt too easy, even on 'I am Death Incarnate', and apparently on 'Uber', too. However, if you didn't play a battle decisively, then the game became incredibly tough for that section, especially in the minor spoiler: Train level, where the game introduces you to the SuperSoldaten, and then an entire squad of them all at once.

I'm glad to have played the game though, and it was fun to experiment with the stealth (It is incredibly forgiving, hilariously so when guards constantly mutter suspciously but otherwise raise no alarm or break from their patrol) and then throw the shackles of stealth off, eat 100+ Overcharged HP (health that drains because it is over your maximum) and run a train on fools with dual-wielded shotguns.
It was a parade of gore and blood.

reviewText: Wolfenstein is the stand out game of last year, it wasn't broken like Assassin's Creed and it wasn't a disappointment like Destiny. When every other game at the time was falling short of what it intended to be this game came out and became a shining light for the gaming industry, not because it was a great First Person Shooter (which it was) but because they also integrated a story that was well paced and structured something that many video games fail to do. Although the start of the game is badly done and boring (My god how did that get in the game) it quickly changes and becomes the game I hoped it was, the game that I was waiting for in 2014 that wasn't a dissapointing reck at launch. This is one of the best FPS since Half life 2, it broke the formula that many FPS games have been following for years and gave us something worth while. They went beyond the likes of COD and battlefield and put effort into their story and characters, they made a world that felt real even though it was alternative history. This is my favourite game of last year and the best FPS we've gotten in a long time, do yourself a favour and buy this game.

reviewText:
Really good FPS with sci-fi mechanazis if you're still into singleplayer things, I like how they didn't waste resources to include a mandatory multiplayer side which would be abandoned after 2 weeks. First playthrough took me about 17 hours so all that saved development counts! I don't know if I'd classify it exactly as old-school but it's not the usual modern TV toybox stuff either.

To abuse game comparisons once again, the shooting bits remind me of the Metro games or perhaps the first F.E.A.R.? No slow motion and bullets are lethal, limbs explode and concrete shreds off the walls. Gunplay never got stale through the game and there's plenty of common troopers for satisfying cannon fodder and more tricky enemies who can withstand a beating. There's a lean from cover-function but thankfully it doesn't make the game a wallhugging cover shooter. You're free to do it your way, dualwield big guns and go in badass macho or you can pick off key enemies with stealth (just don't expect to completely ghost the game, stealth is just an initiator here).

There isn't a talent/xp tree in the usual style but you can unlock new traits (mostly small passive bonuses like clip size) by performing certain feats in combat, like kill 20 guys with thrown knives". Most guns also get upgrades which change how they work just enough so you don't get bored with them.

Story- and settingwise it felt like Dishonored

reviewText:
Ok. First I would like to tell you guys im a big fan of Wolfenstein series, I played all of them.
So first il tell you good things about and in this game (+) and bad things in this game (-).
+Very very nice graphics.
+Good storyline only the end isn't so good because BJ dies but its not still confirmed.
+New weapons.
+Many fun ways to kill nazis.
+ Two storylines.
+ Beside RTCW, (Return to castle Wolfenstein) this is the best game of its series.

-The game needs a few updates because many folks cant run this game properly (low FPS, texture pop-outs, no sound, freezing and other graphical issues).
-The game is too short for 45 GB of needed space (I beaten the first storyline in 10 hrs).
-For me it wasn't a big problem because I have 2 TB on my PC but the game needs around 45 GB free space.

Ranting for this game without upcoming updates that will fix graphical and some other issues 8/10 (worth of buying if you like killing nazis or if you re a true Wolfenstein fan).

reviewText:
Remember how shooters used to be about, you know, shooting stuff? I know, it's a ridiculous notion in this day and age, but really, it used to be! Games like Quake, Doom and the orgiginal F.E.A.R., although they might have had some things at the side, were games like that: Focused on fast-paced, tense action where you were a totall badass and blew things up. Another series from that list is the grandfather of all shooters; Wolfenstein. Now Wolfenstein is back, and with it a shooter about shooting.

First off, let me start of with what it does besides shooting - it's better to get the worst out of the way. There is a story. One with lots of cutscenes. One that doesn't offer too much choice (though there is a little bit of choice involved). It's not a bad story - not at all, even - but sometimes it takes itself a little too seriously, even with the subject matter being treated here, and it's definitely not a great story either. It's solid, does its job, but it might be a bit out of place in a Wolfenstein game.

The best thing about the story is the world: An alternative 1960 where Germany won the second world war by using technology stolen from ancient civilizations. It's a bit far fetched, but the world created is extremely interesting: Massive concrete buildings, oppression... It's a dystopian sci-fi fan's dream, really. The enemy, the Nazi's Reich, is portrayed very efficiently: Brutal, inconsiderate, powerful.

Out of this world goodness streams the action. What kind of action? Action with alternate-reality guns. Assault rifles that blow heads off. Shotguns that blow heads off. Really, a bunch of weapons that blow heads (and other limbs) off. Each weapon is an absolute blast to use; they have just enough recoil and the sounds are utterly fantastic. Besides the fact that every weapon can be dual-wielded (even snipers, which is fun), they also have an alternate fire mode that can change the way the gun works entirely. From the rocket launcher on the assault rifle to the laser rifle on the sniper, there's plenty of variation when it concerns weapons.

One of the centerpiece weapons of the game (think Half-Life 2's gravity gun, if a lot less majestic and fun, but then again, who can top the gravity gun?) is the Laserkraftwerk. The first thing you might think is, if there would be a German laser gun, it would indeed bear that name. The second you might think is what it is, anyway? Well, it introduces some interesting mechanics when it comes to cutting through walls, fences and the like. It's a bit gimmicky, but stands out enough to be mentioned.

Oh, and its secondary fire is a railgun. Just saying.

So, all in all, what does Wolfenstein: The New Order offer? It offers a shooter. A damn fine shooter, even, that took me 12 hours to complete and had me giggling like a madman the whole way, at least when I got to shoot stuff. When I didn't, the story did keep me interested, but the action is where it's at, and because of that I can't recommend it enough.

Buy this. It's the finest shooter to release in years.

P.S.: Dual wielding snipers! Just think of the utter overkill! Doesn't it make your mouth water?!

reviewText:
Wolfenstein is back.  After the very disappointing 2009 game I thought the series was done for.  Not only did Bethesda bring it back in style, they showed the world how to make a modern oldschool FPS.  The New Order is fast, over the top, lengthy, and oozes style.

The New Order takes place in an alternate history where the Nazis won WWII.  It has a retro-futuristic vibe with some very advanced technology, but still styled after the time period.  While it is highly implausable, it's a very interesting world to explore and there are lots of newspaper stories scattered throughout the game you can read to learn more about it.  They even went and recorded German versions of classic music to fit in with the alternate history timeline.

The game plays like an amalgamation of the best parts of classic and moderns games, combining fast satisfying gunplay, clever and interesting level design, quality graphics, great story and voice acting, and a long campaign.  You can duel wield shotguns and rocker launchers to fight giant mechanical dogs.  You can even sneak around stealthily and silently stab enemies with your knife.  After all the carnage is done, you still get a great story and voice acting.

Two things I greatly enjoyed about the game that I'd like to point out are the health system which is a hybrid regenerating / non-regenerating health system.  Your health only regenerates up to the next increment of 20 and you have to find health packs to heal any more.  This helps avoid the modern game design trap of having to duck behind cover constantly to regenerate health while also avoiding the oldschool game design trap of finding yourself helpless if you take too much damage.  The other element I wanted to point out is the almost complete lack of quicktime events (I believe there are two in the whole game.)  At least one developer realizes how terrible they are.

The only drawback I found with the game is the difficulty.  Even on Über difficulty the majority of enemies don't hit very hard and there are tons of health packs around.  The only really dangerous ones are the heavily-armored shotgun-wielding troopers because they have ricocheting ammunition that's nearly impossible to avoid.  There are a few special unlockable game modes however, some of which will offer a larger challenge for those who want it.

The other issue which may concern some people is that this game runs on the id Tech 5 engine, and hence is very prone to texture popping.  The textures are much higher quality than in RAGE however so don't expect a big blur of compression artifacts when looking at objects up close.  I also experienced pretty serious stuttering if I dropped below 60 fps but it wasn't too difficult to keep the game at 60 on my system.

I heartily recommend Wolfenstein The New Order.  It's the most fun I've had with an FPS in quite some time and well worth playing.  I hope it serves as an example to other developers and publishers on how to make an FPS.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein The New Order is easily one of the best single-player First-Person Shooters ever made. Taking place in an alternate timeline World War II New Order tells a dark and brooding tale about survival and resistance against impossible odds as you take the role of legendary hero BJ Blazkowicz. What really makes this game shine is it's attention to detail, fantastic cinematic storytelling, and deep characters that feel almost alive. New Order also features great gunplay, a variety of enemies, and superb graphics that all come together to make one hell of a package.

PROS:
+ Has Characters you actually care about.
+ Fantastic graphics.
+ Well written, gripping and emotional story.
+ Suprisingly decent enemy AI
+ Amazingly detailed & Varied environments.
+ You get to kill Nazis, duh.

CONS:
- Singleplayer only
- May be offensive to Nazis, Feminists, and Angry bald men.

BOTTOM LINE:
Call of Duty gets wet dreams wishing it could be this good. It has an amazing story, great setpieces, and three-dimensional characters. What more do you want in an FPS game? Bottom line, It delivers, and it's an example more games in the genre should follow.

Outstanding 10/10

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cioV2gINXkY
SPOILER WARNING! In order for me to give you a in depth review I must spoil a few things but note this will not spoil the entire game for you.
Where to begin words really can not describe how much I love this game, But I will try for you all.

1 Originality Factor:  Machine games has done a great job keeping it old school just like the old Wolfenstein we all know & love whilst also adding in some new age style to it as well with a new perks system this game really feels like a old school shooter from the 90's.

2 Game Play & Mechanics: There are two different ways to play this game through most of it. You can run & gun all day long make lots of noise with HUGE! guns & let mayhem & carnage reign supreme or you can take the semi new addition stealth sneak up behind the enemy kill the commander before he has time to call in Reinforcements The stealth element is surprisingly well done and the kills are extremely satisfying. (Much better then metro last lights stealth elements) The game allows you to chose which play style you like. Mechanics wise there are perks that can be unlocked to provide bonuses, such as faster reloads and greater magazine capacity etc. The perks can be useful but aren't really needed in this game.

3 Artificial Intelligence: The AI is no dummy in this game a single gun shot or the wrong step or noise can set off a alarm screwing your entire stealthy tatics not to mention if they hear a dog attack they know you're there & if you're playing run & gun you'll find yourself restarting a little more then anticipated because they will actually go looking for you if they know you're there once a alarm has been tripped they are on alert. It's not the best AI I've ever seen but machine games did a very good job at making the game difficult but enjoyable.

4 In Game Options:  The in game visual options are sadly a tad bit lacking with only a few options these would be Graphics Quality, VT Cache Size, VT Compress, MAX PPF, Shadow Resolution, Deapth Of Field which can't be turned entirely off, Screen Spaced Reflection, Additional Quality Settings & Haze Flare & A FOV slider, Very simple but they get the job done. You can't bind 1 key to lean left or right which is sad but you do get a toggle lean which allows you to look up & over down & about or left & right it takes some getting used tro but it's not actually that bad. The rest is very simple key bindings resolution & sadly no audio controls except for master volume it would have been nice to be able to force the game to run in surrounf instead of what windows runs default but hey again it gets the job done & it's nothing that really effects game play.

5 Stealth:  Now for some this is a touchy subject many people have said It looks like metro last lights stealth" well yes & no its no splinter cell or thief game
date: But you can't just kill somebody right in front of another AI enemy whilst their back is turned because if the two enemies are cloes together or within their peripheral vision they will notice it so stealth is a bit touchy in this game but it does a great job with it. It's actually pretty hard to do stealth on uber mode & it does a much better job then metro last lights stealth elements.\n\n6 Weapons:  Everything from Unreal Tournament's flak cannon to underslung rockets on your assault rifles this games gun play is beyond satisfying dual wielding Unreal Tournament's flak cannons? HELL YES!!!! the guns are loud
recommended: proud & HUGE! just like you would expect in a 1990's shooter. Weapon upgrades can be found throughout the game's levels & each one of them offering something fun.\n\n7 The World & It's Story: Visually this game surprised me the graphics of the world are compelling & lots of atmosphere especially the moon level visually again the textures are very good I don't think I have seen a single texture over used all be it not the best graphics but definitely better then a lot of games these days. Trapped in a vegetative state for 14 years
hoursPlayed: Wolfenstein hero B.J. Blazkowicz awakens to a 1960 dominated by Nazis and a life no-longer solely defined by the killing of them. A alternate history reality where nazis won world war 2. The story is very compelling & it gets you hooked in imediately especially if you're a scifi nut and/or history nut I don't want to ruin much but the ending is sad.\n\n8 The Characters & BJ's Relationshhips With Them: I can't help but feel drawn into the world of wolfenstein the new order because of the way the characters react to you & what's going on around them there is just a lot of emotion between you & all the others lots of sadness lots of love lots of hatred & anger. New characters introduced just in time to die tragically

reviewText:
That was absolutely superb.  If you still enjoy single-player shooters in the year of our Lord 2014, this is absolutely worth your time.  It's really nicely varied, with just a few dud levels.  Most levels have a great blend of sneaking around (if you're so inclined) and picking off commanders (which has gameplay consequences) until you ♥♥♥♥ everything up and the ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan.  Then you're running between pieces of cover, gunning down scores of enemies, switching between weapons for different enemies...it all looks and feels just right.

The big surprise is that the introspective moments are, well, 1) there at all.  Introspection in a Wolfenstein game?  And 2) handled really well.  It's a ludicrous game - I killed 815 Nazis across the campaign, escaping death in cutscenes about 30 times - but the human moments they included actually work pretty well.

Wolfenstein feels both fresh AND nostalgic for the run around and kill a zillion nazis" gameplay of the original.  I'm not sure how the ex-Starbreeze guys pulled that off in a Wolfenstein game of all things
date: but the end result is fantastic.  I cannot wait to see their next game.\n\nHaving said that
recommended:
it will be on cell phones with a million microtransactions.



*There are some genuinely gruesome moments

reviewText:
Having been a fan of the Wolfenstein series from the beginning, I was really excited when this game was announced as I had a lot of fun playing Wolfenstein '09. I had almost no fun playing this one.

PROS:

- A cool premise for continuing the franchise.

CONS:

- Abyssmal level designs throughout. Run through corridors until you get to an open area, usually circular and repeat. There are only a couple of exceptions to this layout, one being a destroyed train amidst the rubble of a bridge which is actually the only level I semi-enjoyed.

- You go to the moon to fight Nazi's, super cool idea, but you only get to play on the actual moon for a minute and then you only have a few flying drones you can take down and then you're back into another corridor.

- Not one but two horrible sex scenes that are so out of place, they're ridiculous. Did this game really need that? Nope. It cheapens the series.

-Tries too hard to be deep" BJ's ramblings made me want the Nazi's to win

- Missed opportunities. The moment you're going to town in a mech suit is cool but you're in a confined space and it's over as soon as it begins.

- Tedious one man submarine sequence. It felt tacked on as did all the underwater stuff.

- Scavenger hunts. I understand in a FPS wanting to slow things down but at least it can be a fun diversion. I would have rather had the option to play with crayons and draw something in dum-dum's room than to look for crap for all these lazy NPC's.

At the end of the day
hoursPlayed: a HUGE disappointment because it does nothing exceptional or outstanding and doesn't introduce anything really new or interesting into the genre or franchise. There are some cool ideas but they're squandered aimlessly and
voteText: at the end of it all

there's just nothing memorable or even good about it.

4 out of 10

reviewText:
I'm late to the Nazi killing party but if you would like a very well done FPS about killing a whole lot of Nazis in alternate history 1960 then this is your game.  I killed 841 Nazis in one playthrough.

The graphics are very detailed, which is excellent for conveying the fidelity of your Nazi stabbing, shooting, dismembering, etc.  The story is a little incoherent, but I think they were going for that, and anyway the only story that matters is here's an army of Nazis we need them not alive anymore, you in?  The level design is rather refreshing, as lately shooters have trained me to only move straight down one particular hallway to a specific goal.  Wolfenstein has plenty of hallways - and they're all full of Nazis in need of immediate decimation - but there's plenty of other areas with more open maps, multiple paths of approach, stealth vs. loud, and so on.  If you have a preferred method of exacting fantasy revenge on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 20th century regime (i.e. Nazis) it's in here for you. The upgrade system is well done, as perks unlock due to specific achievements in Nazi-killing prowess, thus rewarding you in 10-25% upgrades in Nazi-disembowling efficiency.

Looking forward to Wolfentein: The Old Blood.  This game definitely needed a prequel, as I don't feel like I've really exacted the totality of my fantasy revenge on the Nazis just yet.  Another 500 or so kills ought to do it, for this year at least.

reviewText:
Great game.

The campaign took me about 9 hours to complete, and there are two timelines (although I'm not sure how different they are). Combine that with collectable finding, secrets, etc, and I think you'd get a pretty good amount of replay value if you're into that sort of thing.

The graphics and sound are excellent, and the story is very well written and acted. The entire presentation is top notch. Great characterization and human moments.

Really, everything about this game is great. I'm happy to see a single-player only FPS get so much attention and praise.

reviewText:
I've played all of the games with the Wolfenstein moniker and this game shattered my expectations in every way.

Gameplay is engaging and satisfying whether you want to go stealth or guns blazing. Veterans to stealth may find the skulking about to be a bit easy though. Veterans to this brand of shooters will find a fair challenge. I say this after playing the first time on the I am Death Incarnate" difficulty and I make a habit of slaughtering UT2K4 godlike bots.

The story was leaps and bounds above standard. BJ is a complex and dynamic character as are many of his co-stars.  Blew my mind! And while it keeps the traditional Wolfenstein wackiness
date: the writing makes an incredible amount of sense.\n\nThe only bad thing I have to say about the game is that the context-based cover system can be finicky. It's nothing game breaking
recommended: just a bit annoying at times when you might be trying to peek out in a certain direction and not others.\n\nStill
hoursPlayed: this is one of the few times I can say triple-A did a genuinely good job. Great stuff and I hope they keep this level of quality at id Software."

reviewText:
the Good:  - graphics, gameplay, sound, story, characters

the Bad:  - the stealth approach is not well done, clicking on every piece of armor/heath/ammo I want to pick up

the Ugly:  - a world governed by nazi extremists

This felt like an over-the-top Hollywood action movie in which the player controls the action scenes.  The combat is fun, the world feels dangerous, and I found myself caring about the characters (and wanting to stop the villains) throughout.  The stealth-specific sections were lame because the enemies conveniently carried only melee weapons.  Those were the only few parts of the game where I felt like I was in no real danger.

Shooting, stabbing, strangling Nazis for 9 hours straight.

And that's not all!

In addition, great cinematics, on of the greatest storylines in fps games and awesome score!
One major con is that sometimes gameplay feels not very connected to the story. For example, our main hero reflects on war horrors, thinks about young lads dying on that war... All in all, great experience. 9/10

reviewText:
First off, you better have a good internet connection, or get this on disc.  Because this game is huge.  Apparently the devs do not know what compression is.

That is my only gripe about Wolfenstein: The New Order.

The rest of it, dare I say, is fun.  Really fun.  It is a solid FPS and is very welcome in the age of bland FPS games that are poorly written and rip off other artists' graphical styles.  The weapons handle well, kills are satisfying, and you have a health bar, which hearkens back to the old retro FPS games like, well, Wolfenstein.  While some of the things like the slide mechanic and the cover system took some getting used to, they work.  Even though I mainly used the cover system to farm kills for the weapon upgrades you get from killing enemies from cover.

The stealth mechanic works too, nowhere near as good as something like Metal Gear, but I like to think that the Nazi AI is intentionally stupid to show how complacent they have become after their victory.  Which leads me to another point.

The Worldbuilding.

It's great.  You can tell that there has been some serious effort put into the worldbuilding of this game.  From the diary entries of one of the main character's cousins after the victory, to just looking around and seeing how different this world looks, it is all very well done.  In the fascist-industrialist way, the Nazis have built and rebuilt massive cities over oceans of concrete.  Propaganda speakers spout information about the greatness of National Socalism along with the weather report.  The military has a retro futuristic look along the lines of Fallout.  Giant robots with lasers, troops in power armor, laser weapons.  It's all ♥♥♥♥in' great.  Hell, even The Beatles songs are in German.

This is a solid game with solid worldbuilding and fantastic gameplay.  Definitely get it if it's on sale.

reviewText:
What is it?Wolfenstein: The New Order isl a full-on action first-person shooter.  The backdrop of the game is post WWII era starting around 1946 and ending up in the 1960s, where an alternative outcome was a Nazi victory.  It's all a little bit silly and overdone, but the game never really takes itself too seriously...

GameplayThe game has an incredible array of weaponry and next to no realism whatsoever - making it a lot of fun!  Yes, you can somehow carry with ease an arsenal of weaponry that probably wouldn't fit into your garage, but what the heck!  Raw FPS action with a story and characters that matter too.  For the most part, ammo is plentiful and you will feel more like a bullet-hose on steroids.  The level of difficulty is strong without ever feeling too impossible and you feel that you accomplished each part of the mission rather than success being an inevitability.

The good...Players are given choice (stealth is often an option).  Mostly though, you will be in the thick of things laying down a carpet of weapon-fire and it's here the game excels.  It has lots of different set pieces, including under-water, train, submarine and even a short lunar walk.  The story is of course far-fetched and silly but the non-playable characters have personality.  Controls are minimal (yay!), and both keyboard/mouse and controllers are supported (with hot-switching between the two).

Despite (as usual) having to play as white dude with muscles the size of Rambo, this game includes a better mix of characters than many of its ilk, and places women AND disabled people (yes, that's PLURAL disabled people) in equal stature to men in the game.  It's something seen so very rarely and yet no reviews seem to have picked up on it which is a shame - so major kudos is deserved here.


The bad...The graphics are fine but not epic by today's standards and level of detail (especially distance texturing) looks a little more dated than its 2014 date suggests.  You will probably need to force anti-aliasing through your GPU's driver software as the game's graphics settings didn't seem to remove jaggies.  Some cut-scenes are choppy but that seems to be a common-place problem in many games.    Some maps are a little too linear and there are occasional but irritating points of no return.  Likewise, side missions must be completed whenever they become available; do something else, like sleep" or play the next part of the story
date: and the side missions are often gone forever (even if the story returns you to the exact same location).\n\nThere are a couple of controller mechanics in the game that are frustrating (the speed-slide being the worst
recommended: needing a combination of 2-3 keys/buttons pressed while simulateously controlling direction)
hoursPlayed:
and these caused a little unnecessary frustration in a couple of places.  You are unable to save your current position (the game uses checkpoint-saves).


And the ugly...Pretty much every German-speaking character is a Nazi.  Now
voteText: I'm English and that bugs me
helpfulPercent: but I'm sure if I were German I would be totally offended by that as it does nothing to remove Germany from that hideous black spectre of Nazism.  There is an inexplicable 'concentration camp' mission where it is your role to free all the prisoners but this really seemed to trivialise such a location and I feel it would have been better in a more generic prison or labour camp setting.  'Freeing all the prisoners' from this camp came down to stomping around in a mech suit gunning down Nazis
votesHelpful: after which 'ALL the prisoners' were notably just 6 NPCs who were seen to leave
votesTotal: hardly giving the player the feeling of liberation of the masses!   This
votesFunny: and a bit of weird sci-fi 'mystery secret technologies hundreds of years old' weren't the highlights of the story exactly
commentsCount: but it IS fantasy at the end of the day
column16: and fantasy has no 'must be plausible' rule.\n\nConclusionWolfenstein: The New Order is a highly enjoyable FPS with both story and character.  The story might not be uber-realistic
column17: but I don't think it tries to be.  Instead
column18: the player is treated to a feast of weaponry and enemies to use them on.  This is a game that proves it hasn't forgotten where the true fun lay in its spiritual predecessors of 1981 and 1992.  If you enjoy full-on FPS action
column19: then you will enjoy this game."

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AQRPm0xVaEY
Above is my impressions on the game.

Wolfenstein the New Order is a no frill action FPS. There actually hasn't been many action FPSs to of come out the last year or more, and Wolfenstein is a great return to form. It does a pretty descent job of mixing some old school mechanics, while modernizing it with new school FPS tropes.

The story and stealth is a little weak, but the gun play, the turret and vehicle segments, and the pacing of the game is top notch, some of the best I've played for a while.

Overall, the game is well worth the asking price, and just a lot of fun shooting the ♥♥♥♥ out of Nazis.

Pros:
- Duel wielding mechanic is fun and balanced
- Fantastic gun play and pacing
- Turrets and vehicle segments are actually really fun and not filler!
- Shoot Nazis

Cons:
- Stealth and story very lack luster
- Could use more variety in guns
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Finally, a game that truly feels oldschool. I love how much effort was put into the singleplayer because the devs concentrated solely on it, leaving out the multiplayer.
The story is pretty intriguing (if not too complex) and the length of it is also pretty damn high for a linear game. Took me about 25 hours to complete it on easy difficulty while taking my time to explore the enviroment (which is made up beautifully, every little sign or poster is worth reading).
The gameplay itself? True oldschool shooter with no regenerating health, armor, all kinds of dakka, most of which you can dual wield for even more carnage. Blowing limbs off is not uncommon and generally the whole game has that special feel that you rarely see these days if you do at all.
Of course, there is no oldschool FPS without hidden areas and items, right? That's right, the devs didn't forget about that either. Lots of stuff to discover and find, you can solve puzzles with the stuff gained from exploration (which I did not complete yet, so I can't have an opinion on it).

All in all, if you loved the FPS games of the past decade, you will really appreciate this one :)

Now get out there and rip 'em a new one. Those nazis won't kill themselves, right? >D

reviewText: Seriously worth your money... Didn't kill enough Nazis in the '40s? Well take them on in the swinging 60's (mit more deutsches musiks) [I'm sorry I'm terrible at German]. Anyway, the game has some flaws, a lack of multiplayer or co-op, but this is made up for with a fantastic albeit slightly too incredible to believe campaign, but its still a barrel of fun (or in this case dual wield automatic shotgun with shrapnel ammo). The game has a nice balance of stealth and action, one minute you may be sneaking up behind a nazi officer wielding two knives and the next lobbing grenades and shooting lasers at nazis as though there's no tomorrow. Another thing to mention is that the story has two storylines and warrants a second and even third playthough if you wish to achieve 100% completion.\n\nI would strongly reccomend this game, it is perhaps the best FPS of this year so far!

column20: ammo and health lying around even on the highest setting to be called "Über".\n\nThen again
column21: the big armoured robots and special troopers can still kill you in a couple of seconds from full health and armour if you're not careful and take cover. The large amount of equipment also helps in avoiding a situation where you became stuck because of too little health. By the way
column22: there is no manual saving
column23:
only predetermined saving spots in each level.

Getting stronger and ninja-er
Blazkowicz gets "perks" to become more capable by completing various weapon-based challenges. True to this age
column24: many scenes or even full missions can be completed either guns blazing or through stealth and sneaking.\n\nStealth is done rather well for FPS: enemies can see you from far instead of being totally shortsighted
column25: they can see bodies (unfortunately they can't be moved) and raise alarm to call in reinforcements. They obviously hear gunshots. It's just odd that when stealthing
column26: even a single thrown knife to the knee or toe will kill any armoured soldier.\n\nThe integrated blowtorch/laser gun deserves a special mention. Blowtorch is integral to progress in The New Order: it's used to break through wired cages
column27: iron chains and metal panels. The holes you cut will be just like you cut them
column28:
a rather cool detail.

Once upon a time in an alternate history
Actually
column29: I'm having hard time deciding whether the action or the adventure portion of the game has been done better. So great is the story
column30:
the dialogue and the setting of the reimagined world.

The New Order tells many touching and powerful stories within a single game. The atrocities of Nazis are showcased in horrifying fashion. There are all these bits and pieces of intriguing made-up history hidden within the game.

It's interesting that in the very beginning chapter you're forced to make a decision as to who lives or dies and this plays throughout the game as two separate timelines
column31: with small details like people changing in due course.\n\nThe characters and their destinies are intriguing
column32: well-thought and memorable. That goes both for your allies and the antagonists. Both sexes are involved in both good and evil. The personalities and destinies of your allies are good and relatable and sometimes harsh and intense. There's even a carefree romance thrown into the mix.\n\nOne of the most powerful events is the scene of an old lady furiously yet weakly slapping the face of a Nazi scum responsible for killing their child. I'll remember that a long time
column33: that's how powerful I thought it was.\n\nThe game is littered with instances like this. They are even more obvious after a playthrough or two
column34: when you've got yourself conveniently and painfully attached to the characters.\n\nThe antagonists are especially well done. If you feel genuine hatred
column35: disgust and/or horror for them and time after time that feeling only intensifies
column36: you know they have succeeded as antagonists.\n\nWhile the cruel prison commandant Frau Engel is scary and absolutely despicable person
column37: Deathshead is still an excellent main antagonist. He's shown to be pretty much insane and horrifyingly sadistic person monster. If not at first
column38:
at least in the second playthrough I just felt about blasting his smirking face when he first appears behind the bulletproof glass in the first episode.

Conclusions
I claim that The New Order is one of the best FPS shooters of the decade. It looks beautiful
column39: it's technically a masterpiece and it excels in story like no FPS before. It only lacks a multiplayer but frankly
column40: it was probably good that they focused on the awesome single player experience instead of forcing in a generic multiplayer.\n\nThere's a nice amount of replay value. With the two different timelines
column41: I played it 41 hours and about 4 times through before I had found all the collectables
column42: cracked the enigma codes (ultimately with a bit of online help though) and so acquired all achievements. Enigma codes unlock special gameplay modes like god mode and one-life mode
column43: which adds another layer of challenge if one wants it.\n\nUnlike usually with single-player games that I play through 100%
column44: I will probably return to play this again for the story. Consequentially
column45: I would recommend Wolfenstein: The New Order even at full price but since it's 2-year old game you can get it super-cheap at a sale. Economically speaking I suggest you wait for one. Then treat yourself to this sweet."

reviewText:
Wolfenstein – The New Order is the latest instalment of the Wolfenstein Franchise.
I have been playing the Wolfenstein games since the Wolfenstein 3D era.
Someone who liked the previous games and the game style will absolutely love this new game.

Story:
As always you play B.J." Blazkowicz but this time the story is set in an alternate reality. It’s 1960 and the Nazi’s won the war. The story of this game is well written and well-acted.

Game:
The game is only single player
date: there is no multi player. But that’s a good thing so the developers good focus all their attention to the single player game. Unlike a lot of games these days where single player is neglected.\nIt’s a fast action fps in true Wolfenstein style. Graphics and sound are impressive; it’s based on the id-tech engine (like Rage). The story unfolds via in engine cut scene’s. It’s impressive how much detail they put in the story telling.\nThe game can graphically be tweaked a lot
recommended:
there are a of options that can influence you’re fps. So it’s important to read some of the guides if you have trouble running it.
I can confirm it also runs on ultra-wide screens 21:9 aspect ratio and a resolution of 2560*1080 without problems.
For those who have never played the original Wolfenstein 3D – the game that started the fps-genre – level 1 is hidden somewhere in the game.

This is a must for everyone’s game collection!
Highly recommended!
"

reviewText:
I must admit that I have enjoyed this game, even if it is kinda too short for the money it costs. I mean I've finished it in less than 15 hours, though I did only one timeline. I will try other one as well. Story was pretty decent, I have really enjoyed alternate history, didn't like kinda forced love story though. I liked weapons in this game, and for some reason I have really enjoyed using mouse3 :) Levels were fine, pretty linear, which I don't find bad with games like this. The final boss was pretty easy in my opinion to be honest, I would definitely change that a bit, make it more challenging.  I see that people were complaining about graphics, I didn't have any issues, and i find graphics really nice, especially in cut-scenes.
also Wolfenstein: The New Order includes nostalgic Easter Eggs carrying the player back to the first days of 3D first-person gaming. That was instant travel to the childhood <3

All in all, pretty good FPS. Though I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price. In my opinion, even if it is good, 15 hours is not worth of 50€. But if you find it on a sale or in some bundle, definitely go for it.

reviewText:
I've never been so immersed in a Video Game since playing Bioshock Infinite. The story is so excellently paced and gripping that i found it extremely hard to stop playing. As a linear FPS i feel that Machine Games did a good job in not making you feel claustrophobic while playing. There's a number of paths you can take and playstyles you can play to reach your objective.

Do you want to avoid confrontation and stealthily kill your enemies? Or do you want to go Rambo mode and decimate everything? It's entirely up to you.

There's a whole arsenal of weaponry that you can use including dual wield and a simple but effective perk system that revolves around your playstyle.

With a whole bunch of collectibles to get and game modes to unlock, there's definitely some replayability value here.

So what are you waiting for?

reviewText:
So I just finished the game, and I can't say I didn't like it.  The game really gets you involved, almost indebted to the characters so that you just want to play more and more.  The story line is great, and I don't think anyone will tell you otherwise.  In all the games I've ever played with campaigns, this one, while not the most grandiose or beautiful, is the most incredible.  I don't want to say anything else; if you like good story telling, this is the game for you.

The game play is actually pretty good.  The guns and animations handle just like doom 3, which is to be expected because that engine is ID's bread and butter.  This is not a bad thing, in fact the weapons were quite fun to shoot and each carried with them their own set of uses, pros and cons.  The visuals left a lot to be desired, however.  Doom 3 was the bleeding edge for gaming back in the day, and unfortunately Wolfenstein is not on par with what I would expect from such a big budget title.  They used some sort of blurring effects on things that were far away (or even not so far away).  Even with draw distance maxed out, it didn't seem to matter.  This of course could be an issue with my machine, but it was worth mentioning  that I had trouble tuning this issue out.  The game is also locked in a 60 fps, thanks to IDtec9.  I am a strong believer that in this day and age 60 fps should not be something that we as PC gamers need to settle on.  But I digress.  The game itself does not feel repetitive.  You aren't mowing down endless hordes of the same enemies.  As we would expect from ID, there is somewhat of a diversity in baddies, but I felt it could be more exhaustive.  However, this is only because I hold ID to such a standard.  The stealth parts are A+.  Seriously, in most stealth games, if you are spotted then its game over.  If you are sneaking up on an enemy, and you anticipate that he is going to see you, you can sprint up to him and assasinate him before he finishes calling you out and not break your stealth.  Really, this is awesome and stealth games that are in development should take note. In the event that you lose your stealth, its not really that big of a deal.  A sizable number of reinforcements are called in, and when you take care of them, you move on.  Since the gunplay is actually pretty good, you may even find yourself making no attempt to be stealthy just to be able to waste a few more Nazis.

Would I recommend that you pay $60 for this game?  No.  Simply because no game with only a single player mode should carry this value.  Because the weapons are so much fun to shoot, I wish there was a multiplayer option.  Doom 3 did not have an amazing multiplayer, but they at least attempted it.  I am the type of person who doesn't play a game twice, and even though I'm only 44% Complete
date: I got my enjoyment and I'm ready to move on.  I came here because I played the original Castle Wolfenstein and Doom games on my windows 95 machine as a kid, and I'm happy to see this title on a game of this magnitude.  I hope for more in the future.

reviewText:
The perfect mix of old-school and new-school FPS. Wolfenstein The New Order has a great story, great German voice actors, good character development and solid visuals. The shooting aspects are strong and the game flows well. Semi-linear with areas to explore, and collect gear/ammo/collectibles/etc.


The game features an interesting way of gaining skills, having to complete certain challenges that vary in difficulty which grant permenant perks throughout your playthrough.
There is no multiplayer, which could be seen as a plus, as they put all their work into creating the best single-player campaign they could possibly do.


Overall I am mega impressed by this game. If you were a fan of the older Wolfenstein games, this is a some-what-continuation of Return to Castle Wolfenstein, and Wolfenstein(2009) and I highly suggest you play The New Order! For newer fans who never experienced Wolfenstein, The New Order is still a great standalone title. You may not understand some of the smaller intricacies and minor character reunions but the game does well enough on it's own to explain that so you won't be left in the dark.


Get it get it get it get it!

reviewText:
A hallmark of classic game design. Wolfenstein: The New Order isnt bogged down by modern game mechanics and can stand as a true successor to the original Wolfenstein 3D. If you love classic shooters like Wolfenstein 3D or Half-Life 2, this is probably for you. The dual-weilding/alt-fire mode of the weapons is incredibly enjoyable, and provides a formidable arsenal against the hoards of mecha-future Nazis you will gleefuly gib, splatter, stab, explode and otherwise maim. Howver, I would level that the lazor weapon is relied on too much by the designers as a kill stick for higher calibre enemies, and as a result your traditional stockpile of arms can feel neglected. The game unlike a majority of other moder shooters does not include a multiplayer component, but I never felt anything was lost from a lack of it. Rather the resources that would have gone towards the multiplayer were directed into the single-player campaign. Locations varied as castles, U-boats and even moonbases serve to clearly distinguish the levels, much like an old NES game would.The game also features a plethora of collectibles including Nazi gold, code fragments, diary entries and even records parodying music of the 50s and 60s in a New Regime style to great effect.
While the game does have an abundance of cutscenes, they were never too much of a distraction from the general action of the main story, and provided B.J. a sense of characterization and depth usually unseen in the traditional meat-headed guntoter. Machine Games did an excellent job of creating dispicable Nazi heads you would love to plow through hundreds of their subordinates to eliminate. Sadly the chance to deliver such sweet justice by your hand is denied. The supporting cast is similarly developed well enough to gain your alligiance but is not seen as much. This should stand as a crime: the allied cast simply does not get enough screen time or even backstory to fill my desire to know more about them.


Overall Wolfenstein: The New Order comes out as a highly enjoyable FPS romp through a dystopian future-past which will leave your smiling face coated in Nazi blood.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order was everything I could have wanted from a single-player focused first person shooter. The story was engaging and ramped at appropriate moments, and the pacing seems to take some inspiration from movies in where the plot gets shoved along in things that wouldn't be as interesting to get to the good parts. The story takes some leaps of faith when doing Tarantino transitions, but honestly they are shorter leaps of faith than what the player had to do in some levels.  It works; Wolfenstein is long without many noticeable lulls and offers a lot of options in each level when it comes to branching paths (some of which are dependant on what you did in the first chapter).

The writing is pretty good for what I was expecting. Some characters are developed more than others, but for how many people get thrown in the mix there's a decent balance. The scope of what occurs during the game is huge, to say the least.

The game features some light stealth mechanics that are simple, but work. They are by no means advanced, but they get the job done and allow you to complete objectives without being seen if player agency wills it. The combat itself is solid, and harkens back to the unlimited weapon inventories of Wolfenstein, in which there's less weapons overall, but you're carrying all of them at once. Every weapon can be dual-wielded, with the exception of turret weapons, grenades, and weapons you only possess one of. There's a decent cover system, and all weapons have some alternate function.

The game features a lot of puzzles or situations featuring the cutting tool, which is a game mechanic to saw through chain link fences and thin metal plates to get into different areas or open some containers. The plates even act as cover against most weapons, except for laser turrets (they chew through them). In a way, it's Wolfenstein's gravity gun. It's interesting to use, and the tool gets upgraded multiple times, even becoming a capable weapon in its own right.

There's a level of detail regarding the world that is excellent. Everything is controlled by the Nazi regime, even pop culture. The level of technology over the time span was also interesting to see in concert with the totalitarian government control. Poking around and listening to dialog gives a bit of insight into just how twisted the world has become.

There were some graphical glitches and pop-in textures, but aside from that, there wasn't really anything detrimental to my overall experience with the game. The game was a blast and ended with a bang, faithful to the source material to the end.

The story of this game is simple but still interesting, it has a solid gameplay with many different weapons to choose from in which you can also dual wield (Now that's awesome) secret areas with items such as gold, letters and enigma codes that you can unlock to get different play modes that will enchance your playthroughs.

I give it 8.5/10 Points. :D

reviewText:
Short and concrete!
This game was actually better than what I expected it to be.

Gameplay is just alright. Music is okay. Secrets and bonuses are AMAZING. (Thank you ID for that fan-service..)
The story is very touching. But that is to be expected as it is a.. WWII-ish game, except alot more darker because the Nazi's now control the damn world.

Now, the cons
I haven't finished it, so mind this.

The lack of gun variety. (I thought there would be more Allied arsenal, really.)
Linear-ity! (What's up with all these locked doors , man? What's this.. Resident Evil?)
Pop-in textures like in RAGE. (This angers many people. But I believe it's a problem AMD has with drivers and stuff. It'll probably be patched.. hopefully.)
In my opinion.. I found this game to be ridiculously easy. But maybe that's just me, or all the medikits and armor lying around, or the kinda broken AI.


8.5/10 - This ID Software-drone recommends this to any avid FPS lover. One of the best releases this year.

reviewText: Now i have quite a few hours on this game, and i have beaten the game on Uber. This game is very good if you like story-based Single Player shooters. If you're a fan of multiplayer, you might wanna steer clear of this game. Or just get over it and play the Single Player. The characters are great, the story is alright, shooting nazis is fun as hell, and it's just a good time overall. There are a bunch of collectables hidden around if you care to find 'em.\nBasically if you like Single Player and shooting Nazi's, or if you were a fan of Wolfenstein back in the day, then go pick this up. Or go pick up The Old Blood, which is considerably cheaper. Either one's good.

reviewText:
If you're into old school shooter games then this game is for you!

The story of this game is simple but still interesting, it has a solid gameplay with many different weapons to choose from in which you can also dual wield (Now that's awesome) secret areas with items such as gold, letters and enigma codes that you can unlock to get different play modes that will enchance your playthroughs.

It took me about 12 hours to finish the game which includes looking for secret areas and items, otherwise I'd probably finish it under...say 8-9 hours? Anyways there are 2 timelines, so if you are to finish the other one than you have one more timeline to go through that will extend your playtime, although these timelines are not so different from each  other than few new characters and dialog.

I give it 8.5/10 Points. :D

reviewText:
As usual, Bethesda never disappoints me, including this game. I feel hard to stop playing the game once indulging myself in its world. Here's my summary below.

Good:

1. graphic visual

2. very sastisfactory sense of shooting

3. very intriguing story and it also has strong emotional impacts.

4. novel perktrees.

5. various silent takedown movements

6. well-hidden objects. You'll probably miss lots of them without these hint marks on the map. And even if you read the map and know there's something around, sometimes it's really challenging to find them, but it's still manageable after hard thinking, and your efforts won't go unrewarded, since these loots are useful and even unique. I even had a sense of achievement once after I successfully find the loots.

7. monologue fits each situation extremely well. It's not like I am playing as some character, but I AM Blaskowicz himself.

8. Very suble tutorial. Unlike some games that just tell you press sth. to do sth, the tutorial is situational based. You will know what I am talking about once you start playing the game.

Insufficient:

1. Too easy combats, even under Uber(hardest), as long as you don't rush into crowd, and  just take out enemies one by one instead.

2. Linear missions and maps, not open world, unsatisfatory sense of exploration. Once you turn in missions related to main story, these side missions are gone.

3. v-sync toggle useless. It's alway 60 FPS for me somehow. It's an FPS and there's a diffreence beween 60 and 120 FPS. Others with good gear might also feel this way.

Others:

I used to categorized the following into the more insufficient kind, but now I've changed my mind and think it suits the game background well.

Sometimes unclear waypoints, and the lack of minimap on HUD also exacerbates the issue. The combination of these two is a real pain for someone who's used to games like Borderlands 2. Relying on your instinct might be more convenient sometimes.

Reason:

In short, it enhances role play experience. Blaskowicz is an American agent trying to infiltrate various German buildings, not a Nazi architect. He's supposed to be somewhat unfamiliar with these interiors, even with the assistance from maps. So it doesn't matter how good his sense of direction is, there isn't any known waypoint in his head except these maps. There's no way for him to immediately know EXACTLY which is where. The rest only relies on his direction instinct (transferred to player's instinct). Some necessary but manageable explorations also strengthen this dangerous and undertermined atmosphere of overall gameplay. Not sure if Bethesda did this on purpose for better role play experience or just omitted this.

The gold's functionality is still unknown even after my first playthrough. But overall, it's a very decent game and is worth your time and money. Althought it's an FPS game, but keep in mind that stealth is really important, like silent takedown and throwing knives, and direct confrontation often is not your best choice, especially under Uber (hardest). BTW, it's really funny that the greenhorn said thank you
date: sir" even if I slapped him in the face. It would be even more funny if he could ♥♥♥♥/piss his pant! LOL!"
