reviewText: This game is very pretty, first of all. The HP system isn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like most new shooters, it's nice and old-fashioned. The gunplay in this game is amazing. The gun sounds (and all the other sounds for that matter) were very well-engineered. Not only that, but the gibs and blood effects when shooting enemies are incredibly satisfying, something which is apparently very hard to accomplish in modern shooters these days. The game has a few cool Wolfenstein 3D references I've found, and in general, there are lots of nice Easter eggs to find. The game, despite what you may expect from a story that revolves around the Nazis winning WWII, is very funny. It's purposely cheesy throughout with the super-American B.J. Blaskowicz (the same one from the canon Wolfenstein 3D) and it's rad as hell. The developers clearly worked hard and had lots of fun doing so, and although I'm very picky with games, I find that this is an excellent shooter. This is the most fun I've had playing a modern game in years. If you love classic FPS gameplay, this is for you. My one complaint is that I need more. A sequel may happen, though...\n\n10/10

reviewText: Wolfenstein: The New Order is a lovingly crafted game made with a ton of heart and charm that I feel will have legs as more and more people try it out. It’s not radically innovative or revolutionary, but it does so many things to stand out in the current landscape that it doesn’t have to be. A brutal and charming adventure that doesn’t pull any punches but knows when to be light-hearted. The combat design and shooting mechanics (no restricted 2-weapon system, no need to aim-down-sights, multiple ways to approach enemy encounters, glorious hit feedback and gibs) are liberating while being supported by tough AI and fantastic weapons to shoot at them with, in more expansive levels that encourage exploration. Meanwhile, excellent storytelling through fantastic characters and the environment is happening all around you, rather than at you. Also, has one of the best soundtracks in a game with some of the most hard-hitting rock and metal with touches of industrial music that gets your blood pumping to fight for the resistance.\n\nIt brings the best of the old and the new. It’s exactly what people who complain about modern shooters should play, to see it’s not all doom-and-gloom. Personally, it has set a new standard in shooters. It’s one of the best shooters I’ve played.

reviewText:
This game is actually better than I'd been led to believe. I came into the game expecting it to be a competent, if fairly brainless shooter. It's more than 'competent' though. In fact - I think it might be one of the best games of the year. Given that the game is an over-the-top, Nazi killing simulator, I was expecting the story to be more of an afterthought. Surprisingly though, the game's alternate history story is compelling and the game does a good job with world building by peppering the levels with optional conversations and newspaper clippings that help make the world seem more alive. I was expecting the story to go for camp humor, but the game takes itself very seriously at times and the quality of the writing is such that it doesn't come off like some 12 year old's idea of what's is dark and gritty.

I also admire the game's design philosophy, as it does a good job of combining the better elements of new-school and old-school FPS design. For example, the game's health system is a hybrid between health pickups and regenerating health. The way it works is that you can only regenerate health in blocks of 20. If you were to start with 100 health and then lose 95, you'd only be able to regenerate up to 20. I like this system a lot, since it alleviates some of the 'die and retry' repetition from older shooters, but still encourages you to keep moving instead of just hiding behind a wall while you wait for your health to recharge.

The levels are well-designed, with lots of large open rooms, secrets and multiple paths. The controls are nice and responsive, and there's a decent selection of weapons with balanced strengths and weaknesses. You can slide into cover, or shoot while sliding. You can also dual-wield almost every single weapon in the game for an increase in rate of fire while sacrificing accuracy. There are situations where you can take out enemies using stealth, or just go in guns blazing. There's also a perk system that levels up organically based on things you do in the game rather than experience (like x number of head shots with the pistol, or stealth kills using throwing knifes).

The game is just... a lot of fun. There isn't any one thing that makes this game stand out when compared to other shooters, but it does many things very well and manages to feel very fresh while not doing anything particularly new. Machine Games did good here. I really hope that we'll see a sequel from them at some point!

reviewText:
Wolfenstein The New Order is easily the most fun first person shooter I've played in years. I was expecting it to be terrible, but I was pleasantly surprised. It's a throwback to classic shooters which were devoid of hand holding, regenerating health and enemies with infinite grenades.

Even though I abhor the idTECH5 engine, once I looked past it, I found a game that was oddly ... beautiful. The music is epic and adds to the atmosphere of the game. The story is even quite decent, which was an even bigger surprise.

All in all, I'm very happy that I cast my assumptions aside and actually made time to play the game.

reviewText:
Game of the Year 2014, Why?

A games pace is determined by it's introduction to the universe and story of the character you take a journey with. Well this game has a pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good one. You start off already knee deep in ♥♥♥♥ creek being prepared to take the battle to the enemy. This game does not subsitute on beautiful animations, textures and level design. The cutscenes are (60% of the time) shot in the characters perspective and require you to do something enbetween them to make a sence of fulfillment outside your standard run and gun action.

So after my wank-fest to this game what are the pro's and con's?

Pro:
- best reboot to a series I have ever seen
- eye candy everywhere
- choice of play style (stealth or loud)
- story is far superior compared to your current shooters
- violence done right
- secret area's
- pacing
- being a brain dead kid for years only to hold two machine guns within 30 seconds.

Con:
- the awkward moment when a sex scene comes on and someone walks in your room
- Choice of saviour only changes the story and gameplay in the slightest way
- For the size of the game I expected the story to be longer (about 15 hours if you can aim)
- multiplayer (note this can be a good thing, most times multiplayer ruins the atmosphere of a good singleplayer)

Things that can make a sequel better:
- Co-op mode, either using the singleplayer or co-op story of it's own about two seperate characters.
- the ability to use takedowns on heavier enemies to weaken them or create a weak spot
- weapon stability (jamming, wear and tear)
- arcade mode (record time, score for killing enemies all in a fancy ui)
- DLC story about a character that BJ crosses paths with

At the end of the wall of text, 9/10. Worth playing.

P.S. People with ATI cards may have issues, Nvidia master race.

reviewText:
I have latey been fustrated with the lack of great fps shooter games that are totally single, with all the focus on the story and gameplay, I saw this on sale and though why the hell not, and WOW.

I have found this to be one of the most gripping games both gameplay and story wise in a while (that is totally single player). For me graphics are not the most important aspect of a game, but they look really kick ♥♥♥ in this game. A great variety in weapons and some great addons to them, a good variety of enemies, and sometimes a great choice of stealth or guns blazing.

Due to the setting/background of the game i knew it would touch on some pretty dark subjects, such as the whole aerian race/no imperfection tolorence. I wont give anything away, but the writer in this really used these dark, horrible subjects in more tastful way (if that makes any sense), which will leave u thinking. It truly has some messages in the game.

Conclusion -
A fighter game which presents a bloody, dark re written histroy which left me thinking.
Presents a believable humanside to the story, not u jst being  kick ♥♥♥ guy who can shoot up everything with no feeling.
Great visuals in both graphics and the mix of a modern 1940's onwards.
My only downside is that once or twice i was confused of what i needed to do, but that was probably me just being stupid lol.
If you love action, gripping story, visuals and anything ww2 themes GET THIS GAME!!!!

reviewText: Wolfenstein: The New Order is a lovingly crafted game made with a ton of heart and charm that I feel will have legs as more and more people try it out. It’s not radically innovative or revolutionary, but it does so many things to stand out in the current landscape that it doesn’t have to be. A brutal and charming adventure that doesn’t pull any punches but knows when to be light-hearted. The combat design and shooting mechanics (no restricted 2-weapon system, no need to aim-down-sights, multiple ways to approach enemy encounters, glorious hit feedback and gibs) are liberating while being supported by tough AI and fantastic weapons to shoot at them with, in more expansive levels that encourage exploration. Meanwhile, excellent storytelling through fantastic characters and the environment is happening all around you, rather than at you. Also, has one of the best soundtracks in a game with some of the most hard-hitting rock and metal with touches of industrial music that gets your blood pumping to fight for the resistance.\n\nIt brings the best of the old and the new. It’s exactly what people who complain about modern shooters should play, to see it’s not all doom-and-gloom. Personally, it has set a new standard in shooters. It’s one of the best shooters I’ve played.

reviewText: I went into this game with no expectations one way or another, and I left incredibly impressed.  Wolfenstein is an excellently executed single player only FPS that does more than simply line up a shooting gallery for you to run through.  Yes, there's tons of nazis that need killing, and yes, you still fight giant mechanical monstrosities, but I was actually more impressed by what they did with the characters.  BJ has the look of a man who's seen far too much, and there's this undertone about the horrors of war that carries nicely through the piece.  They do a lot to humanize BJ as more than just a standard FPS dude, and it plays very well.\n\nThe gunplay is very solid, and interestingly supports both a more run-and-gun playstyle along with a stealthier silent-takedown approach.  The level design is consistently strong with multiple set-pieces and varied locations throughout.  My only complain at the moment is that there's no DLC for me to buy!

reviewText: Wolfenstein is a good, solid, shooter that was fun and enjoyable to play. It is set mainly in the 1960s where WWII was won by Nazi Germany. You play as a soldier who was badly injured during an assault and has spent the past few years in a vegetable state in a hospital. The game seems to borrow from other games as at times it will feel very familar. In ways it is similar to the early Medal of Honor or the first Call of Duty games where you encounter enemies at a middle distance and they dive and shoot from behind cover. Other times it seems to have been influenced by Dishonored with the stealth sections and animated backstabs. It doesn't quite match those games in terms of execution of the mechanics but they are decent.\n\nWolfenstein's employs a standard mission and base system where you complete a few missions and head back to your base for a breather. It uses the base as a way of expanding on some of the characters and fill in the back story. There are some interesting, memorable characters in Wolfenstein but unfortunately that makes some of the others seem one dimensional. I feel that maybe with a bit more time, focus and care this game could have been truly great. The story is at times over the top which lends well to the gameplay, however around the midway point there is one to two chapters which are just plain dumb. It stupidly tosses in a secret Jewish organisation" into the mix which
recommended: is only touched on for one chapter. Aside from that there are nice touches which help shape the story; such as the main character muttering about distant memories throughout the game.\n\nThe level design is very good generally with expansive indoor maps that allow you to do a bit of exploring. As a homge to the early Wolfenstein games there are gold objects and other hidden goodies littered throughout the game. Letters and newspapers are hidden to provide background and as in early 90s shooters enemies drop armour and ammo. The game strangely gets you to press E to collect these pickups which seems a bit odd. Simply running over them would have been a better choose. I actually liked the perk systems in this game as it is not intrusive. You gain perks by just repeating actions such as killing enemies with throwing knives or headshotting guards. There are four bands of perks which cover stealth play
hoursPlayed: assault play
voteText: tactical and demolition. You can purposely pursue them but I found they populated as I played.\n\nIt was nice for me to play a game where the movement is fairly quick
helpfulPercent: guns are snappy
votesHelpful: and pack a punch. Dual-weilding chunky shotguns was a good throw back. There is a peek-from-cover move which I rarely used as you can just blast away. Wolf contains a laser cutting weapon which was versitile and upgradable. Again
votesTotal:
if more time had been spend on it I feel it could have been as good as the Gravity Gun in HL2. There just aren't too many levels that explore its features fully. It also highlights a few inconsistences with the levels and "world". An example would be how certain metal sheets and surfaces are destructable yet some wooden panels or metal boxes aren't. I think it is more a restriction employed for consoles that hindered the game a bit. Its the same with the textures which can be low-res in some places. The game does run very smooth and I experienced no slow down.

The AI of the enemies is a lot better when they are fighting as it quickly becomes apparant that their stealth AI is sloppy. I've had guards look straight at me or see their colleague get shot just to turn and walk away. The first stealthy mission is the best as it has multiple routes the others are very hit and miss. Firefights however are very satisfying and can be challenging when you encounter the different types of soldiers. The game has a decent difficulty level which can cause you to die a few times when you get overwhelmed. Overall Wolfenstein is worth it as it is a fun experience. The majority of the levels are diverse in theme and design. It is not run and gun shooter of old but more of a blend of modern and old. There is no magic directional arrow showing you the way so sometimes you can get lost. I will be replaying this game again to see what I missed. It just misses out on being an 8 out of 10 game.


"

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a fantastic action game. Not only because you can go every bit as crazy as in previous installments, if not even more, but because it reaches beyond the conventional boundaries.
The narrative and especially the characters have been given a lot more attention. While it is perhaps not as moving as games like The Walking Dead, it certainly shines as being a lot more faceted and polished than most other high-octane shooters.

The environments are varied and levels layered, offering depth and tactic. There's even a branch in the storyline as early as the end of the first mission. This means that some characters you will encounter and places you can go in levels change. It doesn't affect the gameplay dramatically, but it makes for at least some variation, warranting another playthrough.

If you're looking to dual-wield shotguns in a game world that's not just decorative but also brings an interesting take on an alternate history, you've come to the right place. This is an action game developed with passion and I can't wait for what MachineGames makes next.

reviewText: What a fantastic game. I don't regret pre-ordering this one bit. This is what storylines in games need to be like. With well-developed characters, alternate timelines, and protagonists you actually despise, a lot of game developers could take a lesson from Wolfenstein the New Order.\n\nThink about it. You can beat this game as quick as 10 hours, as long as 20. But you'll want to do it again based on a choice you make in the prologue that changes the story in a few different ways (including gameplay, to some degree). Because of how quiock you can beat this game, though, you'd think a lot of people would be dissatisfied. Heck, even I'm a bit disappointed by how short it is. And of course, many are still butthurt about no multiplayer. But the fact that the visuals, gameplay, and storyline are enough to counterbalance that? That's where developers need to take note. You don't need a massive sandbox to make a fantastic game (though it can be quite awesome). You don't even need multiplayer. All you need is a good story and good gameplay. Be original, and be compelling. Wolfenstein delivers there incredibly well.

reviewText:
This was better than the 80/100 Metacritic reviewed as.

Like Doom 3, this is a high expectation game due to its history.  I had such good memories playing the 3D and RtCW that when I started this, I was a bit concerned.  But no, life goes on, it is a different game, a 2010s gaming feel (though it is in 60s) and I appreciated the story a lot.  I liked the ending.  It was a dark future, but the game did not feel that claustrophobic.

I thought the guns, even duel wielding, combat mechanics and graphics were great.  The mix of stealth and combat was good.  There was enough variation, like RtCW, in terms of gameplay and locations.  It certainly gave a bit console friendly feel but it was definitely a PC game.

I also liked that you did not look around for weak spots of the map much for ammo health or other stuff.  I was mostly at max in most of them even at harder level.  Some like to play with ammo depletion and be thrifty, others like to 'search' the whole mape for some silly 'thing'.  This game takes away most of that frustration and only focuses on the actual game.

The cutscenes were nicely balanced with the gameplay.

On the negative side **includes spoilers**, the game difficulty felt easier than some other PC games.  It was not a walk in the park for sure, I played in difficulty 4/5.  But some stealth and combat was easy and I expected a higher challenge.

I also expected a bit more 60s alternative life, but there was no 'normal life' around.  Maybe that it is the vision for Nazi victory.

The characters were fine, but could have been developed a bit more.  Also, the character development (Stealth, Tactics etc.) was not that clear or was a bit afterthought when I played.  It is not like an RPG for sure, maybe does not have to be either.

Music was missing for sure.  Maybe it was a part of this doomy future where you have no life signs apart from you and your friends.  I though RtCW's biggest plus was its music where you really felt like in Germany.


Overall, I would have given 85/100 to this game and thank the developers for showing respect to a brand.  It felt good to play this and have a breeze from the past.  These type of games feel much more in connection with human than some other soulless shooters or 'horror' games or over analytical RPGs.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein The New Order is easily the most fun first person shooter I've played in years. I was expecting it to be terrible, but I was pleasantly surprised. It's a throwback to classic shooters which were devoid of hand holding, regenerating health and enemies with infinite grenades.

Even though I abhor the idTECH5 engine, once I looked past it, I found a game that was oddly ... beautiful. The music is epic and adds to the atmosphere of the game. The story is even quite decent, which was an even bigger surprise.

All in all, I'm very happy that I cast my assumptions aside and actually made time to play the game.

reviewText:
This game reminded me of the time when I still liked shooters. They just don't make 'em like this anymore. You can expect a solid 15 hours of gameplay (give or take up to 5 depending on your playing speed) for your first playthrough, that said the game makes itself replayable by having a choice in the first level which will slightly alter the gameplay and minorly affect possible routes you can go in levels. It's not much, but it's enough to give you an excuse to spend another 15 hours on it when you're bored some months (or years) after your first completion (or if you are just starving for more after you finish the game).

My only problems with the game were performance issues, I have a pretty high end machine but it seems that the game is very poorly optimized, for example it does not support triple buffering (so one of my major performance issues was that my framerate was jumping between 15/30/60 all the time when Vsync was enabled, the solution is to disable Vsync in the game options and to force Vsync with triple buffering on in your graphics drivers. Blame iD Software for this one.) And it also seems to have some caching issues. Load times between deaths can get extremely long as well (up to more than a full minute) but after dying an X amount of times in the same spot (2 or 3 times) it seems the game starts to load it faster. Don't ask me why.

Besides the performance issues, the game was great all around, from the gameplay to the story, and even the characters. I also loved the entire soundtrack. The protagonist was your typical classic FPS type (like you'd expect from Wolfenstein or Doom games) which was kindof a nice kick in the nostalgia. It's an oldschool game making use of the capabilities of modern game development tools. A must play if you are or ever were a fan of shooters.

reviewText:
These days there are not a lot of good FPS games, that get the singleplayer right. They tend to focus on multiplayer of which usually the player base dies within the first month as players are confused as to whether they are playing a part of a story or a deathmatch. By ignoring multiplayer altogether ID has produced a gem of epic proportions.

Within the first few minutes you are treated to an intro played out and not merely watched. With characters you relate to, the game gives you choices that affect those relationships. And if you allow it you feel as the protagonist does. Your hatred towards the Nazi's in this alternate timeline grows more and more. When a game can immerse you not just visually but mentally too then you have a winner.

Now how does it play. Well here we have a classic style gameplay method mixed with modern effects. Like old ID games tou must pick up health and armour. However we have moved on from the walk over you must manually pick up using hotkey to do so. Which is a little irritating but understandable as it allows medpacks and armour to be hidden at times thus adding a little bit of realism to the game. The days of giant mansized medpacks are over people.

Duel wield. Nice touch to the game I must confess to using this a little too much and it can at times make the game a little easy as accuracy is of such that you don't need to iron sight guns all too much and so you can use duel wield without actually sacrificing anything. So plus and a minus here.

Secrets. A homage to Wolfenstein 3D I imagine. Gold objects are hidden around the levels what used to give you a score now is a game of find the Nazi gold. Fun for completionists but I have never been so inclined.

I am glad that this game had the balls to use Swastikas. I have never been a fan of people changing the symbol of Nazi Germany to the iron cross. For 2 reasons one it is historically inaccurate and 2 it ironically associates the iron cross with Nazism, when it is a symbol of the German military pre, during and post Third Reich era. So way to go censorship is going to make the current German military seem like a bunch of Nazis.

AI the AI does seem decent enough to be a challenge. The game uses the classic ID 5 levels of difficulty scheme. I started on second hardest but had to raise it to maximum for the challege but it is there. I think and average gamer could handle second to hard no problems. People who love FPS yeah go for the top.

10/10

reviewText:
Review in ENG: If you're a fan of classic shooter games and old-school video games this is one for your games library.

B-movieish plot, epic one-liners, great graphics, overall gameplay is enjoyable. The whole setting is really intriguing and I was fascinated how much Nazis would've developed on science and warfare if they would've won.

This game makes you laugh, cry and yell at the same time, I did love it. If you're a typical COD fanboy then you may dislike this one, I mean it isn't much of a challenge but there's no multiplayer. Either way, the game is truly epic.

Arvostelu suomeksi: (tää ei ole suora käännös läheskään vaan ihan omin sanoin kuvailtu molemmissa):

Tosi mahtava peli ja ehdottomasti suosittelen old-school gamereille ja Wolfenstein-faneille jotka tykkää tappaa ja räjäytellä natseja päivät pitkät.

Pelissä tosin on vaan 16 tasoa ja se on taiturilla ohit 5-8 tunnissa. 50 euroa tästä ei hyvänen aika kannata maksaa vaan todella hyvänä alelaarikamana tää on parasta mitä voi saada 20-30 eurolla. Kannattaa tää hankkia ennemmin kuin CoD: Ghosts.

reviewText:
A brilliant franchise re-imagened.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a game that I did not expect to be as good as it turned out to be. I went into it with minimum expectations and expected to just kill some time, what I got was an experience that I didn't expect. The game has some great shooting mechanics, very nice graphics and superb level design. It was very satisfying to tear through hundreds of Nazis in the world of The New Order. The story is actually pretty good too, it has some interesting characters and the dialogues are very well done. The game also provides some quiet time moments for you to get your bearings before you are put up against yet even more Nazi soldiers, which I like. It makes you appreciate the combat a lot more.

There is room for stealth, a lot of sections in the game give you the option to go full stealth. I myself quite enjoy stealth games, so definitely a one up for that. Of course you can also always go loud, your hand is not held nor are you held back by rules. It's just you versus Nazi Germany.

Would I recommend it? Of course I would. The game offers such a good single-player mode that I can't not recommend it.

Oh yeah, also, dual wielding semi-automatic shotguns. Yes.

reviewText: I went into this game with no expectations one way or another, and I left incredibly impressed.  Wolfenstein is an excellently executed single player only FPS that does more than simply line up a shooting gallery for you to run through.  Yes, there's tons of nazis that need killing, and yes, you still fight giant mechanical monstrosities, but I was actually more impressed by what they did with the characters.  BJ has the look of a man who's seen far too much, and there's this undertone about the horrors of war that carries nicely through the piece.  They do a lot to humanize BJ as more than just a standard FPS dude, and it plays very well.\n\nThe gunplay is very solid, and interestingly supports both a more run-and-gun playstyle along with a stealthier silent-takedown approach.  The level design is consistently strong with multiple set-pieces and varied locations throughout.  My only complain at the moment is that there's no DLC for me to buy!

reviewText:
So first off let me start by saying that I was able to play this thanks to steam's family sharing feature, so I do not know if my hour count will show up here, but as I write this I have played 10 hours of the game, now, on to the review. WARNING: Review contains minor early game spoilers but nothing major.

In Wolfenstein: The New Order you play as Captain Blazkowicz, a US soldier who is injured fighting against the nazi's, who then awakens years later to find they now rule the world. Now it is time to fight back, and lead the resistance against the Nazi's.


Pro's:

+Amazing Graphics - on Ultra it has some of the best graphics I've ever seen in any game, and on low it is still better than most games.

+Fun Gameplay - Dual weilding futuristic shotguns whilst blowing Nazi's to shreds has never been so fun!

+Good Story - The story for this game is pretty good, it is well explained as to why everything happens, leaving no unanswered questions.

+Lots to do - There are many collectables to collect and enigma codes to crack, doing which grants you more game modes!


Cons:

-It's quite short - The story took me just 10 hours to complete, however it was very enjoyable and there is much more for me to do in future playthroughs, so I will likely complete it multiple more times.

-In one of the first few missions you wind up getting injured and becoming a potato for 14 years. When you wake up you still have all your muscle, which isn't very realistic. Though it doesn't really affect anything so meh.

-No multiplayer - I'm not really bothered by this, but with the story being so short and it being such a fun game, it would certianly have been a great feature to include.


Overall I'd reccomend this game to essentially anyone who is considering getting it, it's one of the most fun games I've played in the last few years, and it's amazingly fun to take out rooms full of Nazi's whilst you dual weild gigantic machine guns. Overall I think I'd rate this game with a score of 87/100.

reviewText:
This is the first time I've actually been compelled to write a review for a game. I bought this during the summer sale and finished it in about a week, which for me is a big thing. I barely finish games.
Wolfenstein is excellent. With an amazing soundtrack and impaccable voice acting & sound design to start, it's gameplay is solid and has a great, if linear and seemingly farfetched story. In fact one of my only criticisms is the fact that it's so linear - although I'm not sure how that could change, as is the nature of the Wolfenstein universe.

Pros:Amazing soundtrack that really gets you pumped. You can't really jump straight in because the main menu theme is so good
Brilliant voice acting
Great gameplay. Firing an assault rifle is satisfactory on its own, let alone the multitude of entertaining ways you can spend your time killing nazis as you advance
Pretty good story. It's entertaining if unbelievable, what with the whole Nazis dominating earth, Da'at Yichud secret jew organisation, etc. etc. however it doesn't ever get boring.
The CHARACTERS. The antagonists can be truly ♥♥♥♥ing hated in every way, whilst the supporting cast are all a great bunch. Fergus, Anya, Klaus, even minor characters like Bombate are extremely likeable. However despite this, I do feel like a lot of them need more development. I've only played one run with the fergus timeline, but what the hell was the point in Tekla?
A large amount of weapons in my opinion, with possiblilities to give each weapon a secondary fire mode which essentially changes the weapon completely in most cases
Killing nazis on the moon. Giant frankenstein nazis. nazi robot dogs. Secret sciency jews who make floaty bomb things and super suits.
You can duel wield (almost) every weapon.
RobotsCons:The game is very linear. There's very little freedom to do whatever you want, but I guess that's not necessarily a bad thing.
As far as collectibles go, there are several areas where they'll be displayed explicitly on your map, but in other sections you have no hints whatsoever. Not a bad thing for most people, but this inconsistency ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off a bit.
The gameplay in combination with certain other elements can be a little inconsistent, i.e. dramatic music continuing to play when you've already killed everyone.
For anyone who's affected by this, there is a ♥♥♥♥ton of gore (particularly at the end. But the ending is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing let me tell you)
For whatever reason, machine games decided to make our hero ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Blaskowicz ♥♥♥♥ anya at every opportunity despite him having barely talked to her over the past 14 years.
Frau Engel is a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥There are probably a few things I've left out, but as a game which I've finished extremely quickly for the first time in a long time, I simply feel like I need to write this review. There are a few improvements which could be made but it's on the cusp of being perfect for me. 9/10.

reviewText:
Get this game. No questions go buy it right now. If it’s on sale in any way you should be paying before even finishing this sentence.
The gunplay is fun and dynamic with a lot of varied weapons. The enemy was great to go up against and in the higher difficulties it was very smart. The set pieces were astounding from start to end. The story was in depth and diverse and the characters were interesting and well fleshed out.

This game is phenomenal and well worth more than one play through. My suggestion for that is play it once on hard mode for the feeling of accomplishment for winning and then once on easy because there is nothing more fun than gunning down an army of Nazi’s as if you were the god of war himself.

The controls are robust and responsive. The weapons handle well and later on come with some fun upgrades. You would be silly to pass this up, it may not be the best game I have ever played but I would play it again in a heartbeat. So much fun and excitement.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
Well, this was certainly one of only a select AAA titles worth a damn this year (DA:I, Shadows of Mordor and Alien Isolation being the others), even if it did have a few annoying issues.

Story: Honestly, wasn't expecting as much as I got out of the story. It was kinda like the recent Shadow Warrior, in which I went into a shooter expecting all cheese and came out with a surprisingly decent story. The two main characters, Blaskowitz and Anya, are generally likeable. I like that BJ genuinely seems exhausted and worn down by everything that's happened, and his dialogue reflects that. Most the characters of the resistance are at first unlikeable, but then become genuinely sympathetic as you talk to them. I also like how they flesh out the world around you, a world in which everyone genuinely loves the Nazis and paints you as the terrorists. It creates this psuedo- I am Legend (the book) narrative where you're the monsters making everyone scared to leave their homes, but it's cool because they're Nazis. Unfortunately, it also leads to a massive plothole, which is that the game never really explains how killing the main bad guy is going to undo all this. The nazis have conquered every threat in the world and rule over (as the game points out) 75% of the world, and killing one dude isn't going to fix all that. Perhaps the story writers felt the same way, because the game ends without any closure, which annoyed me. I also didn't care for the choice at beginning, which changes a little bit of the story, because it feels like forced replayability, and I don't like that. Still, I did love the story, and only Transistor gave me a better one of those this year.

Gameplay: This was a bit of a sticking point to me. While the day I'm ungrateful at a chance to kill Nazis on the surface of the moon with dual laser machine guns is the day I officialy can't have fun anymore, the gameplay comes across as Jack of all trades

reviewText:
The re-imagination of the WWII era Wolfenstein comes to us in a 1960s package. Is this game any good and was it worth Total Biscuit's GOTY 2014?

Yeah... it really kicks ♥♥♥!

Story wise you start off in the WW2 era, fighting Nazis, after suffering a combat induced 14 year concussion/vegetable state you come-to in 1960. The Nazis have won the war. They control all of Europe, much of the USSR territory and the US has surrendered. Their campaign, however, still continues into Africa.

You play as the classic William BJ" Blazkowicz

reviewText:
This is one of the best, if not the best, first person shooter of 2014.  Its not perfect, but it is very good.

Pros:
-Story 5/5:  Its an alternative historical fiction where Hitler obtains ancient and secret technology which allows the Nazis to win WWII.  Story is set in 1960s.  Extremely well done. Good narration, good pace, good originality, interesting, not too ridiculous if you can get over the hero’s apparent invincibility.  Its on par with the Half Life series.

-Characters 5/5: Well done, most video games don’t put more than one thought into character design but this is top notch in my opinion.

-GamePlay 4/5: Really good. Controls are a little non-standard but everything works great.

-Stability 5/5: Not one crash, bug, glitch, nothing - ran 100% smooth (i5 4670 & GTX 980)

-Nostalgia 5/5: Good throwback to the original but still fresh and competitive

-Graphics 4/5: Nearly top notch with a few exceptions, namely the vehicles are very clumsy.  The humans and atmosphere look incredible.

-Sound 4/5: Everything sounds good music is awesome. No sound sliders in options so music can only be muted but not turned down.

Quality: 4/5
Fun Level: 5/5
Recommend it 100%
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is amazing, I wasn't sure about paying 60 dollars for it so I waited...and waited...and then the summer sale came!\nI got it for 15 dollars. So you might ask...was it worth it? YES! it was worth every penny! what if it is not on sale? STILL WORTH IT! It is amazing. I usually never buy single player only games  because I fear that once I beat it I'm out of my money and entertainment but something about this game intrigued me, I'm SO glad I gave it a chance.\nI recommend this product!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Theres a cirtain bent appeal about the idea of Nazis winning the war, and making every one of them you come across regret it.

Story is pretty solid, and the game play is a throw back to the old days of carrying the arsenal of a full platoon on your back and blasting your way through waves upon waves of Nazis, but the stealth mechanic is OP so you can just forget every weapon you got and just use the knife like i found myself doing on my first playthrough. Which brings me to my only complaint, the AI is kinda blind when your sneaking, you can be a few meters in front of them and so long as your crouched, they pretty much ignore you.

All in all though its still a pretty excellent game, highly recomend it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fun stuff.  The only things that really got me down in this game were:

- almost-lack of a rocket launcher (there is one, but it's for special occasions)
- in the last third or so of the game, stealth is just out of the question. Stealth was fun.
- as so often happens, there's a brick wall of boss at the end of the game that really sours an otherwise fun experience.  Plus, it's a dumb boss, nothing interesting about it, just pain.

Good stuff:
- shootin' nazis on the moon
- really simple stealth, and when you screw it up (easily), you can fight just fine instead of having to restart and try again
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Having played all Wolfenstein games going back to the original id bombshell of the early 1990's, this particular version takes the game to new heights. The graphics and visual effects are very good and the audio is also excellent. Stealth is a major factor in survival and can be used to eliminate with great success on most of the enemy including the nasty 'Armoured Dogs' that proliferate the game. Don't try this though on any mechanised robotic device as failure will be certain and will set you back somewhat causing you to start again from the last checkpoint. (Albeit not a major problem).

Weapon options although at times limited do not seem to hinder the main character to any great degree as he is able to despatch most opposition with a minimum of fuss. Planning how you go about this is the important thing to consider as opposed to what you have to do to complete the task at hand. Bear in mind also that you need to replenished ammunition and health/armour regularly so take time to look around for possible and usually neccessary pickups, (approach and gather anything that glows for they will most likey be usable items).

You can collect 'Trophies' as well so investigate unusual looking objects and read notices on walls and desks for information (although this can be a little tedious at times when you are trying to get things done).

If you see a bed, have a sleep and you may be surprised at what happens when you do and my opening line will give you a hint as to what to expect!

The game is not open world in as much as you cannot simply move around free to do things as you wish and unlimited exploring is not an option, you go where your mission directs you and that's it!

This leads me to my main dislike, too many cutscenes that slow down gameplay. At times the player (me at least) is left saying Not another one
date: I just want to get on with the game!"\n\nI guess the creators were trying to incorporate the feeling of abject misery (the prison scenes alone will assert to that)
recommended: but may have allowed that idea to stem the flow effect as in pulling on the reigns which brings you to a grinding halt. This then gives the game a 'Build it up as you go' arrangement where you are completing missions which only help to build a small part of the next objective. For me that scenario can get a little tiresome
hoursPlayed: I am sure for others it is more than acceptable so it is all about what an individual wants and expects from a game
voteText: but these are my views and I accept that.\n\nIn conlusion (and now that I have completed the game)
helpfulPercent: I recommend it as on the whole it is very good but for me at times a bit depressing. If that was the aim of the developers then they succeeded
votesHelpful: I just felt a bit hobbled! The real action takes place about a third of the way through and from there it takes off and is excellent and should not dissapoint.\n\nTook approx. 15 hrs to go through first time (not bad)
votesTotal: but missed many items that I will collect next time through. I would rate this game 7.5/10 and my screenshots will give you an indication of gameplay.\n\nCertainly worth a go
votesFunny: but maybe best to wait for a sale.\n\nAlso
commentsCount: a strong suggestion is to play Wolfenstein 'The Old Blood' first....It is a prequal and it does flow on to 'New Order'. Had I done this I would have started New Order with a different mindset and understanding."

reviewText:
I will start off by saying this is the best game I have ever played.

I have played other games for longer. I have had more fun and laughed more from other games. But I can say without a doubt this game is the best I've ever played.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a brilliant game. It's a thrill ride of ups, downs, and killing Nazis. The story is one of the best I've ever seen a game, and it's blend of adrenaline-pumping action with genuine moments of sadness and regret from the characters is very rare in a modern-day FPS. It expresses the true machinelike evil of the Nazis, and people dogged resiatance to them. Even in the darkest moments of the game, someone will always bounce back. Although it' s fictional(duh) and contains some fantasy elemenst (Jewish superweapons, anyone?), the story hits home with every one of us. Although we are thrust into the story just like that, Aas we sneak our way through each level and then inevitbaly  screw up, get caught, and bring out the dual-wield laser guns and automatic shotguns, we begin to understand what we are fighting for: freedom, and what we are fighting against: oppresion, imprisonment, gruesome cruelty(this gmae lives up to it's ESRB rating, and not in a good way) and of course, Nazis. The end, although bland, still left me in shock and awe from just everything this game has to offer. There were times when I almost felt like crying(as much as a game can make you cry), and throughout it all it was evident everyone was suffering(including the protaganist). The story is beyond anything else you will likely see in another FPS for a while. It's great.

Gameplay wise, Wolfenstien offers some refreshing mechanincs will still keeping true to the classic FPS elements that make the genre so popular. It offers plenty of options to stealth around; when the enemies start rolling in it offers some serious firepower. Nearly every weapon has an unlockable alternate firing mode and can be duel welded. With the lasercraftwerk, this game's equivalent of the gravity gun, you can do all kinds of stuff as you find new attachemnts for it, although its feels a little limited due to specific surfaces you can use it on. It also can provide a helping hand when your low on ammo and need a boost in firepower. The manual leaning is much preferable to an automatic system, although the controls are a little strange. I especially liked the no nonsense health value; get shot and the number goes down, get one the various helath kits in the game and the number goes up, if its gets to 0 you die. The armor is the same. Although a little unrealistic(especially with the armor), its provides a refreshing idea instead of the overused immersive" health. Stealth is also quite good. Sneaking behind walls and shooting commanders when no one is looking gives me a thrill like no other. An early game choice determines whether you use stealth/lockpicking(my choice) or explosives/grenades(I think). Overall
date: some refershing ideas give the game a different look and feel then most FPS's.\n\nNow that my glowing review is over

reviewText: First off, it's Wolfenstein.  For those who don't know the Wolfenstein Series was there at the beginning of the FPS.  Over the top weapons and enemies are to be expected.  In TNO these exceptations will be met, if not exceeded.  This is the game we mean when we say First Person Shooter.  Just enough story to give it purpose.  All the weapons in the arsenal, some two at a time.  Maps with varied objectives.  A certain amount of stealth.  Gore splatter, blood spatter and amusing rag doll effects.  There is even a little sex which i believe is a new addition to the Wolfenstein Series.\n\nRecommended for SP, Speed Runners, Wolfenfanatics

reviewText:
Hey there Steam community,

this is my first review... EVER... so please forgive me for any errors in reviewing. First of all I'd like to start by saying that well.... I ABSOLUTELY LOVED THE GAME! For me it was really amazing, this is the first game of the Wolfenstein series that I've tried and I love it love it love it (might try the old 2D one just for fun xD). Before I begin I'd like to apologise for its length, its kinda long but please bear with me.

What I loved the most about the game was its concept, set in World War 2 and well, the Nazi's won and now they rule the world. That itself made it interesting enough to try. I liked the ideas that the producers thought of (the enemies and their uniforms) because they brought a nice combination of the retro Nazi soldier uniform (probably from the helmet) with well.... the modern" soldier
date: its interesting to see it (at least for me). Especially with all the crazy technological advancements the Nazi's made in the game and of course.... throw at you... and believe me they got all sorts of crazy sh.. stuff. The game lets players use well... enough weapons
recommended: though i would say that a little bit more weapon types would be nice

Those who try to go Rambo run the risk of being overwhelmed (running out of ammo for me) should they forget/are unable to kill the officers as they can call in unlimited reinforcements (I haven't seen the officers run out of back-up before). Therefore the game promotes strategic thinking because players must learn to conserve ammo as the game is pretty cheap on ammo drops from dead enemies and take down officers quickly using tactics such as flanking

reviewText:
Firstly,I am old enough (60) to have heard the horror stories about the Nazi's from family members who were there.Secondly,I couldn't care less about graphics(whether I can see a gnat's whiskers from 20 feet away)which is why I am guessing the game runs flawlessly on my 6 year old machine(I run everything at 1024x768,including my desktop)That being said I cannot recommend this game highly enough.From the correct Polish\German pronunciation of Blaskowicz(Blas-Ko-Vitch)by Caroline to the original Wolf3D mini-game,to then presentation of story,action,controls,emotion,and the horror of war(albeit on the premise that the Nazi's won WW2)the game provides a stark lesson in story telling and history twisting.I mean when I discovered the Game difficulty avatars and THEN found the :Uber avatar is the same face used in the original game I mean.....c'mon guy's an' gal's,it just doesn't get any better.I have had an absolute blast playing this entry.The end music is awe inspiring.It is unfortunate that so many newer rigs are having problems running the game.It doesn't speak(IMHO)to the quality of the content.Just for grins my rig is;
ASUS P5N-D Alienware Area-51
Q9650
GSkill Black DDR2(8GB)4-4-4-12
GTX 470
Seagate 500 GB HD
SB Audigy 2 ZS (2005) from different tower
Win 7 x64
Hats off to the Dev's.VERY well done(for me)

The story is beyond anything else you will likely see in another FPS for a while. It's great.

Gameplay wise, Wolfenstien offers some refreshing mechanincs will still keeping true to the classic FPS elements that make the genre so popular. It offers plenty of options to stealth around; when the enemies start rolling in it offers some serious firepower. Nearly every weapon has an unlockable alternate firing mode and can be duel welded. With the lasercraftwerk, this game's equivalent of the gravity gun, you can do all kinds of stuff as you find new attachemnts for it, although its feels a little limited due to specific surfaces you can use it on. It also can provide a helping hand when your low on ammo and need a boost in firepower. The manual leaning is much preferable to an automatic system, although the controls are a little strange. I especially liked the no nonsense health value; get shot and the number goes down, get one the various helath kits in the game and the number goes up, if its gets to 0 you die. The armor is the same. Although a little unrealistic(especially with the armor), its provides a refreshing idea instead of the overused immersive" health. Stealth is also quite good. Sneaking behind walls and shooting commanders when no one is looking gives me a thrill like no other. An early game choice determines whether you use stealth/lockpicking(my choice) or explosives/grenades(I think). Overall
date: some refershing ideas give the game a different look and feel then most FPS's.\n\nNow that my glowing review is over

reviewText:
There's a lot of internet backlash for what I have to say is a brilliant game. I've known about the Wolfenstein series for years but  aside from a very brief playthrough of Return to Castle Wolfenstein, Wolfenstein: The New Order was the first time I payed serious attention to playing. And despite all the dissapointment from others, I say this is a great game almost undeserved of the complaining.

The levels are massive, on several maps I dropped my jaw at the scenery. Id software have gone to great lengths to make awe-inspiring scenes and even arenas for fighting. The AI itself is not stupid (mostly), i've been flanked by the rank-and-file and on higher difficulty levels I've been killed by being outsmarted by the AI (although on the opposite end I have seen soldiers stand in the middle of the floor to shoot me). This game is a love-letter not just to old-school shooters, but veterens of the Wolfenstein series as this game's story continues on from general Wolfenstein canon.

I have not finished the story yet but so far it has kept me hooked. I feel for the resistance leaders, i feel for the poor people being oppressed. There are newspaper cuttings that detail events during the Nazi regime which move me to tears. Machine Games did a good job showing how grim this world is as at one point reading these cuttings I even wondered if this Nazi-ruled world was even worth saving.

With a low-end processor (Intel i3) I can't play with the shiniest graphics. I have seen several patches of low-res texturing but  after a while it didn't bother me, the game as great and the scenery was impressive nonetheless. The cutscenes are gorgeous and the animation is of very good quality. I'd say what Machine Games have done is actually fairly clever as despite my low-end processor as I could still witness moments of some very detailed modeling. While walking around, the PC performs idle animations even if he is just a pair of arms for the most part; checking ammo, priming the weapon and adjusting the sights or playing with his knife. I did have problems getting the game to work as I needed the very latest driver for my AMD graphics card and it took me some time to find the right 64x Catalyst Control Centre for WIndows 7.

Overall I say we got what many old-school veterens want from the FPS genre: An affectionate throwback to the stuff we lost in the advancement of the shooter genre. But this game also includes modern concepts. I'm hunting for ammo, health packs and collectables while watching my ammo supply (old-school) while also shooting from cover down an iron sight (new-school).

reviewText:
A brilliant franchise re-imagened.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a game that I did not expect to be as good as it turned out to be. I went into it with minimum expectations and expected to just kill some time, what I got was an experience that I didn't expect. The game has some great shooting mechanics, very nice graphics and superb level design. It was very satisfying to tear through hundreds of Nazis in the world of The New Order. The story is actually pretty good too, it has some interesting characters and the dialogues are very well done. The game also provides some quiet time moments for you to get your bearings before you are put up against yet even more Nazi soldiers, which I like. It makes you appreciate the combat a lot more.

There is room for stealth, a lot of sections in the game give you the option to go full stealth. I myself quite enjoy stealth games, so definitely a one up for that. Of course you can also always go loud, your hand is not held nor are you held back by rules. It's just you versus Nazi Germany.

Would I recommend it? Of course I would. The game offers such a good single-player mode that I can't not recommend it.

Oh yeah, also, dual wielding semi-automatic shotguns. Yes.

reviewText: This is a game about shooting, stabbing, and strangling Nazis. In that regard and in nearly every other, this game is phenomenal. It has rock-solid shooting mechanics and well designed environments. The game does not by any means take itself seriously which I think is a good thing. You may think that because of this the plot cannot be very interesting but this is not the case. The game puts forth an entertaining and memorable plot that I enjoyed immensely. This is in my opinion the best game released in 2014 and the best first-person shooter to be released in a very long while. The protagonist is also a man with the musculature of a primate and a jaw that is the size of a dinner table. I guess that's a plus, if you're in to that sort of thing...

reviewText:
Good game.

Nice graphics. Nice environments. Nice cutscenes. Nice voice acting. Some nice guns.

Poor enemy AI (the soldiers are really stupid. They get stuck on walls. They ignore their comrades being silently shot in the head. They ignore bullets hitting stuff in front of them, when you miss. They have terrible vision). For some reason you have to stand over every dropped item and press 'E' to pick it up. You can't just run over it. It took me a while to get comfortable with this, and I missed quite a bit, because it was hidden in corpses and I had to go fishing for it. Uber mode isn't challenging enough. And there is too much health and ammunition. The silenced pistol can kill soldiers with one shot to their helmeted heads, from a long distance, which sort of makes the AR marksman sniper rifle and dual-wielding assault rifles a bit redundant, But I guess it gives people two ways to play.

I spent far too much time searching for collectables. I just wanted to get in to the game, go with the flow, but I felt obliged to waste time checking every part of the map for a side room where I might find a document or a golden object.

There is only one ending, which is fine, I don't expect every new game to have more than one. But I found the ending disappointing. There is no multiplayer, which doesn't matter because we can just go and play some other multiplayer shooting game. But it feels like all the work on the environments, models and weapons has gone to waste because you can't use them with other people.

I'd still recommend it, though. It was mostly entertaining, if a little slow-paced.

reviewText:
After playing Shadow Warrior and being left wanting, I decided to give this game a shot after hearing that it was very arcadey and action packed. I was a bit apprehensive because I was afraid there would be too many Halo or Call of Duty style elements introduced to the old formula to make it more palatable for modern gamers, but after playing the game through I can say that my fears were unfounded.

Although Wolfentstein: The New Order has some modern elements, such as the perks system and weapon upgrades, it eschews the systems popularised by CoD and Halo, such as limited weapon loadouts (you can carry all at once, and dual wield almost everything), and reduces the importance of others; I didn't use the cover system at all, and although your health regenerates at very low levels, you will definitely be hunting for health and ammo. On top of that, the combat encourages you to run around a lot, bringing enemies on thick and fast and giving you few places to hide.

The level design is great, with environments that feel like real places but that are both interestingly laid out and packed with multiple layers, air ducts and hidey holes so that you are given some freedom in how you tackle the combat situations you are thrown into. Most of the time you can choose to play stealthily, or run in guns blazing, although the stealth system is not especially fleshed out, and the AI is extremely forgiving, so it just feels like a way to give the player some more options, and also make some tougher situations easier since you can just sneak round and take out key squad captains to prevent them from setting off the alarms.

The weapons in this game are mostly the standard fare, but they all feel very good to use and are all useful in different situations. There is one weapon that is used throughout the game to great effect, which allows you to cut through fences, break chains, or switch modes and use it like a railgun. The heavy cannons in the game also cut holes in some walls, sometimes revealing secrets or ammo caches in crates scattered around the battleground. All weapons can be upgraded by finding modules around the levels, or by getting perks, which are given if you achieve some specific goal, such as performing 5 silent takedowns to get a silenced pistol.

The story actually added to the game for once. There are fairly few action FPS games where the story adds a lot to the game, but here it provides a great setting (alternative WW2 where Nazi Germany took over the world), and is well written and compelling enough that you do care what happens, regardless of how cliched the whole resistance fighter thing has become. Having said that, I did feel a bit cheated by the ending.

If you were holding out on Wolfenstein: TNO like I was, definitely consider grabbing it, as it straddles the lines between modern and retro FPS brilliantly, providing satisfyingly creative combat with a compelling and immersive story and uses some modern smarts to round out the corners and make a more forgiving game than those you might remember playing 15 years ago.

reviewText:
Having played all Wolfenstein games going back to the original id bombshell of the early 1990's, this particular version takes the game to new heights. The graphics and visual effects are very good and the audio is also excellent. Stealth is a major factor in survival and can be used to eliminate with great success on most of the enemy including the nasty 'Armoured Dogs' that proliferate the game. Don't try this though on any mechanised robotic device as failure will be certain and will set you back somewhat causing you to start again from the last checkpoint. (Albeit not a major problem).

Weapon options although at times limited do not seem to hinder the main character to any great degree as he is able to despatch most opposition with a minimum of fuss. Planning how you go about this is the important thing to consider as opposed to what you have to do to complete the task at hand. Bear in mind also that you need to replenished ammunition and health/armour regularly so take time to look around for possible and usually neccessary pickups, (approach and gather anything that glows for they will most likey be usable items).

You can collect 'Trophies' as well so investigate unusual looking objects and read notices on walls and desks for information (although this can be a little tedious at times when you are trying to get things done).

If you see a bed, have a sleep and you may be surprised at what happens when you do and my opening line will give you a hint as to what to expect!

The game is not open world in as much as you cannot simply move around free to do things as you wish and unlimited exploring is not an option, you go where your mission directs you and that's it!

This leads me to my main dislike, too many cutscenes that slow down gameplay. At times the player (me at least) is left saying Not another one
date: I just want to get on with the game!"\n\nI guess the creators were trying to incorporate the feeling of abject misery (the prison scenes alone will assert to that)
recommended: but may have allowed that idea to stem the flow effect as in pulling on the reigns which brings you to a grinding halt. This then gives the game a 'Build it up as you go' arrangement where you are completing missions which only help to build a small part of the next objective. For me that scenario can get a little tiresome
hoursPlayed: I am sure for others it is more than acceptable so it is all about what an individual wants and expects from a game
voteText: but these are my views and I accept that.\n\nIn conlusion (and now that I have completed the game)

reviewText: This is a game about shooting, stabbing, and strangling Nazis. In that regard and in nearly every other, this game is phenomenal. It has rock-solid shooting mechanics and well designed environments. The game does not by any means take itself seriously which I think is a good thing. You may think that because of this the plot cannot be very interesting but this is not the case. The game puts forth an entertaining and memorable plot that I enjoyed immensely. This is in my opinion the best game released in 2014 and the best first-person shooter to be released in a very long while. The protagonist is also a man with the musculature of a primate and a jaw that is the size of a dinner table. I guess that's a plus, if you're in to that sort of thing...

reviewText:
Good game.

Nice graphics. Nice environments. Nice cutscenes. Nice voice acting. Some nice guns.

Poor enemy AI (the soldiers are really stupid. They get stuck on walls. They ignore their comrades being silently shot in the head. They ignore bullets hitting stuff in front of them, when you miss. They have terrible vision). For some reason you have to stand over every dropped item and press 'E' to pick it up. You can't just run over it. It took me a while to get comfortable with this, and I missed quite a bit, because it was hidden in corpses and I had to go fishing for it. Uber mode isn't challenging enough. And there is too much health and ammunition. The silenced pistol can kill soldiers with one shot to their helmeted heads, from a long distance, which sort of makes the AR marksman sniper rifle and dual-wielding assault rifles a bit redundant, But I guess it gives people two ways to play.

I spent far too much time searching for collectables. I just wanted to get in to the game, go with the flow, but I felt obliged to waste time checking every part of the map for a side room where I might find a document or a golden object.

There is only one ending, which is fine, I don't expect every new game to have more than one. But I found the ending disappointing. There is no multiplayer, which doesn't matter because we can just go and play some other multiplayer shooting game. But it feels like all the work on the environments, models and weapons has gone to waste because you can't use them with other people.

I'd still recommend it, though. It was mostly entertaining, if a little slow-paced.

reviewText:
There's a lot of internet backlash for what I have to say is a brilliant game. I've known about the Wolfenstein series for years but  aside from a very brief playthrough of Return to Castle Wolfenstein, Wolfenstein: The New Order was the first time I payed serious attention to playing. And despite all the dissapointment from others, I say this is a great game almost undeserved of the complaining.

The levels are massive, on several maps I dropped my jaw at the scenery. Id software have gone to great lengths to make awe-inspiring scenes and even arenas for fighting. The AI itself is not stupid (mostly), i've been flanked by the rank-and-file and on higher difficulty levels I've been killed by being outsmarted by the AI (although on the opposite end I have seen soldiers stand in the middle of the floor to shoot me). This game is a love-letter not just to old-school shooters, but veterens of the Wolfenstein series as this game's story continues on from general Wolfenstein canon.

I have not finished the story yet but so far it has kept me hooked. I feel for the resistance leaders, i feel for the poor people being oppressed. There are newspaper cuttings that detail events during the Nazi regime which move me to tears. Machine Games did a good job showing how grim this world is as at one point reading these cuttings I even wondered if this Nazi-ruled world was even worth saving.

With a low-end processor (Intel i3) I can't play with the shiniest graphics. I have seen several patches of low-res texturing but  after a while it didn't bother me, the game as great and the scenery was impressive nonetheless. The cutscenes are gorgeous and the animation is of very good quality. I'd say what Machine Games have done is actually fairly clever as despite my low-end processor as I could still witness moments of some very detailed modeling. While walking around, the PC performs idle animations even if he is just a pair of arms for the most part; checking ammo, priming the weapon and adjusting the sights or playing with his knife. I did have problems getting the game to work as I needed the very latest driver for my AMD graphics card and it took me some time to find the right 64x Catalyst Control Centre for WIndows 7.

Overall I say we got what many old-school veterens want from the FPS genre: An affectionate throwback to the stuff we lost in the advancement of the shooter genre. But this game also includes modern concepts. I'm hunting for ammo, health packs and collectables while watching my ammo supply (old-school) while also shooting from cover down an iron sight (new-school).

reviewText: Wolfenstein: TNO is a fantastic continuation of the Wolfenstein franchise.  Better than Wolf 2009.  Just as good as RtCW.  It features a fantastic blend between old school shooter and modern FPS conventions.  Chiefly and critically, it's an old school shooter in that you have MANY different weapons, each suited to a different situation or enemy composition.  Couple that with the fantastic EVERYTHING else (story, graphics, art design, etc.) and Wolf TNO is the best game I've played this year (which admittedly it doesn't have much competition due to work obligations).\n\nI have been very critical of the old school shooter revival games over the last few years (Serious Sam 3 and DNF suck; Hard Reset and Shadow Warrior are great).  Wolf TNO stands as the best, head and shoulders over the others.

reviewText:
Pros:
-The game has absolutely stellar combat: It can go from Splinter Cell to Quake to COD in less than a second
-The game's atmosphere is amazing: It actually feels like you are waging a one-man war
-The game's narrative is pretty good: It can leave you feeling absolutely horrified at times
-The game's map design is pretty great: Lots of little secrets to discover
-The game is worth more than one playthrough: It has two timelines, each timeline has different secrets to find
-The game has the best end boss fight in recent memory: A perfect fusion of modern and classic boss-battling
-The guns in the game are satisfying to use: Just the right amount of kick
-The game has a kickass guitar-based soundtrack

Cons:
-The game's graphics aren't that good: Textures are pretty bad
-Insane system requirements: You NEED an i7. You might be better off just buying it on console.

All in all, if you can run the game, buy the game, or just buy a 360 and buy this game for it. This is one of those games that WILL be considered a classic not long from now. On my personal top ten list, it ranks around #3, near BioShock Infinite and Max Payne, and it beats out GTA 5 and Far Cry 4.

Score: 10/10

reviewText:
Return to castle Wolfenstein was my first true FPS game I've ever played. And it was also the game that got me into gaming.
After Wolfenstein Enemy Territory and underrated sequel to RTCW Wolfenstein 2009 (come on, it wasn't THAT bad), comes Wolfenstein: The New Order.
When I heard the news about the game, I was hyped. A lot. And now, after beating the game and almost completed hunting for achievements, all I can say is: WOW. The game is worth every $.

What I liked:
• Secrets, gold
• Story
• Nazi shooting
• Various locations
• Nazi shooting
• Weapon, health/armor upgrades, enigma codes
• Nazi shooting.

What I disliked:
• iD Tech 5 engine. Please, tell me Old Blood is the last game running on it.
• I was going to put more things here, but all of my issues are somehow connected to the engine

What I missed in the game
• Multiplayer
I understand devs wanted to make g
reat single-player experience, but multiplayer is really what I missed the most.
I had tons of fun in both RTCW multiplayer and ET (never got to play 2009's multiplayer because I had a shi**y PC back then and couldn't hit anyone with those FPS), so I hope MP will come back in future game.
• Support for custom maps
I still play some custom maps for RTCW from time to time and would love to play some for New Order, guess I can dream.

Final verdict:
If you've played RTCW and/or Wolf 2009, definitely get this. If you've never played any Wolfenstein game, it's never too late!
8.5/10

reviewText:
ok so lets get this one thing straight, this game is a Nazi killing
Simulater, also known as wolfenstein. I mean this game is just your
version of quintin terrentino's Inglorious basterds, where your character
William Bj Blazkovics is bassicaly your brad pitt from Ingloriouse ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.
Tho we all know he just the rebooted version of the preiviouse BJ, but
slighty camparable with the movie, anyways. The game Starts off in 1946, where
mr BJ blaztohats is taking on the new fortress head quaters, the Third
Riech. Only to be blasted and swallowed by the sea as he takes a piece of
Shrapnel to the face. Spends 14 years as a vegatable in a polish mental
Health institute where he meets his favorite nurse whome he falls so sexually in
lust with, ( w.e the ♥♥♥♥ her name is ).

The game works as usual picking up health and armor packs to stay afloat
as you grind your way past waves of nazis. Which btw I find it neat that
your armor is not only a flack jacket but you can pick up other armor looking
materials that give you points towards deffence. There are diffrente mechnaics
involved in combat when dealing with the variety of diffrente types of nazis.
Such as juaggernaut to the shotgun weilding soldeirs, to mechs!


The switch between stealth missions, also adds some vareirty and somewhat
serenity to the fast action killer. It allows you to actually think and pursue
your targets which happen to High ranking Officers, whome can run and sound the alarm
And wreck havoc on your mission.

Perks allow you to gain small yet unotciably bonus to the game.They are
aquired through acts of combat during the game and some perks can be easly
forgotton.I believe I looked at my perk tree, twice the entire time I played
the game, they just wernt absolutly needed, but do add some help to the gameplay.
by adding extra ammo, or allowing you to sprint faster while duel weilding.

The level design, ok This is what really got into the game.
The levels have so much detail, there is an impressive amount that went into making this
game and it shows.Idk if I can say much for the console users, but for PC
this game just looks and feels amazing. Some levels offer cookies that unlock level art
for later use to stare in awe of the massive designs that went into each level.
Even sending mr BJ to the moon at one point for some very futuristic battles with
upgraded weapons!

The laser cutter adds to the games puzzle design allowing players to actually have to think
about where to go next, or allowing players to find shortcuts or extra ammo or life in small
holes.The laser gun getting upgraded was a neat fix, so it dint seem like the same old gun
after a while, you actually can use it and have it rival with even the best of you arsenal!
i mean litteraly you can make a nazi pop like a balloon when you have it fully upgraded!

SO in all the game is a great game, deffeenitly something every gamer needs in there library.
As far as first persons go, this game is a great mix of all your favorite fps elements.
Level design keeps you in pure awe and the combat keeps you at an max
blood rusher state. So for my final review Im giving this game a 9/10!!
yes thats what it deserves and I would give it 10 but theres just one thing that I have to do,
I have to hate on something. The RESPAWN. The respawn is needs to get fix like seriously,
idk how many times iv raged over it but there needs to be something done about it cuz DAMN.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein, does anything more need to be said? This is the grandfather of shooters and this iteration brings what it promises. The game provides ample oppurtunities to mow enemies down in various ways, plus where else can you dual wield assualt rifles?

The graphics, many people complain about the textures, pop-in and quality, but honestly the game looks gorgeous. It will have you exploring the world just so you can see all the smaller details developers added in. The gameplay is solid brining what a Wolfenstein needs to bring, guns, guns and even bigger guns.

Now then, the few issues encountered can easily be solved with a patch so its not really game breaking in nature. This is one of the few games that upon launch I encountered no game breaking bugs. Which is a fresh experience in its own right.

Is the game worth $60? In my opinion, yes. If you are a Wolfenstein fan then you need to be playing this game. The developers went through a lot of trouble to bring the old school feel of previous Wolfensteins ooze from this game while at the same time making a new game.

Now to comment on story, the story of the game is interesting and some parts even cliche but it is a Wolfenstein game, if you play for the story then you should not be playing. The game alos has a perk system which is unique in that you unlock perks through actions, for example killing 10 enemies in stealth will provide a perk that makes stealth kills more deadly and efficeint.

Wolfenstein The New Order, I give 8.5/10
