reviewText:
Short:
Strongly recommended. Excellent shooter mechanics and surprisingly well written moving story. If you liked Half-life 2 you'll love this game.

Medium:
When we write the history of video games as an art form I believe this game will be remembered as a landmark for its treatment of sex. The game boldly makes it clear up front that sex is part of Blazkowicz's relationship with his love interest, yet they manage to do it in a way that elevates it from simple lust or an exploitive attempt to sell sex to a depiction of an intimate experience shared between people who truly love one another.

Long:
This game fails to live up to the legacy of previous Wolfenstein games. When I see Wolfenstein in the title of a game I think men with biceps so large they have difficulty wearing anything with longer sleeves than a muscle shirt, chin clefts so deep you could build a mineshaft in them, machismo levels so high that they punch on sight any sissy who actually uses the word machismo"
date: and ranges of emotion that lead you to suspect they've undergone a partial lobotomy. To all outward appearances this perfectly describes the protagonist William "B.J." Blazkowicz. In previous games Blazkowicz has always been little more than a 1940's Duke Nukem with just barely enough taste not to quote bad movies while killing Nazis. As a result I came into the game expecting "Generic Nazi Murder Simulator 2014". That is not what I got.\n\nThe story of Wolfenstein: The New Order as any synapses will tell you is the tale of jarhead William "B.J." Blazkowicz waking up in an alternate universe in which the Nazi have won WW2 and taken over the world. He has to lead the resistance
recommended: tear down their symbols of power
hoursPlayed: bring hope to an otherwise hopeless and dreary world
voteText: yadda yadda yadda something something Half-life 2. This is all true. However the game is in many ways Half-life 2's better in many ways. The writing is shockingly good. In inner dialogues and exchanges with his companions we occasionally glimpse something deeper and more sensitive through Blazkowicz's solemn and emotionless mask. We begin to see him not as a man who does not feel
helpfulPercent: but as a man who hides his feelings for fear that they will make him weak and destroy him. At the end of the first mission he (and thus the player) is forced by a villain to make a sort of Sophie's choice
votesHelpful: with no third option save for a gameover. It's a horrible and terrifying scene during which we see him at his most vulnerable
votesTotal: and while he doesn't show any visible emotion it clearly leaves mental scars which stay with him for the rest of the game.\n\nIt's not just his ability to feel pain the game shows us either. It's his ability to feel love. When we write the history of video games as an art form I believe this game will be remembered as a landmark for its treatment of sex. The game boldly makes it clear up front that sex is part of Blazkowicz's relationship with his love interest

reviewText:
I haven't enjoyed a FPS game as much as Wolfenstein: The New Order in a long time.  With its old school style of carrying 10 guns, duel wielding anything, and health & armor pickups it really was a refreshing break away from current shooter trends.

This iteration of Wolfenstein also added some interesting new mechanics and approaches the perk system many games incorporate in a more personal way.  Instead of leveling up and spending points on skill unlocks, Wolfenstein let's you play it your way, and specific benefits unlock as you perform certain challenges.  This way you're never pigeonholed into singular play style.  There are four style trees to shape the play that suits you best:  Stealth, Tactical, Assault, and Explosive.   You'll be doing a little of each style so it's recommended to complete as many challenges as possible to get the benefits.

The one thing that took me by surprise the most was the story.  There was actually a well written, and voice acted story behind this shooter.  It was effective in boiling my hatred for the cruel and merciless enemies, that I felt sweet revenge when piling up the Nazi body count.

This was pure old school shooter fun with modern improvements, and I'm going on record to predict a FPS Game of the Year award.

reviewText:
So. Wolfenstein. Probably not the game you'd expect to hit the some of the highest heights of storytelling that you’ll see in a game. Also probably not the game you'd expect to deliver it all with a deep and frequently creative narrative. Creative manners of evisceration, is perhaps more in line with preconceptions, but certainly not in presentation, tone and story in which The New Order excels. All of the pieces of Wolfenstein may not be new, but the manner in which it is told is debilitating fresh, and effective. Within thirty minutes, you’re hooked, with one of the most effective openings you’ll see in any form of this genre. If you couldn’t already tell, The New Order does a great deal to subvert your expectations.

By appearances, the alternate history setting of Nazi domination, complete with quazi-supernatural weapons and cement is utterly absurd, and with a lead character when initialised harks back to the Duke Nukem era, it often seems like Wolfenstein is doing all it can to undermine itself. Thankfully, elements from that setting are picked with care, highlighting and providing insightful, if not undiscovered (we've had a lot of texts about war guys) commentary on dystopia, power (or the distinct lack thereof) and universal causality. Thankfully, the game never takes itself too seriously, lest it sway too far from the somewhat pulpy  topic, managing to blend the more light-hearted elements of its roots with a sickly, cynical and all-round rather lovely tongue in it’s cheek.

Wolfenstein, and the folks over at Machine Games know how to craft a tale, and it's this presentation on which The New Order can hang its hat. It achieves levels of beauty, nuance, and depth frequently reached for by other studios, but almost as frequently lays unobtained. In contrast to practically every other game of this size, The New Order knows when to shut the hell up. Dialogue and timing is sharp and acerbic, animation is top-notch cinematography is often stunning, conveying a tremendous sense of confidence in its presentation, close to all of it earned. It’s super slick, and often a joy to expertise and partake in. Characters are strongly defined in a concise and engaging manner, setting them up to be utilized in a cacophony of intelligent and sincere personal relationships, but engage with the setting in a remarkably mature and often darkly comedic manner. While it can occasionally feel that the size of the cast being dealt with is a little too large for what is a 10 hour game, Wolfenstein is nothing if not constantly engaging, and the many twists, turns and heavy-hitting moments you encounter along the way lead up a remarkable conclusion that embodies all that this game does right.

All of this seems to forget the combat system within the game, which is, on most levels, serviceable, if not much else. The combat is pretty stock standard. You've got your iron sights, you've got your hypermobility, and you've got your moments of typical action-movie scale. A means of differentiation is the game’s dual wielding mechanic, which lets you forgo accurate aiming for, say, a couple of semi-automatic shotguns. While initially fun, it doesn’t have the legs as a core gameplay mechanic (perhaps exacerbated by the ammo shortages you’ll usually find yourself in) Stealth is usually a valid option, but you're not incentivised to go in any particular direction, as going in guns ablaze is usually equally effective, and will get you in and out in quicker time.  One criticism is the mini-bosses scattered throughout the game. These mechanised soldiers are boringly bullet-spongy, usually requiring spending a couple of minutes ducking in and out of cover, intersected with the unloading with a machine gun for a few seconds.

Thankfully, the combat is more than enjoyable enough to pull through what is one of the most effective examples of explicit storytelling within a video game. If you’re interested in what a linear experience can provide when taken in context with what is effective in other forms of media, or just want to hear what is a remarkably enjoyable and thoughtful story, The New Order is a game you shouldn't pass over.

reviewText:
I'll be honest upfront.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is, in my opinion, a game so unobtrusive that... I can't really find fault beyond nitpicks. It's a very competent shooter with a surprisingly well acted story. I'll even say that this is one of the few games that actually sold me on the obligatory love subplot. This kinda surprised me, coming from a game that is, at it's core, 'there's a nazi, shoot him'.

I did mention a few Nitpicks, and in no real order:

The split timeline 'mechanic' is... Not really explored. There's only maybe one level that actually changes due to your choice. Minor changes thanks to a tiny minigame, but they're... Generally not used for anything but secret items. There's no change in enemies and no change in weaponry... So it feels tacked on.

Some enemies are grossly bullet spongey, even on 'normal' difficulty. The game has about 4 or so points where you will see that loading screen an asninine number of times because some INCREDIBLY heavily armored jerk murders you. They don't even have to reload! The normal guys do (Or at least they take breaks between bursts). Maybe a future patch will fix it and I'll be able to scrape this off the list of minor irks. Don't take me wrong, The game can be finished... But that final level is REAL annoying.

Finally... If you're the kind of person that goes 'Oooh, Alternate history!' (Like me) and go to look for all the changes, you'll be as disapointed as I was to find out the alternate history tracks from the trailers is basically your lot. I do understand that licensing and recording and junk... But it was a let down none the less not to hear something like an alternate Rolling Stones or The Kinks ('Sie haben mich wirklich' anyone? Just me?)


Oh. And some levels are quite linear. But hey, fish swim, birds fly, levels in 2014 are quite linear.


There. That's really all I got. It's not a back-to-basics shooter in the vein of the original... But it takes just enough from it in such a competent manner that it's worth getting.

reviewText:
Ok so i got this game for approx 10 USD and i have mixed feelings of this game. It is a good game however it has a good amount of issues with it that makes me want to yell at the devs. So on to the pros and cons.

Pros-
- Stealth or guns blazing approach
-Variety of weapons
-Awesome cutscenes and good voice acting
-Good gore looks amazing
-World looks really nice and has many different approaches to complete a level
-Nice bonding of characters
-Great Nostalgia sequence in reference to Wolfenstein 3D
-Nice amount of replayablity and item scavenging
-Good deaths of people (ex Nazi head cut with chainsaw and another by helicopter blades)

Cons
-Terrible Final boss So easy and super cliche
-Map layout isnt very helpful and confuses you
- Texture popin frequently
-Constant frame drops and stuttering ( My pc can easily handle this see specs on my profile)
-Enemy variety is new but some are to easy and others are to hard (ex Giant robots)
-sterotypical level designs dont offer any amazing levels other than the opening plane jump scene
-NO HITLER What the butt is that
-Ai cant hear silenced shot even if you miss their head 7 times
-Not all characters fleshed out
-LITERALLY Sloth character straight out of goonies film

I did enjoy this game however it had a ton of issues i really hated. Never the less i do enjoy a good shootem up game and believe that if the sequel New blood fixes some of these problems then it can be a great game

I give Wolfenstein The New order a 7.2/10

reviewText:
Out of all the shooting games I have played this has to be the one I have enjoyed the most. Not just because I am killing thousands of nazi's but the art and graphic style - Oh my god! Its beautiful. I have never played a Wolfenstein game before and actually got this due to the graphics resembling the Bioshock series. I am glad I had the oppertunity to play this gem. War, violence, sex, guns, robots and the freaking moon walking and moon weapons all created something fantastic with a greater story line to slot it all together. You also get to visit Berlin, London and many exciting locations in this alternative universe.

This game has everything. Classic mini games, hidden items, back stories, classic sewer levels, castles, insane asylums, the moon, characters you can love and hate and when i say hate, i mean really hate. DAMN YOU DEATHSHEAD. YOU RUINED EVERYTHING THAT SHOULD OF BEEN....

At the start you have to make a very difficult choice that effects the game, meaning I now have to go play again and see what alternative story I have missed. WHICH IS AWESOME.

I would definatly recommend this game if not for the amusing points and violent gun play, but for the parts that make you ♥♥♥♥ your pants when a robot dog jumps out to grind you up.

Verdict: Buy this game if you're not a pansy!

reviewText:
Not really a wolfenstein game, but it's still really good.

I give it a 7/10

+Great graphics & effects (bloody as hell)
+Fun gameplay
+Long campaign, took me about 9 hours to complete (Also has an alternate timeline, depending on your choices, but it is basically the same story)
+Good story
+Cool cutting mechanic for the laser gun thing
+Character development of Blazkowicz fits his Nazi killing style
+Good AI
+Easter egg where you get to play the first level of Wolfenstein 3D, sucky graphics and all, but with the new weapons.

-Due to the long campaign it can get repetitive at times
-Doesn't feel like a Wolfenstein game, too much duel weilding mayhem
-Forced fighting in some levels, instead of being able to use stealth
-No multiplayer
-Can no longer kick things above head
-Story seems a little far fetched at times (such as the badass grandparents hell bent on killing nazis, which makes no sense at all)
-Story has a lot of unnecessary slow moments (finding lost toys, cutting a chunk of moldy brick, falling into a sewer)
-The weapons I liked the most were only in the game for the first mission and never used again (Thompson sub-machine gun)
-60 bucks is a lot to ask for a singleplayer only game
-Textures load slowly, but not as bad as Rage
-Low replayability
-43.5 GB file size

I would also like to mention that I played this game on the lowest graphics settings, using a Radeon HD 6850, which is the graphics card listed on the minimum requirements. It ran at around 50-60 FPS, but looked like absolute crap (as expected for low graphics). Textures also loaded very slow when doing a quick spin, sometimes certain textures took 5-6 seconds to load.

I bought it for 30 dollars in the summer sale, and I believe it was worth that price. However, I would not recommend it for the current price of 59.99.

reviewText:
Short:
Strongly recommended. Excellent shooter mechanics and surprisingly well written moving story. If you liked Half-life 2 you'll love this game.

Medium:
When we write the history of video games as an art form I believe this game will be remembered as a landmark for its treatment of sex. The game boldly makes it clear up front that sex is part of Blazkowicz's relationship with his love interest, yet they manage to do it in a way that elevates it from simple lust or an exploitive attempt to sell sex to a depiction of an intimate experience shared between people who truly love one another.

Long:
This game fails to live up to the legacy of previous Wolfenstein games. When I see Wolfenstein in the title of a game I think men with biceps so large they have difficulty wearing anything with longer sleeves than a muscle shirt, chin clefts so deep you could build a mineshaft in them, machismo levels so high that they punch on sight any sissy who actually uses the word machismo"
date: and ranges of emotion that lead you to suspect they've undergone a partial lobotomy. To all outward appearances this perfectly describes the protagonist William "B.J." Blazkowicz. In previous games Blazkowicz has always been little more than a 1940's Duke Nukem with just barely enough taste not to quote bad movies while killing Nazis. As a result I came into the game expecting "Generic Nazi Murder Simulator 2014". That is not what I got.\n\nThe story of Wolfenstein: The New Order as any synapses will tell you is the tale of jarhead William "B.J." Blazkowicz waking up in an alternate universe in which the Nazi have won WW2 and taken over the world. He has to lead the resistance
recommended: tear down their symbols of power
hoursPlayed: bring hope to an otherwise hopeless and dreary world
voteText: yadda yadda yadda something something Half-life 2. This is all true. However the game is in many ways Half-life 2's better in many ways. The writing is shockingly good. In inner dialogues and exchanges with his companions we occasionally glimpse something deeper and more sensitive through Blazkowicz's solemn and emotionless mask. We begin to see him not as a man who does not feel
helpfulPercent: but as a man who hides his feelings for fear that they will make him weak and destroy him. At the end of the first mission he (and thus the player) is forced by a villain to make a sort of Sophie's choice
votesHelpful: with no third option save for a gameover. It's a horrible and terrifying scene during which we see him at his most vulnerable
votesTotal: and while he doesn't show any visible emotion it clearly leaves mental scars which stay with him for the rest of the game.\n\nIt's not just his ability to feel pain the game shows us either. It's his ability to feel love. When we write the history of video games as an art form I believe this game will be remembered as a landmark for its treatment of sex. The game boldly makes it clear up front that sex is part of Blazkowicz's relationship with his love interest
votesFunny: yet they manage to do it in a way that elevates it from simple lust or an exploitive attempt to sell sex to a depiction of an intimate experience shared between people who truly love one another. While she initially appears to be a vulnerable maiden in distress
commentsCount: over the course of the game we begin to see that she is in many ways Blazkowicz's counterpart. Just Blazkowicz conceals sensitive soul inside a warriors body
column16: we learn that she conceals a warriors soul inside her fragile exterior.\n\nThe ending is also not what you'd call typical of stereotypical FPS games. I don't want to spoil it because it's actually quite moving. Oh and the FPS bits are quite nice too."

reviewText:
Ok so i got this game for approx 10 USD and i have mixed feelings of this game. It is a good game however it has a good amount of issues with it that makes me want to yell at the devs. So on to the pros and cons.

Pros-
- Stealth or guns blazing approach
-Variety of weapons
-Awesome cutscenes and good voice acting
-Good gore looks amazing
-World looks really nice and has many different approaches to complete a level
-Nice bonding of characters
-Great Nostalgia sequence in reference to Wolfenstein 3D
-Nice amount of replayablity and item scavenging
-Good deaths of people (ex Nazi head cut with chainsaw and another by helicopter blades)

Cons
-Terrible Final boss So easy and super cliche
-Map layout isnt very helpful and confuses you
- Texture popin frequently
-Constant frame drops and stuttering ( My pc can easily handle this see specs on my profile)
-Enemy variety is new but some are to easy and others are to hard (ex Giant robots)
-sterotypical level designs dont offer any amazing levels other than the opening plane jump scene
-NO HITLER What the butt is that
-Ai cant hear silenced shot even if you miss their head 7 times
-Not all characters fleshed out
-LITERALLY Sloth character straight out of goonies film

I did enjoy this game however it had a ton of issues i really hated. Never the less i do enjoy a good shootem up game and believe that if the sequel New blood fixes some of these problems then it can be a great game

I give Wolfenstein The New order a 7.2/10

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order. A game that had me somewhat worried after hearing some really bad thing about it during E3, Bethseda being the publisher and a new studio making this new entry to the Wolfenstein franchise and now that it is released i decided i would get it instantly anyway, cause of curiosity. Now that i finished my first playthrough i can safely say that this is the best game released so far.
It gives you the Old school shooting, if not more insane than it's previous entries and a damn good story. Like a mix of old Wolfenstein and Inglorious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

The game is roughly 11-15 hours long with the possibility for some different approaches on the levels with some hidden secrets here and there and offers 2 different options you do at the beginning that changes the overall story completley, making it worth it to play through it twice.

The game has some problems but just minor, you occasionally encounter some of the worst AI in the game during stealth" levels but these moments are mostly short and does not really take away from the overall gameplay. Second is some optimising issues

reviewText: actual goty 2014\n\nLike i'm not even joking or being sarcastic, this is the finest game I played all year and I played pretty much everything. reviewText: The Wolfenstein franchise is a strange beast. For something that has been bounced around between developers and publishers as much as it has, it has been remarkably consistent. The New Order is the fifth game in the series (not counting multiplayer only Enemy Territory), and they all share a continued continuity, to the point that a character from Raven’s Wolfenstein from a few years ago is in this game despite the developer and publisher changing between releases. For 2014, Wolfenstein is in the capable hands of MachineGames, a group headed up by ex-Starbreeze employees that were at the forefront of story driven FPS games of the last decade. Their talents have transferred over here, bringing stealth and moments of calm to a universe most known for its nonstop Nazi killing. It all comes together into a stunning mixture of engaging story and visceral gunplay that will leave you wanting more as the end credits roll.\n\nWant more? My full review is available over at Geekenstein.com. http://www.geekenstein.com/wolfenstein-new-order-review/

reviewText:
Like many of you (probably), I grew up playing things like Wolf 3D, Doom, Duke 3D, Rise of the Triad, Blake Stone, Hexen, Heretic. That's out of order and I think I did manage to avoid Quake somehow, but whatever. I was something like 4? I did this until I was around 8-10 and my parents got me a N64 instead of a computer so I got into Mario, Zelda, the usuals. so I've been out of the FPS loop for awhile. Just starting in 2012 or so did I really start diving into the Bioshocks, Metros, Singularity, I even gave Wolf 09 a spin. I enjoyed most all of them except Singularity, haha. Unfortunately, never a Starbreeze game. So even though I was hopeful for this title I didn't really know what I was getting into with that pedigree thrown around since it doesn't mean much to me. But I was hopeful regardless, and it looks like my blind faith paid off pretty well.

It's really fun to kill Nazis. Not really a better way to put it. Watching them fall apart as you overwhelm them, using all the different weaponry, scoping from cover or guns blazing, or clearing out a whole floor with a silenced approach was pretty great. Even though it was highly useful for my Uber playthrough, I wish the thrown knifes and silenced pistol weren't so broken. I ended up avoiding using the pistol in the later half of the game because it was so boring. The knives were similar but a notch harder to acquire and aim so I used that whenever I felt like it. I love how the perks reward you for playing the game in multiple ways, instead of just being acquired skill poiints into a tree or something. It was a little distracting and silly when I found myself failing a checkpoint so that I could work on different perks, but that's on me I suppose. One of my favorites was the one that healed you for doing the melee takedowns. Something satisfying about gunning down a nazi and not wanting to wait for the reload animation so I would just run up to him, slit his throat. and get some health back. Once I learned how powerful the scoped LKW was, that was also and enjoyable tool in the arsenal.

The game starts with some really open map design which gives you a lot of freedom to do those things I mention. However, somewhere around chapter 10-11 it ends up becoming a bit more straightforward, where the game seems to send you from arena" to arena. This is still really fun
date: and a lot of the encounters have enough paths and levels that it doesn't feel constricting. It was just not as good as the first handful of chapters in this respect. However
recommended: I do think that the later locations are much more interesting in general. Chapter 12

reviewText: Wolfenstein is a story driven FPS in the vain of Half-Life 2. The shooting is fun, the story segments tie together well, and don't take you out of the action. The violence is satifying, and graphic, avoid if that isn't your thing. The first chapters do a good job at making you feel like a badass and encourage you to try diffrent playstyles. Unfortunatlly in the last half of the game the it becomes a slog, where enduring bullet sponge badguys is the norm. It would be a top game for me, if it wasn't for the difficulty and bullet sponge bad guys at the end that prevent you from really enjoying a fun ride.

reviewText:
Wow, just wow. Blown away. The Swedish team at MachineGames has a nice pedigree for me. The founders are from Starbreeze Studios, they were the key members that made Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay and The Darkness, two shooters that did very well and are some of my favorite story driven FPSs.

I was hoping they would put Wolfenstein back where it belongs, at the top. I really liked Rage and the direction it was taking but it was lacking something. MachineGames found out what that something was and Wolfenstein The New Order has that classic shooter feel without feeling stiff."

Story: The story is fantastic and the characters are all memorable. What stood out the most was the way they portrayed B. J. Blazkowicz (the main protagonist). He was the main character from the original Wolfenstein 3d also and I feel they couldn’t have portrayed him better. I love his monologues. Also I liked how there are 2 timelines. Depending on a what choice you make in the beginning the game will feel a little different. That was also a nice touch. I won't say more than that though.

Gameplay: The guns are great. They feel awesome and they are different and shine when you use them at the right time. Brings back the feeling from classic shooters when you used different weapons for different enemies to conserve ammo. You could run through the game with the assault rifle but you would run out of ammo a lot I feel. There are also gun upgrades you come across when you play through the campaign. These upgrades are also kept across playthroughs. Also the dual wielding is lots of fun. Running through tight corridors dual wielding auto shotguns splattering Nazis faces along the way felt good. The perk progression is cleverly organic and is based on your play style. As you you play
date: the way you kill and the weapons you use unlock perks that give you passive bonuses. The perks are little things like faster sprint while dual wielding
hoursPlayed:
etc. After completing the game the perks remain in effect giving you a chance to survive on Uber difficulty.

AI: There were a few times the AI was a little derp but it more often was deviously efficient in putting the pressure on. I played the game on “I Am Death Incarnate!” (a step above normal) and there were plenty of times the AI put me down with well timed flanking and pressure. After beating the game I went to the chapter select (hell yeah!) and tried a few of the easier difficulties and the enemies seem to go down faster but aside from that were still lethal.

Sound: The music is awesome and feels like a classic id game. You got nice metal tracks to kill Nazis to. The sound effects were awesome and the voice acting was well done and made all the characters more memorable.

Graphics: Wow
voteText: 40 gb not wasted. The game is gorgeous. I don't know what the game looks like on consoles and I haven't a single **** to give. On the master platform this game is fantastic looking and runs a lot better than Rage. I’m running 2 GTX 780 TIs in sli. I turned off sli and ran the game on Ultra w/vsync to see how it played. A few times I had to restart from a checkpoint the game would lag (frame rate tanked to like 2) as the textures tried to catch up. Enabling VT Compress in the advanced graphics options fixed this issue. I did not have this issue while in SLI (more graphic mem to go around). To be honest I couldn’t tell the difference with VT Compress on or off. The game is breathtakingly beautiful

reviewText:
Now that I have completed the game twice I think I'm ready for a review :)

You know, it must be really challenging to make a game with an over 20 year franchise history. There's always a chance that  it won't be good enough for bunch of reasons.. hell, I myself didn't really like the previous Wolfenstein game though I'm a big fan of shooters. I grew up on id software games. Wolfenstein 3D and Spear of Destiny were among the first games I ever played and remain one of my favorites for the rest of my life. So I was really sceptical about this game but God knows I was wrong...

This game is really darn good. You understand that developers knew what they were doing from the very beginning, which means when you get to the main menu to choose your difficulty you realise that this trip is going to be veeery awesome. And it really is! Everything about this game is near perfect: plot, graphics, gore/blood, dialogues, cut-scenes, jokes, easter eggs etc. Even the main character, B.J. Blatzkowizc, is slightly resembling the old one despite all the modern graphics!

I can only point out two minor things which in my opinion mar the impression of the game a little:
- ragdoll behavior, which sometimes made me burst out laughting
- floating objects (seen two times through the game. I guess it's a common thing in modern games like Metro: Last Light)

Anyway this stuff is so rare that you just don't pay attention to it at all.

I recommend this game to everyone no matter if you fan of the franchise or not. If you are you will be pleasantly surprised and if you're new to the franchise then you'll enjoy the very well-made game.

And I enjoyed every second of it. 10/10

reviewText:
Wow, just wow. Blown away. The Swedish team at MachineGames has a nice pedigree for me. The founders are from Starbreeze Studios, they were the key members that made Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay and The Darkness, two shooters that did very well and are some of my favorite story driven FPSs.

I was hoping they would put Wolfenstein back where it belongs, at the top. I really liked Rage and the direction it was taking but it was lacking something. MachineGames found out what that something was and Wolfenstein The New Order has that classic shooter feel without feeling stiff."

Story: The story is fantastic and the characters are all memorable. What stood out the most was the way they portrayed B. J. Blazkowicz (the main protagonist). He was the main character from the original Wolfenstein 3d also and I feel they couldn’t have portrayed him better. I love his monologues. Also I liked how there are 2 timelines. Depending on a what choice you make in the beginning the game will feel a little different. That was also a nice touch. I won't say more than that though.

Gameplay: The guns are great. They feel awesome and they are different and shine when you use them at the right time. Brings back the feeling from classic shooters when you used different weapons for different enemies to conserve ammo. You could run through the game with the assault rifle but you would run out of ammo a lot I feel. There are also gun upgrades you come across when you play through the campaign. These upgrades are also kept across playthroughs. Also the dual wielding is lots of fun. Running through tight corridors dual wielding auto shotguns splattering Nazis faces along the way felt good. The perk progression is cleverly organic and is based on your play style. As you you play
date: the way you kill and the weapons you use unlock perks that give you passive bonuses. The perks are little things like faster sprint while dual wielding
hoursPlayed:
etc. After completing the game the perks remain in effect giving you a chance to survive on Uber difficulty.

AI: There were a few times the AI was a little derp but it more often was deviously efficient in putting the pressure on. I played the game on “I Am Death Incarnate!” (a step above normal) and there were plenty of times the AI put me down with well timed flanking and pressure. After beating the game I went to the chapter select (hell yeah!) and tried a few of the easier difficulties and the enemies seem to go down faster but aside from that were still lethal.

Sound: The music is awesome and feels like a classic id game. You got nice metal tracks to kill Nazis to. The sound effects were awesome and the voice acting was well done and made all the characters more memorable.

Graphics: Wow
voteText: 40 gb not wasted. The game is gorgeous. I don't know what the game looks like on consoles and I haven't a single **** to give. On the master platform this game is fantastic looking and runs a lot better than Rage. I’m running 2 GTX 780 TIs in sli. I turned off sli and ran the game on Ultra w/vsync to see how it played. A few times I had to restart from a checkpoint the game would lag (frame rate tanked to like 2) as the textures tried to catch up. Enabling VT Compress in the advanced graphics options fixed this issue. I did not have this issue while in SLI (more graphic mem to go around). To be honest I couldn’t tell the difference with VT Compress on or off. The game is breathtakingly beautiful
helpfulPercent: I cant stress this enough. I’m in love with the idT5 engine and I cant wait to pay Doom (4).\n\nLets be honest
votesHelpful: I bought Zone of the Enders 2 for the MGS: Sons of Liberty demo and this this is not very different. I had a feeling this game was going to be awesome but what sealed the deal for me was the Doom Beta. I am pleasantly surprised by how good this game is above my expectations. It stands on it own as one of my favorite Story Driven FPSs of all time. I was expecting a 7-8/10 and I got a 9/10. I feel the people at MachineGames knocked this one out of the park. I will keep an eye on this studio and impatiently await their next title.\n\nThanks for reading

reviewText:
Like many of you (probably), I grew up playing things like Wolf 3D, Doom, Duke 3D, Rise of the Triad, Blake Stone, Hexen, Heretic. That's out of order and I think I did manage to avoid Quake somehow, but whatever. I was something like 4? I did this until I was around 8-10 and my parents got me a N64 instead of a computer so I got into Mario, Zelda, the usuals. so I've been out of the FPS loop for awhile. Just starting in 2012 or so did I really start diving into the Bioshocks, Metros, Singularity, I even gave Wolf 09 a spin. I enjoyed most all of them except Singularity, haha. Unfortunately, never a Starbreeze game. So even though I was hopeful for this title I didn't really know what I was getting into with that pedigree thrown around since it doesn't mean much to me. But I was hopeful regardless, and it looks like my blind faith paid off pretty well.

It's really fun to kill Nazis. Not really a better way to put it. Watching them fall apart as you overwhelm them, using all the different weaponry, scoping from cover or guns blazing, or clearing out a whole floor with a silenced approach was pretty great. Even though it was highly useful for my Uber playthrough, I wish the thrown knifes and silenced pistol weren't so broken. I ended up avoiding using the pistol in the later half of the game because it was so boring. The knives were similar but a notch harder to acquire and aim so I used that whenever I felt like it. I love how the perks reward you for playing the game in multiple ways, instead of just being acquired skill poiints into a tree or something. It was a little distracting and silly when I found myself failing a checkpoint so that I could work on different perks, but that's on me I suppose. One of my favorites was the one that healed you for doing the melee takedowns. Something satisfying about gunning down a nazi and not wanting to wait for the reload animation so I would just run up to him, slit his throat. and get some health back. Once I learned how powerful the scoped LKW was, that was also and enjoyable tool in the arsenal.

The game starts with some really open map design which gives you a lot of freedom to do those things I mention. However, somewhere around chapter 10-11 it ends up becoming a bit more straightforward, where the game seems to send you from arena" to arena. This is still really fun
date: and a lot of the encounters have enough paths and levels that it doesn't feel constricting. It was just not as good as the first handful of chapters in this respect. However
recommended: I do think that the later locations are much more interesting in general. Chapter 12

reviewText:
I’ll be honest, I didn’t expect much from Wolfenstein: The New Order. Since its announcement, there was a certain level of uncertainty surrounding the game; the public’s expectations were a little low, myself included, and there didn’t seem to be a lot of buzz behind it.

The FPS genre has its fair share of mediocre, uninspired, and vanilla shooters where the act of shooting bad guys becomes tiresome and uninteresting. Having little experience with the Wolfenstein series, I feared that any redeemable aspects of the game would go over my head as feelings of nostalgia from referential content would be lost on me. Admittedly, there were a lot of pessimistic feelings entering the game. But I’m happy to say I underestimated Wolfenstein: The New Order – what I expected to be just another shooter turned out to be a very solid one with a surprisingly emotional and intelligent story.

Quite frankly, it is one of the best shooters I’ve played in recent memory. With quality action, an emotional story, and likeable characters, Wolfenstein: The New Order is a smart shooter that pulls no punches.

full review: http://www.relyonhorror.com/reviews/review-wolfenstein-the-new-order/

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is not a very intelligent game.  Neither were any of the Wolfenstein games, matter of fact.  I remember back in 2004 when I was but a child, my Pops let me play Wolfenstein 3D on my old now-gone computer with that old, late '90s computer monitor...it was one of the greatest gaming experiences of my life and I will never forget it.  Hell, I even bought the damn game on Steam just for memories sake.  Fast-forward to now, and I got the entire collection of Wolfenstein games, (except for Wolfenstein 2009) I finally played Retrun to Castle Wolfenstein and loved it.

I actually didn't pay for this game.  While I was on vacation in America about a month ago, my Dad (being a fan of Wolfenstein 3D) bought The New Order for PC at a Gamestop, and after a few awkward moments relating to a drive-in ATM, we got back home and my Dad really wanted me to play The New Order too, so I could enjoy the game as much as he.  At first, we had no idea how to get the bloody thing on to my Steam account.  After a while, one little Google search got us to what we actually needed to do.  We had to link both of out Steam accounts just so I could play it, and it worked swimmingly!  And here I am, playing the newest entry to this series of Nazi killing, gun-toting adventures involving torture, the holocaust, evil....and of course, Nazis.

When I first booted the game up on my newly purchased Alien-Ware laptop, it worked surprisingly well on my high-end gaming laptop.  The game runs of the Id Engine 5, which happens to be the same engine that ran RAGE, and looks a hell of a lot better than that massive disapointment of a game, but that's a game to review at another time.  The textures look all right, with some minor pop-in issues, but they're not too distracting.  The lighting's great and adds to the atmosphere to the overall game-world and works incredibly well in the areas where you are situated in castle-like enviroments.  And the character models look really nice and well-detailes along with nice realistic facial animations that totally don't have the uncanny valley effect at all, and I'm not being sarcastic either.  So yeah, nice looking game.

As I was playing the first part of the game thats set in good 'ol 1946, when World War II was totally raging on by that point in time, and I was having a rollicking good time blowing the Nazi's heads off while going nuts with a mounted machine gun.  The gameplay is satisfying, ridiculous and friggin' fun.  This game is Bullet Storm and Shadow Warrior levels of fun and stupidity, and it has that classic Wolfenstein spirit that both Return and 3D had all those years ago, but with a modern twist and it is glorious!  I have never, in all of my gaming days ever thought I would hear a video game character say damn Nazi spaceman" but now I have.  And what FPS lets you old two shotguns in both hands while blowing Nazi's heads off while guiding an angry scotsman out of a prison cell?  Not Call of Duty
date: that's for damn sure.  And the health system!  My God the health system!  It's like Quake all over again!  Not only can you only get health back from medpacks
recommended: but you don't have to do that stupid tactic that modern FPS games have been making you do for years; the stop & pop tactic that you seemingly have no choice but to use.  Here
hoursPlayed: in Wolfenstein: The New Order
voteText: we don't do that stop & pop crap here.  We actually respect the player's intelligence and expect the player to explore the map
helpfulPercent: find health packs to stay alive
votesHelpful: and be hardcore.  Health only regenerates a small iota of your health and that's all.  No hand-holding and no arrows on the screen telling you where to go on this ride.\n\nSeriosuly
votesTotal: I could go on and on about how happy I am about the old-school health mechanic
votesFunny: because I have been complaining like an old man saying "Back in my day
commentsCount: we didn't have these fancy-pants regeneration systems and cover...we used out bare-boned skill and wits to fight the enemy and take back Mother RussI-" and so on.  Another thing I absolutely love is how you have practically no limit to the amount of weapons you can carry.  You can carry as much weapons as you please except for the heavy mounted machine/lazer guns.  It's been years since I have played a game where you have no limit to your arsenal...no limit to the amount of killing machines that you would have in your inventory.\n\nAnd then there's the story.  It's a very basic alternate history game where the main character of all the Wolfenstein games; B.J. Blazkowicz fights his way through a castle in 1946 to kill a man named Deathshead

reviewText: Finally got around to playing this, and I'm glad I did. Fantastic soundtrack, looks sharp and plays very solidly. Nothing here is revolutionary, but W:tNO knows what it wants to do and does it very well. The story and characters are actually suprisingly well-written too; undeniably a bit cartoony, but engaging and alive. I certainly connected more with the characters here than in many larger AAA games of late. Sometimes a bunch of very skilled people come together and make a game that brims with excellence, tight and solid from beginning to end. That is this game. Buy it. You won't be sorry. Just be sure you have 40 gigs free for the textures and a beefy CPU.

Wolfenstein! How can it be bad? One of the more bad to the bone shooters I've ever played. You can dual wield almost any weapon and rip through nazi's like a sawblade of hurt. The enemies are all nazi's so if you are jewish you should really get your money's worth out of this. The nazi mind controlled dogs are wicked and the big ♥♥♥ nazi robot death machines are awesome. The level design is great: levels are a lot of fun to navigate and fight your way through. However once you've played the game there isn't much reason to play through again because it is what it is. But the one trip you take is a really fun ride. I am enjoying cranking up my 5.1 surround system and mowing down enemies like a whirlwind of pain. The game is made really well despite some slight performance issues. I have to turn off in-game vsync because it causes horrible stuttering and force it through nvidia control panel then the game runs smooth.

The graphics are great and the sound is very good. The music is fitting and the game flows well in terms of both gameplay and story. The game is completely badass in every way. Dual wielding assault rifles and blowing away everything in sight never gets old.

Getting to bang a hot chick in cutscenes and see her half naked 10/10
Overall 8/10

reviewText:
Ok first thing’s first, this is NOT a remake, it’s not even a reimagining, this game appears to happen roughly in the same universe as the original Woflenstine but it is it’s own game.

Visually it is a vast improvement over iD’s last title Rage though they appear to be using an updated version of the same engine.  You will see some Unreal engine style texture pop-ins, which is a shame in this day and age, however it runs very well and for what it is the game still looks good and has some very nice visuals.  Levels have some level of destruction; at least of cover so there is that upgrade, pillars, barriers, certain types of metal sheets can all be gradually broken and shot through different methods.  There is a minor cover system, akin to FarCry 3’s system where you can pop out or over something if you get into the correct position which helps during combat.  There are modeled and skinned in damage indicators for enemy troops, and given that this is a iD game expect some gibs, limbs, some pretty brutal cut scenes, and fair quick but significant take down animations some are quite visceral.

There is a stealth mechanic and depending on your play style you may simply favor running and gunning which, given the fact that you can dual wield almost every weapon in the game you have enough firepower in your hands.  However if you wish to avoid as much attention and fighting as possible, or you enjoy watching the stealth kill animations then you can, at times it’s more beneficial to do so as a fair amount of the enemies in W:NO pixel hunt or are just extremely accurate even while running or moving around.  However stealth wise they tend to be both blind or severely impaired, while at the same time incredibly hyper sensitive to anything and unfortunately the cause varies, the stealth over all can be very forgiving, which is good because there is NO QUICK SAVE!  That is unfortunately correct, there is no quick save in this PC game, I do not understand why this was not added in but the actual developers Machinehead Games really screwed up with this omission.  If you die part of the way through an engagement you will probably not be able to start where you’d like and sometimes you have to do entire sections over again, other times the auto save places a spot right after.  You will need to learn from your mistakes or trial and error it unfortunately; however there are only a few sections in the entire game where I can honestly say that I had trouble with.

There is a leveling up/skill tree system for this game and for the most part it flows quite well.  There are requirements that you have to meet in order to move onto the next branch or in order to meet a requirement for a skill that is not actually connected to a previous skill.  These vary from performing take downs, throwing back grenades, killing a certain amount of enemies while dual wielding weapons, silent kills with throwing knives, and so on.  Some of the requirements however are for the most part nothing but grinding and putting yourself into situation that you would normally not put yourself into AND the game very rarely actually uses this kind of attack which defeats the purpose of requiring it, so you will have to find work around for these unfortunately.  Luckily the forums on Steam are fairly helpful and I know of two skill points that I didn’t know if I would be able to do them that I was actually able to pull off fairly easily by cheating the system, but not actually cheating mind you, simply the description on many of them is vague and the requirements can be met in different ways then what is actually written in the game.

One other major fault is the totally not old school mechanic of having to manually pick up items one by one.  Picture this, you’ve expended your assault rifle ammo and you’re in a semi arena still rife with bad guys, well in W:NO you need to crack open boxes and constantly be looking at the floor for dead bodies so you can rapidly press your use key in order to pick things up.  I can not understand what they were trying to do with this; I can maybe understand it for the gold items, intel and other collectables but NOT armor, health and ammo.  This gets worse when you have to fight the last boss, since every enemy in the game has pin point accuracy you have to continually run and “dodge” in order to juke his shots and on top of that you need to scramble around looking for health, ammo and armor pick ups in boxes and frantically press your use key in order to pick them up.  I have to wonder if Bethesda had anything to do with this choise since, as I recall, you picked up items manually in many of their games; the difference being however that unlike say Oblivion you are not dodging bullets in frantic fights.

The story and characters are pretty well done and there is a single point where you make one decision that will alter what doors you can interact with and that is all, there are no alternative story arcs.  This is fine because the story is fairly good, at least when compared to past Woflenstine titles, the characters and B.J. are the main focus of most cutscenes as well as minor story additions when you are back at the main base.  B.J. is far more fleshed out in this version of him then in any of the past games, while he may seem to be just a muscle head they make him out to be fairly intelligent and kind.  Each side character has their own story line and you will get bits and pieces of it as the game progresses which is a welcome addition as it further fleshes out that person.  While nothing ground breaking happens during these lulls in the fighting it’s defiantly a welcome addition.

The weapons feel and sound quite good and the skill upgrades add some flavors to them that help in dealing with some of the more heavily armored enemies.  Though speaking of enemies some of the armored human units like the shotgunners are just damn annoying and practically a mini boss, their shotguns ricochet off surfaces and do insane amounts of damage in a short amount of time.  There is usually one extra attachment for each weapon, though one in particular has several through the entire game.  The real benefit to the skill columns is that you can gain all of them and go back and start a new game, getting the benefits which will enable you to play with a different playstyle then you would have before.

Both the sound effects and the music are very fitting for the game type, the weapon sounds are very good and have a plenty of oomph behind them, the shotgun being one of my favorites, it sounds like the part.  The music was actually better then I expected, and it changes from stealth to active engagement when stealth is broken.  Each level has its own music score and they all sound very different from each other, sort of giving them even more of their own personality.

Being a Wolfenstine game the developers saw fit to go back to the roots and added a fair amount of collectables, gold items, intel, music, letters and audio logs.  If you’re a completionist then you will get some extra hours trying to fine every single item, which for me added to about 36 hours total play time.  Granted this game is only single player thus some people may say it’s not nearly enough content given how large the game really is, 40 gigs is never something to sneeze at.  There is some talk about adding a few extra levels, maybe multiplayer or something; however it is all just hearsay.

For $60 full price I might be hard pressed to suggest a game like this, however given that it did give me 36 hours, it’s not a hard sell I would say however that if you are at all on the fence about the price versus the content then I would wait for a sale, after that it will be well worth it.  Either way I had fun with it and I hope they will continue in some way, this also gives me some hope as to what Doom could possibly be like.

reviewText: Okay, im going to be honest before this review, I had never played a Wolfenstein before this one. The thing that got me for this was the trailer and the hype.\nOkay, now to the game, the game is rather fast paced, which could have you sneaking around picking off enemies, or dual-wielding your way through the gates of whatever lies ahead. I enjoyed the game, I would say it has replay value, and it has around a 13-16 hour campaign. I feel as if the campaign was greatly developed, as well as the characters. The characters dont have much of a backstory honestly, but they dont feel like useless NPC's who take up space.\nA few downsides towards the game of which I have found are; The AI is a bit derpy, they don't see you most of the time (though i only played on medium so could be an advantage), and other than that, the price. The game is a great game and all, but a $60US/$80AUD pricetag is a bit pricey for a game like Wolfenstein. IT IS a good game, but the price is rather over the top. But it was easy to find cheaper around the net, so if you're thinking of getting this game, get it, you wont be disappointed.

reviewText:
I have been a fan of Wolfenstein since the first time I ever played it. I started mostly with Return to Castle Wolfenstein, pretty much the godfather of FPS's and worked my way through the games as I could to the, I think, 2009 game that some people didn't like, which I may say I did like.  Now let me get this out of the way and this is mostly just a heads up for some people, I bought the retail copy so I got disks, the box had 4 disks in it, which I thought was weird for a 40+ gig game and for good reason, if you get the retail copy you will still need to download 10+ gigs, I think it was like 10.7 or something, I cannot remember.  I understand some people may not have a problem with that, but I had to wait an extra day just to play it.  This may not even be a problem for most people though, unless you have download limits or what not, just a heads up. Now to the review.  As most people that have heard of this game know its about the Nazis winning the war and classic hero BJ is there to kill Nazis.

The story is pretty good, although don't expect it to be the best thing ever written. It is very good and unlike most war focused games, this one actually shows the civilian cost, and the effect people have with the Nazis in control.  The gameplay is fun and I felt tactial at times. Most levels you have the choice of how to engage, there are certain units that if they spot you they will call in reinforments, which can be a pain.  So you can either go guns blazing and take out everyone, or take the stealth routine.  I tended to be as stealthy as possible, but when spotted went guns blazing.  Also this game has a perk system which is kind of cool.  Each of the trees has different slots, all can be earned by doing a certain challenge such as get so many headshots, or kill 2 people with one grenade.  There are a couple trees to earn each skill for and once earned never go away, unless you start a new game.

The AI was kind of buggy at times, not anything that bad to where the game couldn't be played or wasnt fun, just sometimes guards would be looking straight at me and not set off an alarm or shoot at me, but other times the AI would work together to murder me.  I played through the game on the medium difficulty so I could get a decent challenge but still be able to beat the game without raging.  The guns are fun and some can get upgrades which just make a great gun even more fun to use.  If you like collecting things then this game will keep you around for a while.  Of the collectables I can think of off the top of my head you have: Letters written to different people which give you cool histroy and sometimes tips, Gold items that are just around, and the last I can remember are code fragments.  If you get all the pieces of one code you can then decode it, through trial and error, paying attention in game I think there are hints in some levels, and the internet.

The reward for finishing the code? Unlocking a new game mode adding more replayablity to an already good game.  I have around 11 hours or so in the game and finished it in 2 sittings, but decided to give my laptop a break after 9ish hours straight.  The game also managed to have some humor and have a serious tone and some sad moments.  The only really challenging part of the game for me was the final boss fight, I would say much about it but after dying a few times you should figure it out like I did.  I had the settings on Ultra and it looked pretty amazing. Do the side missions also, they arnt listed as missions but if you see them you will know what I mean, and explore every region you can because you can find some cool stuff hidden around. As a big fan of the Wolfenstein series this game was great and kept the old school feel which i miss in most modern games. I highly recommend this to fans of the series or fans of FPS's in general, also there is no MP in case you were wondering. I loved this game, also I get access to the upcoming Doom beta so thats a huge plus too.

reviewText:
Great Game.A throw back to old school shooters from the 90's. Been a Wolfenstein fan from childhood.

Machine Games has managed to mix modern shooter features with the old for a very convincing experience. Solid story line and character development, Wolfenstein NO brings the FPS genre backs to its roots with fast pace action based around combat intensity, excitement and less hyper realism that has overtaken the entire genre as of late. No more ducking for cover every five seconds to regenerate your health. Wolfenstein NO makes good use of HP and Armour pick ups that allows the player to feel more apart of the story rather than just a bystander.

I can't rave enough about the gun play in this game, amazing gun selection and design, almost every weapon can be dual-wielded. A good variety of weapons that all have different uses which help foster and encourage different play styles eg. stealth or open combat. This game has put to rest the argument that every FPS must embrace a multiplayer feature. While I hope due to the success of Wolfenstein NO a standalone multiplayer is developed in the future that echos the Enemy Territory model of earlier Wolfenstein games, this game easily stands tall on its singleplayer features alone.

With multiple difficulties, different characters and a meaningful collectibles feature that unlocks four very unique gameplay modes, this game has plenty of replay-ability and could easily be enjoyed for many playthroughs. I don't normally like DLC but I really hope this game gets some side mission or extended story line DLC and fingers crossed a sequel in the coming year or two.

Hats off to Machine Games for crafting an enjoyable singleplayer FPS in an era where everyone is obsessed with multiplayer and for standing by their development goals till completion to produce a solid product. Props also to Bethesda for backing a  studio with great talent and vision. Hope you enjoy this game as much as I did.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order may be one of the best sequences of those classic titles.

Graphics: 8/10
Sound: 6/10
Music: 8/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Atmosphere: 9/10
Hardware-friendily: 8/10
UI: 7/10
Extra Content: 9/10

New order is the sequence of the original Wolfenstein which released in 1991, over 20 years ago. I play PC games since 2000 so I'm not a old-school PC gamer, but I played many classic old-school PC titles released in the golden age of PC Gaming-1990s. Though, I have never tried the classic Wolfenstein. But when I play the New Order, many features reminds me of those classics. The first time you enter the story line in difficulty selection, you will smile. The intro movie, the way you kill a nazi, the way you restore health, the story, the combat...the more you play, the more you satisfied. I'm not a English speaking guy so I can't really express what I feel about this game in English. But if you a classic-FPS gamer played from 1990s you will know The New Order bring back the old feeling when the first time you play Wolfenstein in 1991 and the first time you play DOOM in 1993 and Quake in 1996. Old-school First Person Shooters. But The New Order isn't just old-school, it learns a lot from many other good FPS titles. Examples like: Double hands shooting, slidding, covering system, gun mods, throwing knives, destructable environment, lots of fun collactables, and it even offers two different story line!
After all, it give you a a lot of enjoyable contents to play, for a classic-FPSer.
The bad thing is, there is no multiplayer mode. I really like to have coop mode in the campaign just like Rage did. I'd like to have some fun TDM maps, shoot run and take cover-what you have done in singleplayer. In my opion, many single elements in this game worth to be made into a good multiplayer mode.Some of you guys may have problem running this game smoothly, but what you need to do is just to turn down the shadow resolution. that's all.
The New Order is worth a try for every FPSer. The graphics is good, the shooting feedback is great just like every id-Tech engine titles. The background music really brings the atmosphere, the sound is ok(since BF3 i feel every other FPS sounds bad). id-Tech 5 engine may not look so amazing comparing to CryEngine3 or UE4 and some others, but it looks good and offers very imersive atmosphere, which what i feel most since Rage. Some people may get bored that The New Order (in fact the id-Tech 5 engine) can't not push their ultimate gaming rig to the limits, never mind, you just relax and play it. You will find fun and enjoyments in it.

简单一句中文，德军总部：新秩序是我近年来见过的最有诚意的FPS续作，不静下心认真体会下它是你的不对。
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the best games this year, and one of the best AAA titles in a long time.

Gory as hell, with a story you can follow and characters that, shockingly, you can invest in, The New Order plays well and looks great. The gunplay mechanics are tight and very fun, with great diversity in the play styles and a skill-tree system that is as flexible as you are, and one that really compliments your preferred play style (if you don't just choose them all). Machine Games have really pushed idTech 5 far beyond the capabilities shown in RAGE, making this game a sight to behold. The textures and models are highly detailed without dragging down your framerate - I can play it on nearly full specs with a 4 year old Nvidia card, and the atmosphere of the game is thick and immersive as they have used that capabilities of the engine to compliment the game in all the right ways.

The game does toe the line of modern shooters in some ways that border on negative - specifically, the opening scene is great to play the first time, and then a drag upon replay as you go through the motions, but this is the only criticism that I really hold, and it's a minor one at that.

Highly recommended to any FPS fan.

reviewText:
Ok first thing’s first, this is NOT a remake, it’s not even a reimagining, this game appears to happen roughly in the same universe as the original Woflenstine but it is it’s own game.

Visually it is a vast improvement over iD’s last title Rage though they appear to be using an updated version of the same engine.  You will see some Unreal engine style texture pop-ins, which is a shame in this day and age, however it runs very well and for what it is the game still looks good and has some very nice visuals.  Levels have some level of destruction; at least of cover so there is that upgrade, pillars, barriers, certain types of metal sheets can all be gradually broken and shot through different methods.  There is a minor cover system, akin to FarCry 3’s system where you can pop out or over something if you get into the correct position which helps during combat.  There are modeled and skinned in damage indicators for enemy troops, and given that this is a iD game expect some gibs, limbs, some pretty brutal cut scenes, and fair quick but significant take down animations some are quite visceral.

There is a stealth mechanic and depending on your play style you may simply favor running and gunning which, given the fact that you can dual wield almost every weapon in the game you have enough firepower in your hands.  However if you wish to avoid as much attention and fighting as possible, or you enjoy watching the stealth kill animations then you can, at times it’s more beneficial to do so as a fair amount of the enemies in W:NO pixel hunt or are just extremely accurate even while running or moving around.  However stealth wise they tend to be both blind or severely impaired, while at the same time incredibly hyper sensitive to anything and unfortunately the cause varies, the stealth over all can be very forgiving, which is good because there is NO QUICK SAVE!  That is unfortunately correct, there is no quick save in this PC game, I do not understand why this was not added in but the actual developers Machinehead Games really screwed up with this omission.  If you die part of the way through an engagement you will probably not be able to start where you’d like and sometimes you have to do entire sections over again, other times the auto save places a spot right after.  You will need to learn from your mistakes or trial and error it unfortunately; however there are only a few sections in the entire game where I can honestly say that I had trouble with.

There is a leveling up/skill tree system for this game and for the most part it flows quite well.  There are requirements that you have to meet in order to move onto the next branch or in order to meet a requirement for a skill that is not actually connected to a previous skill.  These vary from performing take downs, throwing back grenades, killing a certain amount of enemies while dual wielding weapons, silent kills with throwing knives, and so on.  Some of the requirements however are for the most part nothing but grinding and putting yourself into situation that you would normally not put yourself into AND the game very rarely actually uses this kind of attack which defeats the purpose of requiring it, so you will have to find work around for these unfortunately.  Luckily the forums on Steam are fairly helpful and I know of two skill points that I didn’t know if I would be able to do them that I was actually able to pull off fairly easily by cheating the system, but not actually cheating mind you, simply the description on many of them is vague and the requirements can be met in different ways then what is actually written in the game.

One other major fault is the totally not old school mechanic of having to manually pick up items one by one.  Picture this, you’ve expended your assault rifle ammo and you’re in a semi arena still rife with bad guys, well in W:NO you need to crack open boxes and constantly be looking at the floor for dead bodies so you can rapidly press your use key in order to pick things up.  I can not understand what they were trying to do with this; I can maybe understand it for the gold items, intel and other collectables but NOT armor, health and ammo.  This gets worse when you have to fight the last boss, since every enemy in the game has pin point accuracy you have to continually run and “dodge” in order to juke his shots and on top of that you need to scramble around looking for health, ammo and armor pick ups in boxes and frantically press your use key in order to pick them up.  I have to wonder if Bethesda had anything to do with this choise since, as I recall, you picked up items manually in many of their games; the difference being however that unlike say Oblivion you are not dodging bullets in frantic fights.

The story and characters are pretty well done and there is a single point where you make one decision that will alter what doors you can interact with and that is all, there are no alternative story arcs.  This is fine because the story is fairly good, at least when compared to past Woflenstine titles, the characters and B.J. are the main focus of most cutscenes as well as minor story additions when you are back at the main base.  B.J. is far more fleshed out in this version of him then in any of the past games, while he may seem to be just a muscle head they make him out to be fairly intelligent and kind.  Each side character has their own story line and you will get bits and pieces of it as the game progresses which is a welcome addition as it further fleshes out that person.  While nothing ground breaking happens during these lulls in the fighting it’s defiantly a welcome addition.

The weapons feel and sound quite good and the skill upgrades add some flavors to them that help in dealing with some of the more heavily armored enemies.  Though speaking of enemies some of the armored human units like the shotgunners are just damn annoying and practically a mini boss, their shotguns ricochet off surfaces and do insane amounts of damage in a short amount of time.  There is usually one extra attachment for each weapon, though one in particular has several through the entire game.  The real benefit to the skill columns is that you can gain all of them and go back and start a new game, getting the benefits which will enable you to play with a different playstyle then you would have before.

Both the sound effects and the music are very fitting for the game type, the weapon sounds are very good and have a plenty of oomph behind them, the shotgun being one of my favorites, it sounds like the part.  The music was actually better then I expected, and it changes from stealth to active engagement when stealth is broken.  Each level has its own music score and they all sound very different from each other, sort of giving them even more of their own personality.

Being a Wolfenstine game the developers saw fit to go back to the roots and added a fair amount of collectables, gold items, intel, music, letters and audio logs.  If you’re a completionist then you will get some extra hours trying to fine every single item, which for me added to about 36 hours total play time.  Granted this game is only single player thus some people may say it’s not nearly enough content given how large the game really is, 40 gigs is never something to sneeze at.  There is some talk about adding a few extra levels, maybe multiplayer or something; however it is all just hearsay.

For $60 full price I might be hard pressed to suggest a game like this, however given that it did give me 36 hours, it’s not a hard sell I would say however that if you are at all on the fence about the price versus the content then I would wait for a sale, after that it will be well worth it.  Either way I had fun with it and I hope they will continue in some way, this also gives me some hope as to what Doom could possibly be like.

reviewText: This game encompasses old and new, a throw back to the health and armor system that seems to have been lost on most shooters these days. The gunplay is absolutely fantastic, it feels smooth and fresh like it did in RAGE but better in my opinion, I haven't felt this satisfied with a shooter since Half-Life 2: Episode 2. The sounds and music transitions with the cut scenes are absolutely beautiful and the voice acting is really well done.\n\nWith hints of Tarantino style story telling, the game pulls you through both sides of the spectrum when it comes to feelings and responses, like a rollercoaster of rage and punishment. I can safely say this is the first time a game has really put me through a process of Oh god that is awful

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a blast. It really is, it has enough fun, wacky, and bloody moments to make it worth your while. Don't be deceived, this is not an old school game, it is very much modern, with lots of cut-scenes, iron sights, and linear level design to make Call of Duty eat its heart out. Does that make it bad? Not at all, in fact, it is a well done modern FPS well worth your time.

For your first playthrough.

After that, trying to play it again, you realize how much fluff the game has, the amount of cutscenes and gameplay moments where you're not blasting through Nazi scum is astounding. There are intense moments of gameplay that will last from 5-15 minutes, with a level or two dedicated to full blown action or stealth just as you prefer it. In between all that is 30-minutes to an hour of doing a whole lot of nothing. Do you enjoy exploring sewer levels, finding lost toys for a character, or getting a sample of moldy concrete for research? It's all here.

Another big issue is the illusion of stealth vs. action gameplay, this was prominently advertised before the game's release. It implied that you would be able to go as stealth or Rambo First Blood as you wanted. For some levels, yeah, you can do that, but for most, not really. Sometimes your cover is blown right out of the gate, forcing you to go akimbo AR's and mow through lines of baddies. Other times you're so ill equipped to fight you really can't, and you have to go sneaky or face getting your arm ripped off by a genetically mutated robot German shepherd.

Finally, lets talk about the Nazis, there's no Hitler to kill, lets get that out of the gate, and it sucks. The Nazis feel overly evil, and it doesn't give you the proper motivation to kill them. They feel like generic evil-doers that you have to kill in order to progress the story. Instead of an attitude of business as usual" while committing heinous crimes

recommended: or flipping tables out of enjoyment as they purge a mental hospital. Don't get me wrong here
hoursPlayed: they do very much try to give you that feeling of genuine evil
voteText: but personally it comes off as a joke.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
This was a breath of fresh air. I was really happy that this game came out and I would put in my top games of 2014. As a fan of Wolfenstein, I couldn't help notice all of the old school things that they did in the game (even though I only played Return To Castle Wolfenstein). One of them are the secrets and duel wielding of the heaviest shotguns possible. Some of these things in the game really made me remember how fun and over the top an FPS can be. Wolfenstein is one of the pioneers of this genre. One of my favorite easter eggs in the game is the Wolfenstein 3D dream. I loved playing through that and thinking to myself, did the series ever lack a story? The answer is yes. The New Order has a big story with great writing, great voice acting, and characters that you can actually feel pity for. Some other great things that this game is top notch at is the combat. I found it to be very satisfying and I wished that more game took the idea of duel-wielding assault rifles because if you think about it, when fighting big robotic Nazis, it takes more damage. I also enjoyed the puzzles. You get a lazer gun in the game, which you can use to burn though wire and other objects with a highlight. As the game progresses, you can modify your weapons which I really like as well. The last thing about combat is armor. Whenever you kill an ememy, you can pick up their armor and take more damage in battle. But, it doesn't totally make sence, how would dog armor or big robot armor fit on you? Well, it's just a game and I don't really get bothered by it.

A new addition to the series is stealth. If you talk about Wolfenstein, you never really think about stealth and when first thinking about it, I found it odd, but upon further inspection it's pretty useful when you're playing on Über (hardest difficulty), like me. It's also more logical since, you can't be a one man army, litterally killing all Nazis and them never being able to kill you right? I liked the stealth and I like that when you get spotted, they call the alarm and call in more enemies. If you successfully kill everyone in the level, that will never happen. If you playing on the easist difficulty, then stealth is not really that useful. The other nice addition is the way you want the story to be. Save Wyatt, or save Fergus. Whichever one you save, the story unfolds with the one you let live. But, there is not really much of differnce, I actually played the game twice to see the differences and I was a little bit dissapointed to be honest. I was expecting for the characters to say their dialogue differenty but they were too similar. The only real change is lockpicking a door. With Fergus, you hot-wire and with Wyatt, you pick the lock. But I won't expect anyone to actually play the game twice, I'm just telling you this as an interesting fact.

A game is never perfect, and it always has it's flaws. One of them is how repetive some of the things can be. I don't like that everytime I enter an area, or open or press a button, the enemy jumps me and knocks me out, only for me to find myself in a different room, and later escaping again. I wish that they didn't take those cliches so high. Maybe it's just me, but I wished for not that to happen so many times. A huge problem I have with this game is the 60fps lock. Yes, I know 60fps is good and all but, when you have a person with not the most powerful pc in the world, you'll get lucky when it stays at 60. This also means that you can't even run the game on Ultra. I have a GTX 960, so I don't need to bother but I'm concerned for other people who also want to run the game on high settings at least. Apart from that, if you have no problems with that, then good for you. The last flaw is film grain effect". When I was playing I believe that it had some film grain. For personal preference

recommended: but I couldn't find where. I was quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at that. But I still loved the game and I really tell my friends to play it and anyone else as well. These flaws were more personal for me
