reviewText:
Story
World War II is over. The nazis won. The U.S. surrendered and now the world is a dictatorship in its entirety. It's up to you, William Blazkowicz, to save the world and kick the nazis out of power.

The premise is good but the delivery feels a bit bland. I suppose they chose to stick to the classic FPS theme, omitting an overwhelming/complex storyline (which would've been better in my opinion). However, be warned, for W:TNO isn't all about shooting nazis, there's an unavoidable romance storyline that can make things a bit cheesy.

Gameplay
The game itself is pretty straight-forward. No secondary missions or time to fool around. There are two storylines based on who you let to live (Wyatt or Fergus), but they're pretty much the same, with the cutscenes being practically the only difference.

Gunplay is 100% pure, unfiltered fun. You can double-wield, throw knifes to insta-kill enemies and become death itself if you want to. While average nazis aren't much of a challenge, major bosses can be tough, so don't underestimate them. There's a couple of easter eggs and you'll be able to play a level of the classic Wolfenstein but with modern weaponry.

Sadly, there's no multiplayer, which is a bit outrageous since the game weighs 50GB, but still, if you like FPS and hate nazis you're in for a ride.

Graphics/Soundtrack
Solid sountrack. It can be both engaging and chilling. It does a fantastic job pumping you up for shootouts, so if you liked it I recommend getting it.

Controls
Completely customizable and 100% left-handed friendly:
You can use the arrows instead of WASD
You can use Enter instead of E
You can use Backspace instead of R
Observations
No, you don't get to see Hitler (although he is mentioned). Yes, you get to have sex with Anya.

Breakdown
8/10 excellent FPS, lots of fun. I'm hoping for a sequel/DLCs in the near future.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is the latest main Wolfenstein game, a series of FPS games, which sometimes have very light stealth implented, where you shoot and kiss many Nazi and other fictional beings nearby. This time it was developed by MachineGames and published by Bethesda in 2014. Smartly enough, developers decided to focus fully on single-player, with no multiplayer modes. Otherwise it would have got hated by Return to Castle Wolfenstein multiplayer fanatics for not being same, who don't care about singleplayer campaign.
Game was developed with Id Engine 5, also used in RAGE, and was also made for PS3, PS4, Xbox 360 and Xbox One. There is no difference worthy to mention.

From technical side, I must note that AMD cards users will have harder times with this game. I remember how it would lag hard and crash even at intro movie at launch day. Good thing I updated to official Catalyst drivers and it got fixed, so I could enjoy my low-end laggy experience. No, I don't mind, I am used to being behind the times tech-wise.

The plot in this game is quite exciting. The Nazis, thanks to Deathshead, one of villians in previous Wolf games who now takes a main anatogonist role, advanced far above the Allies forces in technology, taking a horrifying shapes. It doesn't take them long to win the war and soon you will be out there, fighting your way through the world rebuild in evil Nazi ideology and style in 1960.

It's also executed cinematic-wise, awesomely. Blazkowich is back to his square-jaw and he now has non-stop inner monologues which deepens him as character. World is potrayed in dark tone. Your only friends are often weirdos. It has amazingly directed cutscenes and jaw-dropping setting. I also liked how action jumps from one point to another, and game never dumps a lot of info on you, saying little to create a big picture. Also helps with tastefully placed newspapers.
Though it does have a lot of shockers. Adult thing and all. But at times it felt that some shockers were there just to increase the rating really. And why main hero is totally cool with NPC drugging him with boiled water, not punching into face?

You also get to make choice between two characters in the beggining of a story: Wyatt and Feigus. Big deal it's not. It barely changes cutscenes and story, they say same general things in each line. Just depends on how much you want to hear F-bombs. Feigus timeline" lets you find the permanent health limit upgrades

reviewText:
Wolfenstein series is now over 20 years old and i begun my hobby around the same time. It's interesting to see the progress of two decades, but by the end of The New Order i felt like i just might give up on the whole FPS genre.

Plot is dumb but not in a fun action movie sense. Enemies sure are cartoonishly evil but the rest of the world doesn't seem so bad. Tech has gone forward in great steps resulting in robo-dogs and such which are clearly not to be taken seriously. Then again you see and act horrible violence that leaves people as empty shells (literally) that is perhaps meant to provoke some drama. I wasn't having fun with the story but could not take it seriously either.

Gameplay is divided in two sections: On missions and at base. The base is where you interact with various characters who are visually well desinged and kind of interesting but the objectives you get there are find a piece of moldy concrete" or "find missing power tool" and such. Even the main character complains about being "just like an errand boy". Still the characters and places are so well made that i liked those parts more than the shooting.

Enemies can take a load of bullets
recommended: and on the hardest difficulty ammo is scarce. Corpse may only carry 9 bullets so spraying all over is not an option. Of course you don't come to Wolfenstein looking for realism since the name of the series itself has meant Robo-Hitler with two miniguns for over 20 years. Problem is that the movement grinds to a halt when you have to peek from behind a corner slowly firing off hitpoints of something that also only stands still. There are only handful of enemy types. Sure there are diffrent colors and clothes but all carry same assault rifle and behave in the same way. Then there are few types of robots and occasional boss but overall the variation is way too low.\n\nMuch advertised feature is that you can dual-wield every weapon and that certainly is the case
hoursPlayed: but the flip-side is that there are only six or so weapons in the game. Pistol

votesHelpful: Sniper
votesTotal: Laser weapon/welder and occasional pick-ups like minigun. There are variants of all in different parts of the story set on different years
votesFunny: but i can't tell any meaningful difference between them. Basically what dual-wielding does is make the weapons fire at faster rate at the cost of iron sights. Since there are atleast two weapon options assinged on every weapon key and game brings up what you used last time
commentsCount: you'll more often than not get the wrong thing. For example at the later part of the game there are 4 possibilities of what comes up when you press number "4": Assault Rifle
column16: Assault rifle's underbarrel rocket launcer
column17: two assault rifles or two assault rifles with the primary shooting underbarrel rockets. So too few weapons but still too much to handle.\n\nThe laser/weldergun itself is interesting. It allows you to cut a hole in few materials. The desctiption says it will cut "thin metal" but you can only cut chicken-wire

reviewText:
Type of Game:

First Person Shooter

Version Played:

PC version through Steam

Similar Games:

The new Shadow Warrior, Serious Sam series, and some of the older Wolfenstein games

The Good:

- The tone of this game is a major departure from the uber-serious tone of previous games in this series. The tone is lighter and less bound by reality (and in some of the series, mysticism) than previous Wolfenstein titles. It’s a good reflection of the ultimate source material, Wolfenstein 3D. In summary, it’s really fun and seems to know it.
- You can dual wield every weapon. Even knives and sniper rifles. See the above note.
- Features returning for this game from the original include attack dogs, treasure hunting, and the ability to eat dog food. I can’t stress how fantastic this is for anyone (like me) who grew up with the original.
- The game’s difficulty gradually ramps up, and only rarely does it become stiflingly difficult. It balances its pacing very well.
- The levels are well designed and very creative. Additionally, the easter eggs like treasure, Enigma codes, and scattered articles, are plentiful.
- I don’t normally notice the soundtrack for this kind of game, but this is an exception. I thought the soundtrack for this game was remarkably well done.
- There is no multiplayer, and since I generally don’t invest enough time to get good but still feel obligated to play it, I only ever end up frustrated. So yes, this is a positive.

The Bad (all negatives have to do with the storyline so… SPOILERS):

- There are points during the game in which I believed there was a lack of communication between the voice actors/writers and the director of this game. Particularly when B.J. is growling though his monologue of childhood memories, I had to remind myself that this is a game where I can eat dog food, dual wield sniper rifles, and infiltrate a moon base (in 1960, no less).
- B.J. wakes up in an asylum after his first encounter with Deathshead, semi-conscious but unable to move, and remains unable to move for fourteen years. When he is finally able to get up and start the killing again, he’s still a mass of ripped muscle. I mean, this dude is a beefcake. But after not moving for FOURTEEN YEARS? Were they injecting him with HGH the entire time?!? Come on. Give me a montage where he brings himself back, something. There’s unrealistic, and then there’s this.

While I’m picking nits…

Not much this time. This game is remarkably clean. The only thing I noticed was that sometimes if I turn around quickly the game can’t keep up with which doors are open and which are closed, so there is a split second where there does not appear to be a door, then it appears. This happened infrequently however. No game breakers, no serious bugs. Machine Games QA FTW.

Did I make time to complete it?:

My first playthrough took fifteen hours. I did not get every single unlockable, however, and there is a decision early in the game (it saves one character while killing another) that I would like to change and see the story from that perspective. So this game will probably clock in at 25-30 hours for me.

Recommended Purchase Price:

Not $59.99, but only because I am philosophically against paying the same amount for a digital download as I do for a physical product. I picked it up for $35 and was happy with that, but I’d have gone as high as $45.

or

75% of current retail value of $59.99

Reviewer: Rod Kimble

A Quick Look at those Games you Might Buy:
http://www.gamersglance.com

reviewText:
===Not a shooter with a brain and/or soul, but definitely a shooter with a heart.===

Wolfenstein pre-dated Doom. Now ponder that for a moment. What you're playing is history. History that will hopefully be made again if the game sells well enough to warrant a sequel, and I do hope you buy this game because I want to know how it all plays out since the game ends on a cliff-hanger, the almost Half-Life 2 Episode 2 cliff-hanger.

This game is one of those ultimate male-fantasy games. It just nailed pretty much everything right. It is also a tale of revenge. You play as an alpha-male with a soft heart, you get a hot chick, you travel around the world and to the moon, you get some downtime there and there, you kill Nazis and robo-Nazis, destroy their accomplishments, unravel their secrets, inspire the resistance, etc.

It's a roller-coaster of a shooter with some old-school and some new-school" mechanics that is outrageously fun

In the other games, BJ is not given much of a personally he's as emotionless as the Doomguy. Which is what I liked, I like silent killers. His thing is killing Nazis, he does it for a living and he does it in his free time. He doesn't have time to moan over random people and have a ♥♥♥♥ing Polish Girlfriend. reviewText: If you're an AMD GPU user then stay away from this game like it's the plague! Trust me when I say that this is a really really fantastic First Person Shooter, it's just so good but it runs so so terribly. My GPU is an MSi Radeon R9 280x 6GB Gaming and my CPU is an Intel Core i5-3570K so my rig is easily mig/high tier but even on lowest possible setting this game runs terriby. I did it all, I renamed WolfNewOrder_x64.exe to WolfNewOrder_x32.exe, I turned off the Steam Interface, I tried to run it as Admin and I tried other tweaks I found around the internet but nothing works, I still get around 20 FPS on lowest which makes the game really difficult to play. The only time I get 30FPS or over is when I stare directly into the muddy textures of a wall and sadly that's not how the game is supposed to be played. I'm getting a refund on this game and I feel sorry for you people who bought this game at launch and still can't play it.

reviewText:
!NOTE! - If you don't want to read a detailed review, GO STRAIGHT TO THE PRO CON SECTION.

This game is probably one of the most satisfying Nazi killing game hands down! Visuals are fantastic, gameplay puts you in the zone, the music is so solid and amazing it fits the mood for every situation whether you're mowing down enemies, exploring a location or picking a stealthy approach, this game has a good bunch of everything.
However, one thing to note is the story. The entire premise is captivating, well executed and definitely makes you feel like the Nazi's are in power. But one thing is a small issue and is quite ironic: The story. While the story is there, it is good and puts you in the middle of it all, you forget the reason why you're doing anything you're being told on any point in the chapter. This is actually just a small factor in the game, as it immediately puts you back on track. Now where to start with the review...

The Premise: The Nazis won the war and they are definitely in power. Wolfenstein: The New Order executes every bit of this atmosphere so well it is scary. It almost feels historical! Except for the fact that they are extremely technologicaly advanced. Aside from that, this game is amazing when it comes to making it seem like the Nazis really do control everything!

The Atmosphere: Every mission and environment are different in their own ways both visually and game wise. They really put you in the situation and allow you to feel the weight of it all. Althought the paths you take can be very linear, the world is open enough for you to feel like you are really exploring. Among other things, the Nazis are also one of the biggest parts of this atmospheres(as if you didn't know already). They add a really good grim feeling to anything they're are around while also adding a nice touch of military strength. If the Nazis weren't as good as they looked, this game would be bland.

The Graphics/Visuals: Stunning in every way shape and form. Honestly, this game is Tomb Raider levels of good. Lighting, shadows, character models and texturing are all so well done. Some parts lacked like the Lunar Base and other textures but they never removed from the game. On top of that, all the Characters, Enemies and Robots look so amazing its insane. Every Nazi soldier looks awesome that when you kill them you can't help but look at them. Each character is also very well detailed that you want to stare at them.

The Gameplay: Very solid for a first person shooter, and it is to be expected. Controls for leaning might be a bit wonky but it is no biggy. It is as basic as you can get with controls. But the weapons and enemies is where the meat of it all is of course. You have a varied but formiddable array of weapons to your disposal and on top of that most of which can be dual wielded. They can be upgraded as you progress and allow for dynamic fighting. The enemies you encounter however are what determine what you should be doing. You could encounter a large wave of enemies and need some serious automatic fire power, so why not dual wield Assault Rifles? Heavily armored troops could jump in so mount up some laser weaponry. Enemies too far away? Marksman rifle. Don't wanna deal with them all at once? Grab your knives and stealth kill everyone. The vast amount of choices to engage enemies is surprisingly wide.
Another thing to expand on with this game is that you actually make choices, both linear and personal. The game can make you do small or large decisions that can ultimately change the game itself or do something to the immediate situation. Really good. And then you have engagement options which varies between stealth and destruction.

The Characters: All characters are voiced and designed well. Although they are not incredibly attachable they allow you to be immersed in the game. However, you don't actually get to see much of them unless you're in the safe house or taking care fo the dirty laundry". Otherwise
date: characters are well done.\n\nThe Main Character: William J. Blazkowicz is a pretty awesome and badass character. Well voiced and well designed. No real backstory is provided
recommended: just his part in WWII. All in all
hoursPlayed: pretty good.\n\nWhat is BAD about the game?: Well first off

reviewText: Okay, I get it. You got burned by Rise of the Triad. We all did. Shadow Warrior was good, but everyone ignored it because Hard Reset blew and they thought it would be like that. This is different, though.\n\nThis is a full-on nazi-murdering masterpiece, a sequel worthy of Return to Castle Wolfenstein. The game tempts you in with a snappy cover system, dual-wielding anything, stealthy stabfests, and the ability to jump between any of those playstyles at a whim. But then it keeps you there with the story. Who the ♥♥♥♥ expected that? Wolfenstein isn't about characters you care about, dramatic scenes, and an emotionally-charged soundtrack, right? It is now. I think we all expected a multiplayer-focused pithy attempt to chew into Call of Duty's playerbase, but this is a single-player only mother♥♥♥♥in' -narrative-, and it is wonderful.

reviewText:
I suppose I should start by saying that I am a longtime Doom fan and I suppose I have a soft spot for Id (the developer of these games), but till now I have never actually played any of the Wolfenstein games.  I was ready to ignore this one too until I noticed that the game came with access to the new Doom beta.  So I got curious, did some reading, saw that it's a Bethesda game and again almost ignored but said what the hell, for Doom I'll try it.

My first pleasant surprise came with the initial credits - Id is still alive and kicking!  Good for them (for those who don't know Id invented the 1st person shooter).  Then I started playing the game and wihle the idea of americans vs. natzi's has been a pet peeve of mine for a very long time, the story of this game was surprisingly well thought out and quite compelling.

Just as improtantly, the graphics were quite crisp and the game play very fluid and engaging with interesting weapons and upgrades that were either unlocked through challenges or you had to keep an eye out to find as there is no store" in this game.

All in all I really enjoyed this game and was sad when it was over.  I'd say it was worth the spend."

reviewText: Wolfenstein: The New Order's shooting mechanics are sublime. The audio and visual feedback, along with the excellent animations and diverse enemy types all work in concert to provide a joyful shooter romp. And all this is made sweeter by the surprisingly fresh story. Whereas antiheroes and muddled morality systems seem all the rage in today's pop culture, WTNO returns to a simpler time, in which heroes are heroes and villains are horrible, evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥ whom I wanted nothing more than to see put six feet under the ground. The problem of ludonarrative dissonance (as seen in recent shooters such as Bioshock: Infinite) is not a problem here, because the player experiences firsthand, often in states of powerlessness, the atrocities committed by the bad guys, so often that by the time he or she is locked and loaded with akimbo, fully automatic shotguns, he or she is ready to mete out righteous buckshot justice. More than dull shooting galleries, every fight becomes an act of catharsis. This is why we crave better stories in games - not because of an appeal to some artistic standard set by film and literature, but because of the way it FEELS.\n\nThree-dimmensional characters, wonderfully despicable villains, a romance subplot that, as far as I'm concerned, is touching, and a seemingly meatheaded protagonist who, as you get to know him, turns out to be just a peace-loving country boy fighting for friends, family, and barbeques on sunny, suburban lawns.

reviewText:
This is the most brutal, brain-bashingly bloody title I have played in the last three years and I've played plenty of titles that have tried to be just that. Wolfenstein: The New Order, while not technically impressive on the PC with its frame limiter, is a story-driven shooter experience you will not soon forget.

id Software has done an exceptional job making you REALLY hate the antagonist Nazis in the game. Anything bad that happens throughout the story? It is directly the Nazis' fault. And that makes you, Lieutenant Blaskowitz, really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off. Add some unique and alive-feeling characters on the good guys' side of things and a guitar solo of the US national anthem and you've got yourself a narrative that explodes with awesomeness.

The gameplay is quick and hands off, just aim at Nazis and start gunning them down. No cover system, no nothing to hold your hands against the teched up, excuse-free Nazis. Melee attacks are quick and satisfying and actually offer and advantage over just running and gunning in stealth situations which were a pleasant surprise when they were presented.

Overall, I would recommend this game if you are looking for an engaging first person story-driven experience with a required element of skill. If you're up to the challenge of ending a genocide and feel like you can pick up the role of the badass Lieutenant Blakowitz, pick up Wolfenstein: The New Order. If not, well then, just let the Nazis take over and see what happens, you sadistic prissy boy.

reviewText: There's been a lot of hubub recently about Wolfenstein being the sleeper hit of the year, and after hearing it was made by most of the same team that worked on the Chronicles of Riddick and The Darkness (both fantastic games that are criminally overlooked), I was excited to try it.\n\nDoes it succeed? Mostly. The general premise (your character is in a coma for 14 years and wakes up to a world where the Nazis won WWII) works, largely because of solid storytelling and a fantastic art direction. Up to this point, BJ Blaskowicz's defining trait is being that dude who kills Nazis
date:
but Machinegames does a really good job of making him a belivable character thrust into an unbelivable situation.  Except for the romance stuff. Ech, that romance stuff. The various newspapers and decorations throughout the levels do a great job of establishing the world and overall tone.

The actual gameplay doesn't break any new ground, but it's really good for what it is.  The guns have a great feel and weight to them, the enemy types encourage a vareity of strategies, and the pace is fast and frantic.  There's also a stealth element, where the game often encourages you to silently kill generals in the area to prevent backup. This works most of the time, but not always - the AI has some weird quirks where sometimes it'll notice you from miles away and other times it has no idea that you're right next to it.  Also, the game loses some steam towards the end - they run out of new enemy types and the new environments just aren't exciting enough.

I think some of the surprise GOTY" talk is a bit overblown
hoursPlayed: Wolfenstein is a great FPS with a surprisingly good story that stands above a lot of games in its genre. Recommended

reviewText:
This is probably one of the best games I have ever played… you know, after fixing it so my computer doesn’t melt whilst playing it. (That isn’t a stab at the game at all!)

I’m gonna do a simple Pros and Cons list for this game because I’d end up writing an essay about it. TL;DR located at the bottom.
PROS:
-  Genius ideas. It takes on an FPS style obviously but it keeps your interest for the entire duration of the game. The enemies are so creative and original that I was honestly curious as to what the game would throw at me next.
-  Graphics. Are. Godly. There’s detail where detail wouldn’t even be necessary, helping to complete the atmosphere the game wants to create.
-  Music. This is more of a personal thing but I personally loved the music. At certain parts too, it just knows how to get your adrenaline pumping.
-  The STORY. I loved the story so much. I grew a love for characters and I grew an unrelenting hatred for characters too. If you want to have your heart cycle between loving the characters and experiencing extreme bloodlust, this game is for you.
-  Weapons are pretty awesome too. I loved using the missile launchers, in the few instances that I could.
-  The game knows how to balance between explosions, chaos, fire and death and the calm “just go around and explore” levels. It makes you appreciate both of them if you’re someone that gets annoyed when there’s too much of one or the other.

CONS:
-  If your computer isn’t the absolute best, this game will decimate it. Initially when launching the game (I can’t remember if it detects your computers specs and sets graphics accordingly beforehand) it was very de-synced. The video was slow and the audio seemed to had to repeat itself because the video was so slow. But after fixing the graphics so my computer can tolerate it, it ran pretty well.
-  I don’t know if it was just me being bad at video games in general, but it’s pretty easy to get lost. The path isn’t given to you with a giant neon green arrow screaming “GO HERE.” The good thing about this though is that it sort of encourages you to explore more. Though when you explore everything you might get a bit frustrated. All the more satisfying when you make progress, though.
-  Some of the robots can be a bit of a pain to figure out how to kill.
Honestly though I can’t come up with many Cons. The Pros definitely dominated in my opinion.

TL;DR:

Would definitely recommend this game for anyone looking for something that will give you a satisfying feeling when you launch rockets and grenades and Nazis and see them explode all over the floor. The game bombards your senses with the most detailed atmosphere I’ve ever seen in a video game, and takes a pretty frightening and nightmarish idea and makes a badass game out of it. A bit expensive though. I bought it when it was on sale for $20, mainly since I don’t want to spend too much on games. A truly spectacular game. Took me out of reality for the time I played it.

reviewText:
I will admit that at first, it wasn't a game that I would've choosed like that... But a few friends recommended it to me and let me try it a bit, I decided to buy it and try it to a full extent once and for all, so here's my Pros, Cons and Misc for this game.

Pros:
-Very nice Graphics
-Nice Weapon Pallet
-Very Good Senario
-A decent main Cast
-Satisfying enemy death animations
-Beautiful designs and artwork
-Rare non-simulator FPS that uses cover mechanics
-Game that has stones showing and talking about the concentration camps(Though a bit light on what they show)

Cons:
-Occasional AI stupidity
-Stealth makes the enemy look incompetent
-A bit short
-Occasional awkward death positions(Though some made me laugh really hard)

Misc:
-Occasional tough choices
-Music is good
-Exaggerated proportions
-General Death's Head is a happy man
-Satire, exaggerations and Noir are on the menu here

I recommend this game for people who want a good time in an alternate-history fps with Nazis everywhere, a good number of weapons allong with dual wielding(Watch out for ammo though!), and a great senario.

reviewText: Games in which the storyline is delivered to the player via rails catch a lot of flak, and rightly so; but occasionally you'll get one so good that it goes overlooked as another hour passes with your eyes glued to the monitor. Portal, Half-Life, Bioshock, Metro and many more all managed to do this and now Wolfenstein: The New Order can be added to that list.\n\nDeep, exciting and rambunctious combat with a gripping story make Wolfenstein: The New Order a great throwback the original Wolfenstein 3D, not to mention the music and cinematography are superbly executed. If you enjoy games like Duke Nukem (Not the reboot), Serious Sam and the like, this is a must buy.

reviewText: Where to start on just how great this game is? First of all, my playtime on steam is in no way represantative of how long the game is, as I completed it mostly in offline mode. To start, this is in my opinion one of the best FPS i've ever played. To start off, gunplay. The guns all feel powerful and fun to use, that combined with the fact that you can dual-wield pretty much everything in the game adds to how satisfying to use the weaponry in Wolfenstein is. Every weapon in the game has an alt-fire mode activated with C which essentially doubles the weapons in the game. The combat is visceral, enemies die satisfyingly and spurt moderate ammounts of blood, barely noticable amongst the havoc. The giant Nazi robot enemies add a good degree of challenge to the game aswell and they feel good to take down. There are many, many collectable throughout the game which can keep you trying to find them for a decent ammount of time. Surprisingly, the plot of Wolfenstein is quite enjoyable and gets quite dark in the latter half of the game. The game does have some stealth sections, but, also surprisingly, the stealth within the game is oddly enjoyable and it feels good to sneak through and take out a bunch of Nazis without being seen. Adding to this stealth element is the commanders. They broadcast alarms to bring in more enemies in the event that they see you or hear gunfire. This adds to stealth, meaning the player could go all out on a rampage, or take out the commanders for a more subtle approach. Wolfenstein: The New Order is an overall fantastic game and the best FPS of 2014 in my mind.

reviewText:
This is a solid FPS about killing Nazis. Do you really need another reason to play?

Do you wanna be stealthy, using knives and silenced pistols? Be my guest.
Do you wanna blow people up with grenades and grenade launchers? Go for it.
Do you wanna run into the Nazis duel-weilding automatic shotguns or machine guns? Why not?
Do you wanna to laugh as heads explode to your sniper's bullet? Sure.
Do you wanna watch giant robots die to your lazer guns that also works as a fancy metal cutter? Of course.
Do you wanna do all of the above? Hell freaking yes!

Not only are all of those possible, but this game actually has an interesting story. Call of Duty or Battlefield won't leave you with the feeling you're gonna have after this game. Trust me.

reviewText:
It's one of the prettiest games to date. For gameplay, a shooter is a shooter is a shooter, though it seems to be very stringy with ammo at times while being exceedingly liberal with it at others. The stealth elements are not as well developed as in, say, DXHR, but they do work.

The contrast between how seriously it appears to take it's own story and how it can't possibly be serious about it is quite puzzling, though, and I am not sure if this is a positive or a negative. But for me, I'd say this contrast itself is the high point of the game.

Get it anyway.

reviewText: Before I purchased Wolfenstein: The New Order, I was very skeptical. Normally I can't stand to play a FPS for more than 15 minutes without becoming immensely bored and disappointed. Certain previous Wolfenstein titles were disappointing, and I wasn't sure whether or not the $60.00 price tag was worth it. However, IT IS. -- For the first time in a long time I was immediately gripped by the story set in an alternate timeline in which Nazi Germany defeated the Allies in WW2. Not only is the story amazing, but the graphics, mechanics, and overall bad-assery of B.J. Blaskowicz make for an incredible game that you won't want to set down. Wolfenstein: The New Order was the first game that I completed all the way through and was legitimately satisfied with in a very, very long time. I recommend this to ANYONE. However, be prepared for some horrendously gruesome violence in the cutscenes (which Wolfenstein is infamous for). ENJOY!

reviewText: Wolfenstein's fallen from grace in recent years, and that's a shame for a franchise that practically launched the First Person Shooter that is so mainstream today. The 2009 title did nothing to fill in the gap between the legendary Return to Castle Wolfenstein and Enemy Territory titles, which were multiplayer juggernauts back in their day. Wolfenstein seemed doomed to fail and interest could never be lower, but perhaps that's what made The New Order one of the best shooters I've played in recent memory.\n\nThe New Order does so many things so very, very right, ranging from the tight, punchy feel of the combat to the stellar writing of its relatable and sympathetic characters, to the incredible art design of a Steampunk Nazi-controlled world, an intuitive and simple challenge-based leveling system, lifelike animations, cinematography that rivals many films of today, a lavish level design, collectables that are worth giving a damn about, and even an interesting early moral choice in the game makes it worth replaying. This game is tuned so tight in its' combat which alone makes it worth the price of entry. Weapons are punchy, sending enemies flying or satisfying limb dismemberment with a thunderous thud" with a sound design that rivals that of Killing Floor or Battlefield 4

reviewText:
Wolfenstein is back. So what's this 2014-Wolf like?

-Gore: Check
-Cool weapons: Check
-Dual-wielding shotguns: Check
-Amazing audio: Check
-Stunning visuals: Check
-No tacked-on MP: Check

In addition, the game has surprisingly good story and some pretty neat extras (artwork, codes that unlock special game modes etc.). The only downside is that it's quite short (about 10-12 hours one playthrough on hardest mode).

I wish we got Endless Killing in an Arena" DLC for this game.

Do yourself a favor and play this game.

9/10"

reviewText:
Outstanding!  My only complaint is that the system requirements are a little high.  If you're looking for an entry that makes up for that boring Wolfenstein that came out in 2009, buy the hell out of this game.

Everyone mentions the cheesy one-liners (which I'd like to point out only applies to the script, the voice acting itself is fantastic), but whole game is so over the top that they actually fit really well, so I don't know why everyone feels the need to point that out.

Also, the soundtrack is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic!  I'm reminded of the first time I heard Brighter Death Now or Throbbing Gristle.  As if that isn't amazing enough, there's even collaboration from Fredrik Thordendal of Meshuggah!  It's all about making this dark, oppressive, mechanical reimagining of the 1960's truly come to life and the music accomplished that beautifully!

reviewText: This game is amazing, no real other way to put it. As you're running through scores of Nazis with dual wielded fully automatic shotguns while listening to a fan-freaking tastic soundtrack you'll understand what I mean. The story is rock solid, it's no change you outlook on life good, but it's above average. The gameplay. as I mentioned earlier, is some of the best mindlessly fun FPS in recent memory, and offers a fair degree of challenge. The graphics are no Metro Last Light or Crysis 3 but they're good enough to not be a detractor from the overall experience, and it performs well, even though I believe there is a 60 fps cap, my hardware almost never dipped below it. (Considering the fact I have a superclocked 780, a 4770k and 16Gb of RAM I wouldn't expect it to) Overall a great experience. TL:DR Story's above average, gameplay is kick ♥♥♥ in every way, the soundtrack is amazing and the graphics/video performance are good if nothing too special.

reviewText:
For a game that I thought would be nothing but over-the-top action, W:TNO really surprised me with its storyline, characters and fully realized, vivid universe. In between rushing through bases and U Boats with dual wielded, full auto, ricocheting shotguns, it actually makes you feel involved in the story and care about the characters. Really tight controls, great level/sound design, satisfying gunplay and difficulty (played on hard.)

Cons: There are 2 timelines in the story based on a choice you make early on, but the difference between them isn't a massive deal. Not worth immediately starting a new game only to see the difference, unless you're wanting to play it again just to play it again.

The graphics are pretty underwhelming, especially considering the gargantuan file size. You can't even turn on AA without console commands.

Overall 9/10. Would kill Nazis again.

reviewText:
This is a solid FPS about killing Nazis. Do you really need another reason to play?

Do you wanna be stealthy, using knives and silenced pistols? Be my guest.
Do you wanna blow people up with grenades and grenade launchers? Go for it.
Do you wanna run into the Nazis duel-weilding automatic shotguns or machine guns? Why not?
Do you wanna to laugh as heads explode to your sniper's bullet? Sure.
Do you wanna watch giant robots die to your lazer guns that also works as a fancy metal cutter? Of course.
Do you wanna do all of the above? Hell freaking yes!

Not only are all of those possible, but this game actually has an interesting story. Call of Duty or Battlefield won't leave you with the feeling you're gonna have after this game. Trust me.

When I first heard they were adapting Spice & Wolf into a video game, I was skeptical.
When they accidentally changed the name to Wolf & Stein due to a clerical error, I was taken aback.

reviewText: This game is brilliant.  Definitely my favourite game of the year so far.  The graphics are outstanding and the story very entertaining.  Lots of guns, grenades, knives and explosions. I would happily recommend this game to fellow adults.  I will state that the controls are not as good as they could be for a pc player but something that can easily be overlooked for the quality gameplay and storyline.

reviewText:
Having just completed this game I couldn't not write a review.  This is the best fps I've played in some time and for a single player game that quite an accomplishment.
Start to finish Wolfenstein is a rollercoaster ride packed with adrenaline and never gets stale.  The pacing is excellent providing intence gunfights with optional stealth.  The stealth in particular is such an achievment considering the games roots as a fast paced shooter.  The game lets you play your way and if you go the stealthy route everything is just as exciting as if you went guns blazing yet stealth is rarely required.
The world is fantastic.  I love alt history games and this one does it so well placing the whole world at the feet of a Nazi superpower.  All the characters feel well suited to the world and are voiced excellently by actors with some real character behind their voices.
As I said I just completed Wolfenstein and I can't quite sum up all my thoughts on it right now but if you're on the fence just go ahead and buy it.  You wont regret it.  10/10.

reviewText:
Gameplay: Really satisfying shooting mechanics, smart AI and a great assortment of weapons make the game really fun.

Story: The plot is surprisingly deep, with complex characters and a consistently engaging narrative.

Graphics: Textures are lackluster, due to the game using the id Tech 5 Engine, though the upside to this is that they are (hypothetically) all unique. The enemy design is great and all the locations are detailed and look impressive.

Sound: The sound effects are very immersive, with all of the weapons sounding punchy and the enemie's war cries constantly instilling a sense of fear.

Re-playability: There are lots of unlockables, collectables and multiple difficulties.

reviewText:
In my opinion, this game has a lot of defaults :
- Graphics.
Played in Ultra (with a GeForce GTX 970) and ID Tech 5 engine does not deliver really impressive graphics : old design, few polygons, average lighting and textures (I played this game after Metro last light, alien isolation and farcry 4, all are better in my point of view).
- Mixed gameplay.
developpers want to mix stealth with a nervous FPS but both of them are just average : a stealth game where stupid ennemies don't care about dead bodies is strange, a nervous game where you need to press E everytime to loot items is crap ...
- Difficulty.
Difficulty is bad balanced (I played and finished it in Uber mode) : most levels are really too easy (at the game beginning, I checked really twice if i haven't made a mistake for my difficulty choice), and few parts are incredibly too hard and can be frustating (final boss for example).

Despite these defaults, I recommend this game : the storyline, the background, the characters and the atmospheric world are efficient. Gameplay has defaults but it's not totaly crap.
In conclusion, it's a relative decent FPS, and in 2014, we can't count many of them ...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Wow... This game is great. The cutscenes are amazing and don't distract from the gameplay. I also appreciate that the developers give  the option to skip any one of them, which comes in handy when you replay the game. Believe me, you will be replaying it. Initially I found myself skeptical of the Nazi tachnology and construction, but as the game progressed, I started being enveloped in the world. It feels almost claustrophobic since there is nothing but concrete and steel, as well as the hulking threat of the Nazis always looming. The game has emotion and heart, and I truly believed this is a labor of love from the developers. The ending was not as satisfying as I had hoped, and I wasn't all that keen on the plot's reasoning as to how the Nazis attained all of thier amazing technology (a jewish cult? really?). Other than that, the gameplay is great. The sound effects are comparable to Battlefield. Weapons really sound beefy and have some punch. The game is loaded with little details scattered throughout the world which add to the narrative. I personally loved seeing all of these little stories and newspaper clippings, and think that they further draw you into the game's world. You are given information from the Nazi and resitance perspective. The characters are unique and very interesting, each with a detailed personality that you find yourself wanting to know more about.\n\nI could write a book as to why you should by this game, but I'll just stop there. If you purchase this game, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
9.9/10

Runs Great
Looks Great
Feels Great

Explore this alternate history- If Wolf3d.exe was your first FPS game, as it was mine, you shold really enjoy the dog%%%% outta this one.

more pros-
Excellent story immersion.
Flawless development.
Amazing artistry.

cons-
the recommended specs from BETHESDA say you need an i7 to meet min. system.
(THIS IS A MISTAKE!  You can definitely play it on a decent i5 sandy or ivy bridge, and maybe even lower grade CPU than that- check forums.   I use my i5 overclocked IB / GTX 660 and can run most of the settings ramped up!)

NO SLI PROFILE- PROBABLY EVER.
(id's Tech4/5 engine can not utilize SLI frame rendering.  HOWEVER- using NVIDIA control panel, you can use your SLI setup to run antialiasing in SLI mode.  For example- 8x AA SLI = 16x.  Just need to tweak settings for game profile in Nvidia Control Panel or Inspector.)


Other thoughts-
You will probably enjoy this game more by using your gamepad.  I haven't tried M+K for this game, but since I play it with a gamepad, and am partial to the ease of play that comes with it, I have to personally recommend using a gamepad.

reviewText:
WOW! What a surprise!
Wolfenstine The New Order sets the standard in modern day First Person Shooters

I didn't know what to expect from this game. From the prologue I gathered it would be a mordern world war 2 game but the story changed drastically and I couldn't appreciate it more.

The gameplay is very good with beautiful graphics but what sets it apart from other fps's is the entising story with interesting characters. It is also easy to associate with the protagonist and the game does a very good job at stirring up emotion in the player.

The story was excellent but I feel a lot of players will want to know more. I'll leave it at that.

This was a very challenging game and players can't just COD their way through levels. The game requires strategy and sometimes a few failures to pass specific areas. Stealth which I normally hate was fluid and not too unforgiving.

Bethesda is really a industry leader in gaming and they deserve a lot of credit for this game.
I feel that this game definitely deserves a sequel

8.5/10

reviewText:
As a fan of the original Wolfenstein game who fell in love with Return to Castle Wolfenstein, and at least enjoyed the 2009 game, I had high hopes for The New Order. The fact that it released on my birthday, and Wolf3D was my first FPS furthered my hopes, wishing for something more than the gimmick of the 2009 game. I pre-ordered my copy with just a couple hours left, loaded it, and waited.
The plot works, and while sometimes BJ's internal monologues feel a tad forced and unnecessary, I felt that the game itself had a nice balance of gameplay and story. The addition of being able to choose how to go about a majority of the missions (either guns blazing or stealth) really sealed the deal for me. While I've only played it through once, I am gearing up for another playthrough to see if I can unlock more things, and also explore the other 'timeline'.
10/10, highly recommended if you want a Nazi-killing game.

P.S. Keep in mind that it IS a Wolfenstein game, and that if you have any issues with body horror, you will encounter it a lot. It's the Nazis. We KNOW they did ♥♥♥♥ like that during the war.

reviewText:
I gambled on this game with a pre-order before it came out, setting my expectations low and solely in the interest of acquiring access to the Doom 4 beta. Initially, there were a slew of technical problems leading to desktop crashes and making the game nearly unplayable due to the checkpoint system. After a few weeks, the problem was patched, and I must say, the experience went above beyond anything I could have imagined.

To take a game so devoid of plot like Wolfenstein and a character so lacking in depth as B.J. Blazkowicz and create such a fantastic story and cinematic experience is one thing. But the experience itself is action packed, the stealth is tense and fun if you choose that route when available, and the gameplay is just seeped in all the proper elements of old school shooters while utilizing first person in a way I haven't seen any other game do so well.

It took a formerly silent protagonist and breathed life into him, immersing the player in his shoes and surrounding him with characters you'd genuinely care for and antagonists you love to hate. Uber difficulty is challenging, so no worries there if you're looking for a bit of masochism like me. The graphics are breathtaking and the locations vary significantly in this bleak, alternative-history Nazi killing dystopia.

The folks at Machinegames have outdone themselves. They absolutely deserve a chance at a sequel. I for one would be quite happy (and relieved since it seems like it's in development hell) if they went over to id software and helped them out with Doom 4. They know what they're doing, and they delivered a reboot I didn't know I wanted until I played it. 10/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm going to start by saying that this is probably the best single player FPS game that's come out in quite a while, mostly because it's so well balanced in terms of gameplay. You can run-and-gun while dual weilding ‒ sliding around and dealing wads of dps ‒ take the usually optional stealthy route that prevents reinforcements from arriving, or simply play it like a cover based shooter. Typically you'll end up doing whichever one is most appropriate for the circumstance you find yourself in, but the option to do any of them is always there and usually always viable. The guns are freaking huge and pretty damn satisfying to shoot, the terrain that eneimes use for cover is normally completely destructible, and the stealth is rather intuitve and effective. It does all three styles well rather than just being a big brown puddle of boring and ineffective mechanics like most shooters that try to give you different gameplay options.

The story is pretty decent, with a lot of fairly memorable characters and an interesting take on a Nazi ruled planet. The dialogue and plot are what happens when you mash a gritty comicbook and an over the top action movie together. It's rather likable, but if you're looking for something with some semblance of realism then you're in the wrong place. Also, there are some pretty humorous parts of the game where the characters basically acknowledge that you're probably the most effective soldier to ever live, and the character interactions are normally not whiney or depressed in nature, they're more dynamic than that. They'll bicker, berate, tease, jest, laugh, cry, talk, complain, and do basically anything normal people would do with one another. It's definitly not 2 dimensional or anything.

In terms of fidelity it's decent but not fantastic. There are a lot of textures that just seem off, one that really bugged me was how pens and papers are actually just 2d parts of the desk textures. Speaking of textures, most of the non-cover and weapon textures are pretty poor, but to be fair they're hard to notice since you move around so much. Other than that there's not a lot to complain about, but ‒ then again ‒ there's not a lot to really praise.

Lastely, I'd just like to say that the levels and environments are really important parts of any FPS, and this game definitly has a lot of variety and good design when it comes to them. If you're worried that you'll be stuck in a brown corodor shooting faceless white guys in grey uniforms the whole time then you can relinquish those fears. You get to go to some pretty cool places and do some pretty awesome stuff. It's part of the whole ludicrous plot I was talking about earlier.

That's it. I hope that you found this at least slightly helpful. I can't tell you what you'll like, but I can at least try to give you a decent idea of what to expect. Whether or not you like what you hear is up to you, of course.

reviewText:
I never really looked at this title until it went on sale during the Steam summer sale - and a good friend bringing it to my attention.   I'm very glad he did.  His opinion (and what he heard) plus the trailers really got me excited for this title.

My thoughts about Wolfenstein had been colored a lot by its previous title, which was ok, but nothing more... so I wasn't really interested.

But after playing a couple hours into it... it's reminding me a lot of the somewhat recent Tomb Raider title (without all the crafting nonsense, mind you).  They've made Wolfenstein into a triple A title - worthy of that branding.  It feels like a movie that you play along in.  There are some lengthy cutscenes, but they're pushing a story that you want to see.

[Edit:  The storyline and characters!  Wow!  They did a fantastic job in putting effort into them.  Specifically the characters.  You grow to like them and want to hear more about them.  It's very enguaging and was the primary reason for me to wanting to continue to play to the very end.]

The maps are very well done - complicated enough so that you can explore, but not enough to get lost.  There are parts of the maps where you're given very satisfying power to exploit if you wish.  Then there are others areas where you feel the proper amount of presure pushed upon you, as you would expect in the overwhelming presence of the Nazi army.  Which leads me to my next point...

The stealth system.  They've attempted to put one in this game... but it's rather hallow and not fleshed out.  You CAN be stealthy one some missions, but on others you're simply forced into fighting.  Regardless of your best efforts to go unnoticed, you'll somehow be found and they open fire upon you as any typical AI would - no confusion, no reports going between your foes on your current location.  They simply know where you are, and move towards you like dogs during supper.

There are collectables to search for.  Some unlock more total hit points for you, some for play modes, and some just for simple achievements.  Some of these are well hidden.  During my first play through, I missed a bit more than half of them, and I was actively looking for them as I progressed.

But enough details... in summary... this game has good graphics, sounds, gameplay, and maps.  The only adjustment I would wish for would be smarter AI.

I would give this title 4/5, or 8/10.  Overall the single player was impressive, but lacking in AI (sorry, but Fear kind of upped the bar on this).  I would definately recommend this title due to the other fine things it has to offer.

I purchased this title for $30 (during a sale, if you recall) and I feel it was almost worth that amount.  If you can pick it up for cheaper, you would be wise to do so.  My ideal pricing for this title would be between $15 to $20.

Also, please be aware that if you're looking for multiplayer, this game doesn't have any (which I'm grateful for after the previous Wolfenstein).

reviewText: This game blew my expectations out of the water.  I had originally expected a shallowly made shooter, but I was give something with incredible depths. I felt the strings of my heart pulled at certain point in the game.  The gameplay was fast and challenging at parts sometimes making you take a step back and reassess your strategy(Which isn't a bad thing).  There were several ways to approach every scenario and through a currently in progress second playthrough I saw different even more places I could have done something different. Definitely giving you a different taste.\nWolfenstein's story was spectacular. I honestly expected something more akin to the old one, but I was given something very different and loved every moment of it.\nThe game does have some issues, but I didn't find many contrary to many reports. The graphical settings were a little odd and vague. Raising it drains the system, but makes it look incredible crisp.  Yet, the lower settings it ran very smooth and looked quite nice despite.  I did notice some audio desyncs at some cutscenes, but there were not that many of them. I found turning off Vsync fixed a good few of them. While, it was a little rough around the edges there, I only had some issue that affected gameplay.  Some soldiers spawned within a wall which wasn't that big of a deal and it was the sole occurence of it however.

reviewText: Wrestled with Robo-Puppy and had some Schnapps with the Nazis - 10/10\n\nSeriously though, it's a great blast - Machine Games have nailed the gun play, atmosphere and story. Ignore lack of multiplayer, it's not needed here. A few trivial criticisms though which you do get used to: you end up pressing 'E' constantly to pick up weapons, ammo, armour and collectibles, bit of a juggle if you're trying to our-maneuver the enemies through crouching and sliding around (I'm playing with WASD and mouse as you should do!) - personally I just changed the toggle crouch button to one on the mouse and forgot all about sliding etc unless otherwise prompted. The other issue is the speech levels - hard to hear over rapid fire and explosions etc. I had the subtitles on but found it difficult to read unless I had pre-cleared out the room of enemies. These are minor things though and this game is an essential purchase for the classic FPS lovers.

reviewText: There's been a lot of hubub recently about Wolfenstein being the sleeper hit of the year, and after hearing it was made by most of the same team that worked on the Chronicles of Riddick and The Darkness (both fantastic games that are criminally overlooked), I was excited to try it.\n\nDoes it succeed? Mostly. The general premise (your character is in a coma for 14 years and wakes up to a world where the Nazis won WWII) works, largely because of solid storytelling and a fantastic art direction. Up to this point, BJ Blaskowicz's defining trait is being that dude who kills Nazis
date:
but Machinegames does a really good job of making him a belivable character thrust into an unbelivable situation.  Except for the romance stuff. Ech, that romance stuff. The various newspapers and decorations throughout the levels do a great job of establishing the world and overall tone.

The actual gameplay doesn't break any new ground, but it's really good for what it is.  The guns have a great feel and weight to them, the enemy types encourage a vareity of strategies, and the pace is fast and frantic.  There's also a stealth element, where the game often encourages you to silently kill generals in the area to prevent backup. This works most of the time, but not always - the AI has some weird quirks where sometimes it'll notice you from miles away and other times it has no idea that you're right next to it.  Also, the game loses some steam towards the end - they run out of new enemy types and the new environments just aren't exciting enough.

I think some of the surprise GOTY" talk is a bit overblown
hoursPlayed: Wolfenstein is a great FPS with a surprisingly good story that stands above a lot of games in its genre. Recommended
voteText: especially at $20."

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order
I'll cut through the chase and say that it is a very good game. For its type, I would say it easily rates a strong 5/6 rating, where six out of six are Half-Life(1-2) and Modern Warfare(1)

Strengths:
+ The gameplay rewards exploration in an organic, almost old school manner.
+ Controls for weapons and movement are tight and very responsive.
+ You get to kill nazis, by the dousins.

Weaknesses:
- Graphics
- Internal consistency

This is where it gets interesting. In my mind there are really two flaws that prevent top score. And while it may seem odd and out of character coming from me, my first comments concern graphics, the second comprises the authenticity, or internal consistency, of the story being told.

Graphics. While the character models, and indeed motivations, are wonderfully rendered-- panoramic views, or really any of the wide-angle shots, leave much to be desired. Particularly when compared to other idtech games like Rage and Quake4, which have both delivered jawdropping panoramic visuals.

From personal preference, I would say that the aesthetic design of the Nazi warmachinery, ranging from combat drones to larger war machinery, also leaves me cold and uninspired. This may be a leftover homage from the previous games of the series, neither of which I am particularly familiar with, but from a personal point of view, the concept art could be much streamlined-- which leads us to my other concern.

Internal consistency. It may seem odd to criticize the internal consistency of an over-the-top action shooter, but my point is not that the game fails to  replicate Arma, it is that the game plays sloppily with the 'setting realism,' and therefore authenticity of story it presents. Certain plot elements seem improvised, the plot characters response to wounds are inconsistent, and the handling of plot elements (read high-tech military vehicles/weapons) seems ad-hoc and poorly thought out.

Contrast this to the games that earn top score. Modern Warfare, while hardly a realism game, applies its concepts consistently. Half-Life, presents a set of concepts, AND STICKS WITH THEM. In essence, these game feel authentic, even if they are not realistic, in a pedantic sense of the word. Now vehicles moving at 'the speed of plot,' are hardly new to the genre, I just prefer consistency to wishy-washy-handwaveium.


Conclusion:
Neither of my points of criticism are dealbreakers. Wolfenstein: The New Order, is a good game in all the ways that matter.  Its a good game, but not a great one. MachineGames is a studio to be watched in the future.

5/6-- well worth the playthrough.

Ken

reviewText: One of the most surprisingly good games I've played in a long time. I wasn't expecting much with this when I originally heard about it given Wolfenstein's lackluster history after Return to Castle Wolfenstein and the tendency of Bethesda published games to be mediocre at best, but I was proven wrong. If there was ever a prime example of the statement Don't judge a book by its cover" for video games
date: this is it.\n\nThe story is very engaging and somehow manages to make hating Nazis feel new again. The characters on both sides are very well written
recommended: and even B.J. still feels compelling as a character outside of brutally murdering Nazis. The main plot is very interesting and solid. Besides maybe a hiccup here and there concerning jumping to different levels
hoursPlayed: it's very coherent. The overall tone and style of the plot is what I would describe as Bioshock Infinite meets Metro 2033. The entire campaign lasts for around 8-10 hours
voteText: and that is without trying to look for all the secrets hidden in each level. Not to mention there are 2 branching paths to choose from.\n\nThe visuals are great. Not really eye melting and some textures and effects could be better
helpfulPercent: but the overall aesthetic is astounding. The annoying visual anomalies present in the only previous idTech 5 game
votesHelpful: RAGE
votesTotal: are no longer present for the most part. Maybe some popping in textures every so often
votesFunny: but it's not nearly as jarring as it was with RAGE or some Unreal 3 games.\n\nThe sound design and soundtrack are great as well. Weapons are just a joy to use with the sounds they have. The Nazis sound authentic and are in no way cheezy. As for the music
commentsCount: if you're a fan of the new Killer Instinct reboot
column16: you may recognize the stylings of Mick Gordon in the gameplay tracks. The songs range from moody and atmospheric to intense and thrilling. Even though some of my friends jokingly refer to the more intense tracks as "Nazi robot dubstep"
column17: it just feels right in this game and I quite enjoy them. There's even some German covers and re-imaginings of famous songs from the time period given a Nazi Germanic spin to them. While you probably won't hear them much throughout the game
column18: it's a nice touch that most game developers wouldn't even consider.\n\nThe gameplay is tight and precise as with any idTech shooter. If there's one thing idTech based games always get right
column19: it's player input. As alluded to earlier

column21: it always presents you with a challenge.\n\nThe only thing I would've liked to see with this game is a multiplayer mode. I can understand it not having one given how immaculate the campaign is
column22: but the mechanics are so solid and fun that it almost seems ridiculous to not have it.\n\nThe only negative thing I can say about this game is that I don't think it's worth $60 USD. I know that's more Bethesda's fault than the developers

reviewText:
I got this game on sale when it was 30 bucks, and I think it was definately worth it.

Positives:

Very fun and satisfying shooting

Very fun and satisfying sneaking

Very fun and satisfying loot finding

Pretty good story, very cool alternate timeline / history

Negatives:

The thing that really irked me was when I was trying to do all the side missions in the hideout so I turned in one and it automatically sent me to the next main mission. I wouldve preferred it warned me first before sending me off, but I'm going to play through it again for the diferent branching paths anyway.

The ends of missions end somewhat weirdly in how they just drive away from a bunch of nazi killing and sabatoging, and are able to make it back to their hideout, which is in the middle of the city surrounded by oblivious nazis, every time they go out. You would think that since the nazis rule the world, that they wouldbe able to just keep forces on their tail so they would never get back to their hideout, but yadda yadda videogames.

Overall it is a very fun game, with nice collectables, gunplay, interesting story and characters, and it was nice that they gave some depth to the 'ol block head B.J. Blascowits.

reviewText:
If you look at my library you'll see that, despite having a library of over 600 games, I don't have much, or any, playtime, on a majority of my games.   Wolfenstein: The New Order was able to keep my interest and I thoroughly enjoyed the game.

There are a few cliched plot points (though, some are most likely intentional nods to other media) but the story is overall pretty good.  After an initial issue of the game not even running without ATI graphics drivers of at least 14.something, and a subsequent update of drivers, I experienced no issues running the game on the highest settings.

I'd highly recommend picking the game up as there is plenty of challenge, a good story, and no game breaking bugs to ruin the experience.


An edit to quantify running on the highest settings": My game was run with an i7-4770k

reviewText:
This is the closest thing to a flawless game I have ever played.  Each aspect of it is perfectly crafted, whether it's the story, the gameplay, the characters...

Let's start with the story.  It is 1960, and the Nazis have won World War II.  Everything we know about the free world has gone to hell and been replaced by a horrifying vision of what could have been.  Down to the tiniest details, such as a Nazi-style Beatles album, or letters recounting the war, this is a fully fleshed-out world, and each twist and turn of this fast-paced tale hits you hard and makes you feel real emotion for what is happening.  The setting and the level designs feel fluent and fitting in this grim reality, as do the look of the soldiers and weapons.  There is a ton of background information you can discover about it as you progress through the campaign.

Next, the gameplay.  Very much in tune with the original Wolfenstein games of old, The New Order feels like the perfect mix between modern and classic.  The health system makes each leap from cover to cover suspensful, as you have to keep finding health packs and hidden rooms to stay alive as the futuristic soldiers fire at you.  Also in vein with classic shooters, you have access to every gun you pick up at any time throughout the level.  This leaves room for a lot of variety as you mow down evil soldiers.  Yet, despite these more retro aspects of gameplay, the shooting and sprinting feels fast and responsive.  Not once did I feel like I died because I was too slow, or got stuck.  Also, almost every gun you pick up will get upgraded as you progress, adding insane features to your favorite weapon.  Now, the one thing that was a little lacking was the stealth.  It feels a little like it was added last minute, after they had designed the game to be a fast-paced shooter (which it is), and sometimes it can be annoying.  But, it is still possible and very fun to sneak around and silently pick off guard dogs or commanders.  In addition, The New Order has a very cool perk system, that unlocks new abilities as you carry out actions or takedowns in-game, and you can progress down a multitude of skill-trees, such as stealth or melee, or shooting to name a few.

Finally, the characters.  Good god, the characters.  Each one is a shining gem, sticking out uniquely in their own ways.  They too, interact with the world around them, and have great dialouge/voice acting behind them.  You begin to feel a bond with your friends, and an immense hatred for your ruthless enemies.  Every nazi boss or major character is different, and by the end of the game, you will want to kill every last one of them.  All of this character development is backed up by secret letters you can collect that talk about the characters, or audio logs that you can unlock.  Nobody in this game feels flat, especially not your character, B. J. Blazckowicz.  He is not the traditional, remorseless first-person-shooter protagonist at all.  He feels regret, or sympathy, or disgust, or hatred.  He too interacts with his surroundings and turns an already great game into an excellent experience.

All in all, you should definently play this.  It has really changed the way I view first-person-shooters, and I feel like now I've been spoiled by this wonderful game.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a follow up to the mediocre Wolfenstein game from 2009, which didn't really stand out against other WWII games and just generally failed to innovate. Coming from the team responsible for games like The Darkness and The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay, I had very high hopes for a polished shooter with a riveting story. I can happily say I was not disappointed; from start to finish, Wolfenstein: The New Order is expertly crafted and memorable in every way.
You are BJ Blaskowics, US soldier and steadfast killing machine, tasked with the elimination of General Deathshead. Standing out from previous game, BJ's character is extremely well characterised and likeable, supported by strong voice work and character movement/modelling. All of the characters in this game have excellent voice acting, and this really supports the role of the villains in the game; characters such as Frau Engel and Deathshead were memorable because of the terrifying non-combat encounters reminiscent of scenes from Inglourious Basterds.
Gameplay generally borrows from thw work of Quentin Tarantino, with plenty of gory explosions and dismemberment. The shooting mechanics are tight and refined, including a wide range of weapons which can all be dual wielded for maximum carnage. This works fairly well and allows the player to mix up the gameplay whenever it is desired. You can also take cover and peer over obstacles. You also have a mostly non-regenerating health bar, and there is more empasis on old school mechanics like health-kits and armour pickups. The refinement of somewhat simple mechanics means that this game is a successful blend of old and new age shooters, meaning the game never grows boring and even breathes fresh life into the genre. The levels are less restricted than other games of the genre, and you are actively encouraged to explore in order to find new weapons and unlocks. New features of the game such as perks (new upgrades unlocked by performing specific tasks) are not necessary to the game, but provide an interesting addition for completionists.
The visuals are also quite polished, and the game is often stunning to observe. However, there are occassionally texture pop-ins and slow loading textures, which can get distracting over the course of the game. Despite this, most of the game retains decent visual quality.
Overall, Wolfenstein: The New Order is an entertaining, over-the-top shooter that surprises you with a quality story and characters you'll really invest in. The high quality of the game ensures a definite return for the series, and has given me high hopes for both this franchise as well as DOOM; Machine Games has lived up to their reputation and delivered a fantastic game not unlike The Darkness and Riddick. Excellent and surprising. 10 / 10.

reviewText: Now I did not get my hopes high before playing this game. I expected it to be just another generic shooter that I am gonna have good 5-6 hours of fun with. Oh boy was I wrong. It starts at a high speed and it carries that momentum till the very last seconds of the game. Playing it on Uber difficulty is a must and reminds me of good old days of brutally hard FPS games, where there was not automatic health regen and replaying one part of the game endlessly was a common thing. The stealth aspects of the game are very simple, yet really fun and easy to grasp. Same can be said about the story, which is surprisingly well written and is not just another war shooter with Hitler in the main role (no Hitler at all in this game). Graphics are really well done, but do not push your PC to the point where you do not get constant 60 FPS, or else you are going to have a bad time with a game of this kind. Gameplay is very fluid and feels natural, nothing stands in your way and the controls just make sense. You are going to spend more than one night on this game as well, as it is about 12 to 14 hours long, depeding on your playstyle and difficulty you are going to play. TL;DR ♥♥♥♥ing buy it and enjoy the living ♥♥♥♥ out of it, because it is one of a kind in this day and age and I NEED MORE OF IT:

reviewText: This was a surprising game, even after hearing reviews about it being a surprisingly good game, I still found myself getting wrapped up in the characters, and really feeling the weight fo the decisions I had to make. Combat was solid and fast and brutal, and ridiculously gruesome, definitely not a game for the weak of heart. The game features a really well-built progression system as you go through each level and obtain more and more pieces and parts (not all are found as part of the story, some have to be discovered) and you can really feel the changes in combat as you pick them up.\nMy one complain is that, sometimes, the direction I was supposed to go in was either difficult to follow or stuck me in a bad place with next to no health, and then it saved with me at that point. Nothing playing carefully/slowly wouldn't fix, but sometimes it felt flow-breaking to have to halt the Nazi-Killing-Marathon to tiptoe my way through.\nGreat to play as a Stealth Game or as a pure shoot-'em-up, this is DEFINITELY worth the money they charge. 10/10~

reviewText:
If you are looking for a pure action shooter in the over the top style of Quentin Tarantino this is your game.

It carries all the hallmarks of the classic shooter that have gotten so overlooked in the current list of shooters. You can lean out from cover, there are multiple ways to move around a level, the enemies are aggreessive and will flank you if you stay still for too long, and the weapons are just plain fun. Each has their own unique secondary mode with most of them having the option for dual wielding no matter how ridiculous that may be for the weapon type.

The characters and story are fairly run of the mill though there are some disturbing exceptions and what you'd expect from this sort of game, just people trying to survive though there are plenty of quirky and memorable faces to be sure. For the most part those characters are well used and the voice acting is superb.

A word of caution however, this game can get grisly. There is a lot of blood and some very disturbing imagery involved that is not normally touched upon in games. To put it simply: you're fighting the Nazis, expect all that implies in gruesome detail, they didn't hold back much.

In short, go and kill some Nazis.

reviewText:
I bought this game on its premise that the Nazis won World War II. The retro futuristic aspect of the game added to my enjoyment. And no hint of multiplayer made this come to the top of my list. The game is challenging at times but it was not enough to drive me away from finishing the game in a long weekend marathon gaming session.

The game writer did well. I was not expecting the amount of character development  that Blazkowicz undergoes. You feel his pain and sorrow about what he has done and witnessed; his hopes for the future. Over the course of my twelve hour pay through I slow found myself becoming emotionally drawn into Blazkowicz's story and why he was fighting against the tyranny of the Nazis. The mucsical score was another unexpected great joy. Unlike most other games that just have music to have it, here the music adds to the overall feel of teh game and fits the mind set of Blazkowicz at the current moment in time.

Having an American protagonist but not going to Nazi occupied United States was a small disappointment but going to the moon made up for that. Nazi moon base for the win.

A great FPS with a very dark story of what it could be like if the Germans had won the war, expect horrorific encounters and acts of crualty but told in a way as though you were there yourself and not just someone playing a character.
Story cutscenes are sometimes interactable, many a time I watched them playout only to watch my death approach just because I didn't realise I was supposed to do something.

Game play wise it  is very well done as enemy AI will happily throw grenades to you and not rush over to their deaths to the point they seem to have an unexhaustable supply of them.  As with any FPS they also have no issues with ammo limits but will reload their weapons when empty.

Main problem with this game is that you will likely get lost and will have no clue where to go untill you blunder into it, there is a map feature as the game keeps telling me but I never did use it.

This is a great game that is very bloody in more ways then one and has great replay value.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: A solid FPS campaign for sure.  Lots of fun, top notch graphics, cool hidden easter eggs for those of you old enough to remember the original Wolfenstein.  I was excited when I saw this remake being backed by Bethesda, and I think it was money well spent.  Cant wait for DLC and/or sequels, and of course DOOM!!!

reviewText: This game is awesome ! Could of been longer but still good fun. If you played the other Wolfenstein series then this is a must.
